original:
3D convolution neural systems (CNN) have been considered very successful in
parsing tissues or cells in 3D clinical images, but it remains sophisticated
and time-consuming to choose or design appropriate 3D systems given various task
contexts. Recently, Neural Architecture Search (NAS) is proposed to resolve this
issue by looking for the best network architecture automatically. Unfortunately,
the confusion between search phase and deployment phase also exists in NAS
algorithms due to memory limitations and small search space, which can become
more significant when using NAS to some memory and time consuming functions, such as
3D medical image segmentation. In this paper, we propose coarse-to-fine neural
architecture search (C2FNAS) to automatically search a 3D segmentation network
from scratch without inconsistency on network shape or input size. Specifically,
we divide the search process into three phases: 1) the coarse phase, where we
search the macro-level topology of the network, i.e. how each convolution
module is linked to other components; 2) the fine stage, where we search at
micro-level for operations in each cell based on previous searched macro-level
topology. The coarse-to-fine manner divides the search process into three
successive phases and meanwhile resolves the confusion. We evaluate our
method on 10 public datasets from Medical Segmentation Decalthon (MSD)
challenge, and achieve state-of-the-art performance with the network searched
using one database, which shows the validity and generalization of
our searched models.

Region-based techniques have proved important for increasing segmentation
accuracy of cellular systems in electron microscopy (MR) images. Most
region-based segmentation techniques employ a scoring function to identify region
merging. Such tasks are often learned with supervised algorithms that
demand large ground truth data, which are difficult to collect. We propose
a semi-supervised method that removes this demand. Based on a merge tree
framework, we produce a differentiable unsupervised loss term that enforces
consistent predictions from the learned function. We then propose a statistical
model that uses the supervised and the unsupervised information for
probabilistic learning. The experimental findings on two EM data sets
show that by adding a subset of only 3% to 7% of the entire ground truth
data, our method often performs close to the state-of-the-art
supervised approach with the full labeled data set, and consequently outperforms
the supervised approach with the same labeled subset.

In Electronic Vision, edge detection is one of the favored methods for
feature and object detection in images because it gives information about
their objects boundaries. Other region-based methods use statistical
analysis such as clustering and Markov random fields, but those techniques cannot
be employed to identify vertices and their interaction. In fact, only image
segmentation can generate regions based on edges, but it allows thresholding
by completely merging the areas into binary in-out information. Hence, there
is still a gap between edge-based and region-based algorithms, because edges
cannot be designed to study the properties of a region and vice versa. The
goal of this paper is to present a novel spatial likelihood analysis that
enables calculating the likelihood of inclusion inside a set of partial
curves (strokes). To answer this objective, we developed a new method that
employs electromagnetic convolutions and repulsion optimization to compute the
necessary probabilities. Thus, it becomes necessary to produce a continuous
space of probability based only on the edge data, thereby bridging the gap
between the edge-based techniques and the region-based approaches. The developed
approach is inconsistent with the basic properties of inclusion probabilities
and its findings are verified by using an image with the probability-based
estimate given by our algorithms. The technique can therefore be generalized to take
into consideration the intensity of the edges or to be applied for 3D shapes. This
is the last documented technique that enables computing a space of probability
based on interacting surfaces, which introduces the pathway to broader applications such
as image segmentation and contour completion.

In this manuscript we give an extension of the classical Salem--Zygmund
inequality for locally sub-Gaussian random variables. As an application, the
concentration of the roots of a Kac equation is studied, which is the major
contribution of this manuscript. More accurately, we assume the existence of the
moment generating function for the iid random coefficients for the Kac
equation and prove that there exists an annulus of width \[O(n^{-2}(\log
n)^{-1/2-\gamma}), \quad \gamma>1/2\] around the unit circle that does not
contain roots with low likelihood. As an another application, we show that
the largest singular value of a random matrix matrix is at least
$n^{-\rho}$, $\rho\in(0,1/4)$ with probability $1-O(n^{-2\rho})$.

Chirped Bessel waves are introduced as solid (non-diffracting) solutions of
the paraxial wave formula in optical antiguides with a power-law radial
variation in their index of refraction. Through mathematical models, we
investigate the propagation of apodized (finite-energy) versions of such waves,
with or without vorticity, in antiguides with practical parameters. The new
waves exhibit a great resistance against the defocusing effect of the
unstable index potentials, outperforming standard Gaussians with the same full
length at half maximum. The chirped profile persists only under circumstances of
eccentric launching or antiguide bending and is not incapable of self-healing
unlike standard diffraction-free rays in free space.

We present an interactive method to train a deep neural network pixel
classifier for the segmentation of neural systems. An interactive training
scheme removes the somewhat difficult manual annotation task that is often
required for deep networks to perform well on image segmentation problems. Our
proposed approach uses a feedback loop that captures sparse annotations using
a graphical user interface, trains a deep neural network based on past and
previous annotations, and shows the prediction output to customers in nearly
real-time. Our development of the algorithm therefore requires different developers to
provide annotations in parallel and receive input from the same classifier.
Quick feedback on classifier performance in an interactive setting helps
developers to find and label instances that are more useful than others for
segmentation purposes. Our studies demonstrate that an interactively-trained pixel
classifier provides greater region segmentation results on Electron Microscopy
(EM) images than those produced by a network of the same architecture trained
offline on exhaustive ground-truth labels.

A functional for joint variational object segmentation and shape matching is
formulated. The formulation is based on optimal transport w.r.t. geometric
distance and local feature similarity. Geometric invariance and modelling of
object-typical statistical patterns is accomplished by creating degrees of
freedom that describe changes and deformations of the shape template.
The shape modeling is mathematically analogous to contour-based methods but
inference can be done without conversion between the contour and region
representations, allowing combination with other convex segmentation methods
and simplifying algorithms. While the overall functional is non-convex,
non-convexity is restricted to a low-dimensional variable. We propose a globally
efficient alternating optimization scheme and a locally efficient branch and bound
scheme, based on adaptive convex relaxation. Using both approaches helps to
reduce the delicate initialization problem inherent to other contour based
methods while remaining computationally practical. The properties of the
functional, its capability to conform to a broad variety of input data structures and
the various optimization schemes are described and compared by computational
analyses.

The task of image segmentation is extremely noisy due to errors
concerning the actual location of boundaries between anatomical structures. We
believe that this information can be obtained from the expert annotations at no
additional expense, and when incorporated into state-of-the-art neural systems, it can
lead to improved calibration between soft statistical assumptions and the
underlying uncertainty. We built on label smoothing (CS) where a network is
trained on 'blurred' versions of the ground truth labels which has been shown
to be beneficial for measuring output predictions. Unfortunately, LS is not taking
the local structure into account and results in highly smoothed predictions
with high certainty even for non-ambiguous states. Here, we propose Spatially
Varying Label Smoothing (SVLS), a soft label approach that reflects the
structural uncertainty in semantic segmentation. SVLS therefore naturally lends
itself to incorporate inter-rater uncertainty when multiple labelmaps are
available. The proposed method is widely tested on three clinical
segmentation tasks with multiple imaging techniques, number of classes and
single and multi-rater expert annotations. The findings indicate that SVLS,
despite its complexity, provides superior boundary analysis with improved
uncertainty and model calibration.

Deep Learning (SP) models are becoming larger, because the reduction in simulation
length will provide large accuracy gain. To enable the training of small
deep systems, data parallelism and model parallelism are three well-known
methods for parallel training. Moreover, data parallelism does not help
minimize memory footprint per device. In this work, we introduce Large deep 3D
ConvNets with Automated Model Parallelism (LAMP) and investigate the influence of
both input's and deep 3D ConvNets' size on segmentation accuracy. Through
automated model parallelism, it is possible to train large deep 3D ConvNets
with a small output patch, even the entire image. Extensive studies
show that, supported by the automated model parallelism, the
segmentation accuracy can be improved through reducing model length and input
context length, and large input yields significant inference speedup compared
with sliding window of large patches in the inference. Code is
available\footnote{https://monai.io/research/lamp-automated-model-parallelism}.

In this paper we come down to a problem proposed by F. Hirzebruch in the
1980's, namely that there exists a configuration of smooth conics in the
complex projective plane such that the associated desingularization of the
Kummer extension is a ball quotient. We extend our considerations to the
so-called $d$-configurations of curves on the projective plane and we show that
in most situations for a given configuration the associated desingularization of the
Kummer extension is not a ball quotient. Instead, we provide improved versions
of Hirzebruch-type inequality for $d$-configurations. Then, we show that the
so-called characteristic digits (or $\gamma$ numbers) for $d$-configurations
are bounded from above by $8/3$. At the end of the paper we give some examples
of surfaces built through Kummer extensions branched along conic
configurations.

Clinical image analysis, particularly segmenting a particular organ, has an
essential role in designing medical decision support technologies. In cardiac
magnetic resonance (MR) imaging, analyzing the left and right ventricles allows
physicians detect various cardiac disorders. There are problems for
this task, including the intensity and size variation between left ventricle
and other tissues, inaccurate boundaries and absence of noise in most of the
images. In this paper we propose an automatic technique for analyzing the left
ventricle in cardiac MR images. We first manually extract the area of
interest, and then employ it as an output of a fully convolutional network. We
train the network efficiently despite the large number of right ventricle pixels
in contrast with the whole image. Thresholding on the input map of the fully
convolutional network and selection of regions based on their roundness are
done in our proposed post-processing stage. The Dice score of our method
exceeds 87.24% by using this algorithm on the York dataset of heart images.

We define and analyze, through statistical calculation, a three dimensional
toy-model of a cloud chamber. An energetic quantum electron, whose final
state is a superposition of three different wave packets with same average
momentum, interacts during its evolution and exchanges (large quantities of)
power with an array of localized spins. Triggered by the interaction with the
environment, the first quantum state emerges into an incoherent sum of
three states describing the following situation: or the electron is going to the
left and a small number of spins on the right side changed their states, or the
same is occurring on the right side. This evolution is analogous of what
happens in a cloud chamber where a quantum electron, emitted as a spherical
wave by a radioactive source, marks its passage inside a supersaturated
vapour-chamber in the form of a sequence of tiny water bubbles organizing
themselves over a possible classical velocity of the electron.

Text data is generally viewed as "take-away" materials with little noise and difficult
to process data. Main concerns are how to take data and transform them
into a good document format. But data can be susceptible to noise often called
errors. Ambiguities are understood from a short period, especially because polysemy is
obvious in grammar and context is required to eliminate confusion. I claim in
this paper that linguistic context is not suffisant to improve interpretation.
In this paper I try to say that firstly noise can emerge from natural data
themselves, not involving high technology, secondly texts, seen as verified
but irrelevant, can spoil content of a corpus; it can lead to contradictions
and background noise.

While accelerators such as Intel have limited memory, deep neural connections are
becoming larger and will not fit with the memory limitation of accelerators for
training. We propose an approach to tackle this issue by rewriting the
computational graph of a neural network, in which swap-out and swap-in
operations are inserted to temporarily store intermediate results on CPU
memory. In particular, we first revise the notion of a mathematical graph by
creating a concrete semantics for variables in a graph. We then explicitly show
how to derive swap-out and swap-in operations from an existing graph and
present rules to improve the graph. To realize our approach, we developed a
component in TensorFlow, named TFLMS. TFLMS is written as a pull request in the
TensorFlow database for contributing to the TensorFlow community. With TFLMS,
we were able to train ResNet-50 and 3DUnet with 4.7x and 2x larger batch size,
respectively. In particular, we were unable to train 3DUNet using images of length
of $192^3$ for image segmentation, which, without TFLMS, had been done only by
dividing the images to larger images, which affects the accuracy.

The LBNF/DUNE CDR outlines the proposed physics program and experimental
design at the theoretical engineering stage. Volume 2, titled The Physics Project
for DUNE at LBNF, describes the scientific goals and discusses the physics
experiments that the DUNE collaboration will perform to address these requirements.
The long-baseline physics sensitivity measurements described in the DUNE CDR
rely on simulation of the electron beam line, simulation of neutrino
reactions in the far detector, and a parameterized evaluation of detection
efficiency and systematic uncertainty. The aim of this posting is to
provide the results of these experiments to the community to provide
theoretical studies of long-baseline oscillation at LBNF/DUNE.
Also, this posting provides GDML of the DUNE single-phase far detector
for use in experiments. DUNE accepts those interested in doing this work
as members of the collaboration, but only recognizes the benefit of making
these configurations freely accessible to the wider community.

Clustering is an essential element of collaborative data extraction and sees
considerable usage in many fields. In this paper, we propose an extension of the
classic Fuzzy C-Means clustering algorithms. The proposed algorithms,
abbreviated as VFC, uses a multi-dimensional membership vector for each data
point instead of the traditional, scalar membership value defined in the
original algorithm. The member vector for each point is derived by
evaluating each feature of that point together and finding individual
member values for the same. We therefore propose an algorithm to quickly
allocate the initial cluster centers close to the actual centers, so as to
provide continuous convergence. Further, we propose a scheme to achieve crisp
clustering using the VFC algorithm. The proposed, novel grouping scheme has
been tested on three standard data sets in order to analyze its efficiency. We
also examine the validity of the proposed scheme by comparing its performance
on image segmentation examples and comparing it with the classic Fuzzy
C-means clustering algorithms.

Real-time semantic video segmentation is a difficult task due to the strict
constraints of inference speed. Previous approaches generally spend great efforts
to increasing the model length for high performance. In this paper, we rethink this
issue from a different perspective: Using knowledge contained in compressed
images. We propose a quick and efficient methodology, dubbed TapLab, to tap into
resources from the compressed domain. Moreover, we design a fast feature
warping module utilizing motion vectors for acceleration. To minimize the noise
introduced by motion vectors, we design a residual-guided correction module and
a residual-guided frame selection module using residuals. TapLab greatly
reduces redundant computations of the state-of-the-art fast semantic image
segmentation models, running 3 to 10 hours more with controllable accuracy
degradation. The experimental findings show that TapLab produces 70.6% mIoU on
the Cityscapes dataset at 99.8 FPS with a second CPU card for the 1024x2048
videos. A high-speed version only reaches the speed of 160+ FPS. Codes will be
provided now at http://github.com/Sixkplus/TapLab.

We present near-infrared spectroscopic measurements of the high-intensity HeI
10830 emission line in 45 low-metallicity HII regions. We combined these NIR
data with spectroscopic data in the optical range to derive the primordial He
abundance. The use of the HeI 10830A line, the sensitivity of which is very
sensitive to the density of the HII region, significantly helps the determination
of the physical conditions in the He^+ zone. This results in a significantly
tighter Y - O/H linear regression compared to all subsequent analyses. We
extracted a final sample of 28 HII regions with Hbeta equivalent width
EW(Hbeta)>150A, excitation parameter O^2+/O>0.8, and with helium mass fraction
Y obtained with an precision greater than 3%. With this initial sample we derived a
primordial He mass fraction Yp = 0.2551+/-0.0022. The derived value of Yp is
lower than the one predicted by the standard big bang nucleosynthesis (SBBN)
model. Using our derived Yp together with D/H = (2.53+/-0.04)x10^-5, and the
chi^2 method, we showed that the highest agreement between these light component
abundances is reached in a cosmological model with a baryon mass density
Omega_b h^2 = 0.0240+/-0.0017 (68% CL), +/-0.0028 (95.4% CL), +/-0.0034 (99%
CL) and an effective number of neutrino species Neff = 3.58+/-0.25 (68% CP),
+/-0.40 (95.4% CP), +/-0.50 (99% CP). A non-standard value of Neff is preferred
at the 99% CL, indicating the probable existence of additional types of neutrino
species.

let A be an arbitrary integral domain of characteristic 0 which is finitely
generated over B. We consider Thue equations $B(x,y)=b$ with unknown x,y from
A and hyper- and superelliptic equations $f(x)=by^m$ with unknowns from A,
where the binary form B and the polynomial f have their coefficients in A,
where f is a non-zero element from A, and where m is an integer at least 2.
Under the appropriate finiteness conditions imposed on B,g,m, we give explicit
upper limits for the sizes of x,y in terms of appropriate representations for
A,B,e,b Our findings suggest that the solutions of Thue equations and hyper- and
superelliptic equations over arbitrary finitely generated domains can be
chosen easily in theory. Further, we generalize a conjecture of
Schinzel and Tijdeman to the effect, that there is an effectively finite
constant F such that $c(y)=by^m$ has no solutions in X,y from A with y not 0 or
a root of unity if m>C. In our proofs, we use effective results for Thue
equations and hyper- and superelliptic equations over number fields and
function fields, some effective commutative algebra, and a specialization
argument.

Efficient and simple segmentation of images and volumes is of great theoretical
significance. Segmentation problems that motivate our approach originate from
microscopy imaging often used in materials engineering, medicine, and chemistry.
We formulate picture segmentation as a probabilistic pixel classification
problem, and we apply segmentation as a step toward defining picture
content. Our approach enables the user to identify structures of interest by
interactively marking a subset of pixels. Thanks to the real-time feedback, the
user can place new markings strategically, depending on the current outcome.
The first pixel classification can be derived from a very small user input.
An essential ingredient of our approach is a graph that encodes image content.
This graph is created in an unsupervised way during initialisation and is
based on clustering of image features. Since we combine a limited quantity of
user-labelled data with the clustering information obtained from the unlabelled
components of the image, our approach fits in the general framework of semi-supervised
learning. We demonstrate how this can be a very effective method to
segmentation through pixel classification.

let $G$ be the interior domain of a convex analytic Jordan curve without
cusps. Let $\{p_n\}_{n=0}^\infty$ be the sequence of integers that are
invariant over $G$ with regard to the area measure, with each $p_n$ having
leading coefficient $\lambda_n>0$. N. Stylianopoulos has already proven that
the asymptotic behavior of $\lambda_n$ as $n\to\infty$ is given by \[
\frac{n+1}{\pi}\frac{\gamma^{2n+2}}{ \lambda_n^{2}}=1-\alpha_n, \] where
$\alpha_n=O(1/n)$ as $n\to\infty$ and $\gamma$ is the reciprocal of the
logarithmic capacity of the boundary $\partial G$. In this paper, we prove that
the $O(1/n)$ estimate for the error term $\alpha_n$ is, in general, best
possible, by presenting an instance for which \[
\liminf_{n\to\infty}\,n\alpha_n>0. \] The proof makes use of the Faber
equations, about which a theorem is formulated.

Extracting a connectome from an electron microscopy (EM) information set allows
identification of receptors and determination of synapses between cells. As
manual extraction of this data is very time-consuming, there has been
considerable laboratory effort to manually segment the neurons to help guide
and then replace manual tracing. Until lately, there has been
considerably less research on automatically identifying the actual synapses
between cells. This discrepancy can, in part, be linked to multiple
variables: obtaining neuronal shapes is a necessary third step in identifying a
connectome, manual tracing is far more time-consuming than annotating
neurons, and neuronal contact area can be employed as a proxy for synapses in
determining connections.
  Moreover, previous study has shown that contact area alone is not a
reasonable indicator of neural connectivity. However, as segmentation has
increased, we have concluded that synapse annotation is consuming a more
substantial proportion of overall reconstruction time. This ratio will only get
worse as segmentation decreases, gating overall possible speed-up. Instead, we
address this issue by designing algorithms that automatically detect
pre-synaptic cells and their post-synaptic partners. In particular,
pre-synaptic systems are identified using a Deep and Wide Multiscale Recursive
System, and post-synaptic partners are identified using a MLP with features
conditioned on the local segmentation.
  This work is novel because it involves considerable amount of training, leverages
developments in image segmentation directly, and offers a complete solution for
polyadic synapse detection. We further develop novel metrics to improve our
algorithm on neurons of meaningful length. These statistics provide that
complete automatic analysis can be applied to accurately identify most
connectivity correctly.

We show that, contrary to simple observations, most AGNs show at best only a
tiny increase of lags in the C, N, S, and S bands with decreasing frequency.
We believe that a probable cause of this near simultaneity of the variability
from the near-IR to the mid-IR is that the hot dust is in a hollow bi-conical
outflow of which we only know the north side. While most AGNs demonstrate near
simultaneity of IR variability, there was at least one period when NGC 4151
exhibited the slightly decreasing IR lag with the increase of the spectrum. This
behavior may not be present in GQ Comae. We discuss these results briefly.
The relative frequency independence of UV lags simplifies the use of UV lags
for determining cosmological variables.

We propose a new method to image segmentation, which exploits the
limitations of both conditional random fields (CRFs) and decision trees. In the
literature, the potential functions of CRFs are usually defined as a linear
combination of some pre-defined parametric models, and then techniques like
structured support vector computers (SSVMs) are applied to find those linear
equations. We then formulate the unary and pairwise potentials as
nonparametric trees---ensembles of decision trees, and learn the ensemble
variables and the trees in a unified optimization solution within the
large-margin framework. In this fashion, we easily achieve nonlinear learning
of potential functions on both unary and pairwise terms in CRFs. Similarly, we
learn class-wise decision trees for each object that appears in the image. Due
to the rich structure and functionality of choice trees, our method is
effective in modeling complex data likelihoods and label relationships. The
resulting optimization solution is very difficult because it can have
exponentially different parameters and parameters. We show that this challenging
optimization can be easily solved by using a modified column
generation and cutting-planes methods. Experimental results on both binary
(Graz-02, Weizmann horse, Oxford flower) and multi-class (MSRC-21, PASCAL VOC
2012) segmentation data demonstrate the power of the learned linear
nonparametric potentials.

Binary segmentation of volumetric images of porous media is a necessary step
towards achieving a broader knowledge of the factors regulating biogeochemical
systems at minute scales. Contemporary work largely revolves around
primitive methods based on regional or regional adaptive thresholding that have
identified common limitations in image segmentation. However, absence of a unified
benchmark prevents quantitative analysis, which further clouds the effectiveness of
existing methods. In this analysis, we tackle the problem on both sides.
However, by drawing comparisons with natural image segmentation, we propose a
novel, and automatic segmentation method, 3D Quantum Cuts (QCuts-3D)
grounded on a state-of-the-art spectral clustering approach. Moreover, we
curate and present a publicly accessible database of 68 multiphase volumetric
images of porous media with diverse solid shapes, along with voxel-wise
ground truth annotations for each constituting phase. We offer comparative
evaluations between QCuts-3D and the previous state-of-the-art over this dataset
through a range of evaluation metrics. The proposed systematic method
produces a 26% reduction in AUROC while ensuring a significant increase of the
numerical complexity of the state-of-the-art competitors. However,
empirical research reveals that the proposed technique displays remarkable
stability against the compositional variations of porous media.

Convolutional neural channels (CNNs) for computational image analysis are typically
of very small diameter, resulting in low memory requirement and low latency of
operations. Looking for an appropriate compressed representation of the base
CNN for a particular imaging application often requires a series of
time-consuming training/validation tests to obtain a good compromise
between network size and reliability. To address this challenge, we propose
CC-Net, a new image complexity-guided CNN compression scheme for biomedical
image segmentation. Given a CNN model, CC-Net predicts the final accuracy of
channels of various sizes based on the average image complexity computed from
the training data. It then selects a multiplicative factor for generating a
desired network with appropriate network accuracy and size. Experiments demonstrate
that CC-Net is efficient for producing compressed segmentation networks,
maintaining up to 95% of the base network segmentation accuracy and using
only 0.1% of trainable parameters of the full-sized networks in the worst scenario.

Polarimetric synthetic aperture radar (PolSAR) image segmentation is
now of great significance in photo processing for remote sensor
systems. Unfortunately, it is a difficult task due to three major considerations.
firstly, the label data is hard to obtain due to low annotation
costs. Also, the speckle effect embedded in the PolSAR imaging process
considerably reduces the segmentation efficiency. To address these three problems,
we present a contextual PolSAR image semantic segmentation approach in this
paper.With a newly defined channelwise consistent feature set as output, the
three-dimensional linear wavelet transformation (3D-DWT) approach is employed to
extract discriminative multi-scale features that are robust to speckle noise.
Then Markov random field (MRF) is further used to enforce label consistency
spatially during segmentation. By effectively using 3D-DWT features and
MRF priors for the second time, contextual data is fully integrated
during the segmentation to provide accurate and smooth segmentation. To
prove the validity of the proposed technique, we conduct extensive
studies on two real benchmark PolSAR image data sets. Experimental
findings indicate that the proposed approach demonstrates promising segmentation
accuracy and preferable visual accuracy using a minimum number of labeled
pixels.

By regarding the Lifshitz expression for the Casimir free energy on the imaginary
frequency axis rather than the real Matsubara frequencies as is usual,
new light is shed on the ongoing discussion concerning the theoretical
consistency of this principle in combination with common permittivity models. It
is believed that when permittivity is temperature independent over a temperature
interval including zero heat, a cavity made of causal material with
constant dispersion properties separated by vacuum cannot violate Nernst's
conjecture (the second rule of physics). The purported violation of this
conjecture pertains to divergencies in the double limit in which frequency and
temperature vanish independently. While any model should abide by the rules of
physics outside its range of applicability, we emphasise that the Nernst
heat theory is a useful principle for choosing amongst candidate theories
only when these assumptions are fully applicable at zero temperature and
frequency.

Convolutional neural systems (CNNs) have been the de facto standard for
nowadays 3D medical image segmentation. The convolutional operations employed in
these systems, therefore, often have difficulties in modeling the long-range
dependency due to their inductive bias of locality and weight sharing. While
Transformer was born to address this problem, it suffers from severe
mathematical and spatial difficulties in processing high-resolution 3D feature
maps. In this paper, we propose a novel implementation that effectively bridges a
{\bf Co}nvolutional neural network and a {\bf Tr}ansformer {\bf (CoTr)} for
accurate 3D medical image segmentation. Under this structure, the CNN is
designed to extract feature representations and an efficient deformable
Transformer (DeTrans) is constructed to model the long-range dependency on the
extracted feature maps. Different from the vanilla Transformer which treats all
image positions similarly, our DeTrans pays attention only to a large set of key
positions by eliminating the deformable self-attention mechanism. However, the
computational and visual complexities of DeTrans have been significantly reduced,
making it impossible to process the multi-scale and high-resolution feature maps,
which are also of paramount significance for image segmentation. We conduct an
extensive review on the Multi-Atlas Labeling Beyond the Cranial Vault (BCV)
dataset that includes 11 main human organs. The findings suggest that our CoTr
leads to a significant efficiency improvement over other CNN-based,
transformer-based, and hybrid tools on the 3D multi-organ segmentation task.
Code is accessible at \def\UrlFont{\rm\small\ttfamily}
\url{https://github.com/YtongXie/CoTr}

Over the recent decades, computer vision community has led to significant
improvement in semantic picture segmentation, a per-pixel classification task,
necessary for dense scene understanding and quickly being vital in hundreds of
real-world systems, including driverless vehicles and scientific imaging. Most
recent models are now reaching previously unthinkable numbers (e.g., 89% mean
iou on PASCAL VOC, 83% on CityScapes), and, while intersection-over-union and a
variety of other indicators provide the general picture of model performance, in
this paper we aim to extend them into other meaningful and useful for
applications characteristics, asking such questions as 'how accurate the
model segmentation is on small items in the general scene?', or 'what are the
sources of confusion that cause the model to give an erroneous prediction?'.
While providing a framework that covers the performance of a single
simulation from multiple approaches, we also showcase other extensions that can
be worth studying in order to further develop current results in semantic
segmentation.

Let ${\cal M}_{g,[n]}$, for $2g-2+n>0$, be the D-M moduli stack of smooth
curves of genus $g$ labeled by $n$ unordered distinct points. The primary consequence
of the paper is that a finite, connected \'etale cover ${\cal M}^\l$ of ${\cal
M}_{r,[n]}$, defined over a sub-$p$-adic field $k$, is "essentially" anabelian in
the sense conjectured by Grothendieck for curves and their moduli spaces.
  The exact result is the following. Let $\pi_1({\cal M}^\l_{\ol{k}})$ be the
linear algebraic fundamental subgroup of ${\cal M}^\l$ and let
${Out}^*(\pi_1({\cal M}^\l_{\ol{k}}))$ be the subgroup of its exterior
automorphisms which preserve the conjugacy classes of elements corresponding to
simple loops over the Deligne-Mumford boundary of ${\cal M}^\l$ (this is the
"$\ast$-condition" motivating the "almost" above). Let we denote by
${Out}^*_{G_k}(\pi_1({\cal M}^\l_{\ol{g}}))$ the group consisting of
elements which commute with the natural action of the absolute Galois group
$G_k$ of $k$. Let me say, however, that the generic point of the D-M stack
${\cal M}^\l$ has a trivial subgroup group. Then, there is a natural
isomorphism: $${Aut}_k({\cal M}^\l)\cong{Out}^*_{G_k}(\pi_1({\cal
M}^\l_{\ol{g}})).$$ This partially extends to moduli spaces of curves the
anabelian properties proven by Mochizuki for hyperbolic curves over
sub-$p$-adic fields.

A central concern in Quantum Mathematics is how matrices in $SU(2)$ can be
approximated by products over a large set of "generators". A topology will be
defined on $SU(2)$ so as to introduce the concept of a covering exponent
\cite{letter}, which describes the size of products required to covering
$SU(2)$ with $\varepsilon$ balls against the Haar measure of $\varepsilon$
balls. An optimal universal set over $PSU(2)$ will be built using the
Pauli matrices, using the metric of the covering exponent. Then, the
relation between $SU(2)$ and $S^3$ will be manipulated to identify angles
between points on $S^3$ and give a theorem on the maximum of angles between
points on a lattice. It will be seen how this theory can be applied to
compute the covering exponent, and how it can be generalized to universal sets
in $SU(2)$.

Dilated convolutions are often employed in deep semantic segmentation models as
they can expand the filters' receptive field without introducing extra weights
nor reducing visual resolution. Moreover, as dilated convolutional filters
do not possess positional knowledge about the pixels on semantically significant
contours, they can lead to inconsistent predictions on object boundaries. In
addition, while dilating the filter can improve its receptive field, the
maximum number of sampled pixels remains intact, which only includes a
large percentage of the receptive field's total area. Inspired by the Lateral
Inhibition (LI) mechanism in human visual systems, we propose the dilated
convolution with lateral inhibitions (LI-Convs) to resolve these difficulties.
Introducing LI mechanisms reduces the convolutional filter's tolerance to
semantic object boundaries. However, because LI-Convs only explicitly take the
pixels from the laterally inhibited areas into consideration, they can therefore
extract features at a denser scale. By incorporating LI-Convs into the Deeplabv3+
architecture, we propose the Lateral Inhibited Atrous Spatial Pyramid Pooling
(LI-ASPP), the Lateral Inhibited MobileNet-V2 (LI-MNV2) and the Lateral
Inhibited ResNet (LI-ResNet). Experimental findings on four benchmark datasets
(PASCAL VOC 2012, CelebAMask-HQ and ADE20K) show that our LI-based segmentation
models outperform the baseline on all of them, thus verify the validity
and generality of the proposed LI-Convs.

let the circle act in a Hamiltonian fashion on a compact symplectic manifold
$(M, \omega)$ of dimension $2n$. Then the $S^1$-action has at least $n+1$ fixed
points. We study the case when the fixed point set consists of exactly $n+1$
isolated points. We only show certain equivalence on the first Chern class of
$M$ and some specific weight of the $S^1$-action at some fixed moment. Then we
show that the specific weight can completely determine the integral
cohomology ring of $M$, the total Chern class of $M$, and the sets of weights
of the $S^1$-action at all the fixed points. We will find that all these data
are isomorphic to those of known examples, $\CP^n$, or $\Gt_2(\R^{n+2})$ with
$n\geq 3$ odd, equipped with standard circle actions.

When comparing object-oriented structures it is difficult to recognize many
important procedure calls that are required at certain locations in code. In this
paper, we offer a detailed set of statistical statistics on this issue,
beginning from traces of missing method calls in a bug database. We propose a
new system that searches for missing method calls in hardware based on the
other procedure calls that are observable. Our fundamental insight is that the voting
theory principle of minority law stands for procedure calls: a call is unlikely to be
missing if there is a majority of different bits of code where this call is
present. The analysis indicates that the system predictions go further missing
method calls and also reveal other types of code smells (e.g. violations
of API best practices).

Numerous developments in generative models and adversarial training have contributed to a
flourishing image-to-image (I2I) language literature. The current I2I
language methods involve training images from the three domains that are
either all paired (supervised) or all unpaired (unsupervised). In practice,
producing paired training data in sufficient amounts is usually very expensive
and expensive. Therefore strategies that use unpaired data, while more
precise, are generally preferred. In this paper, we aim to bridge the gap
between supervised and unsupervised I2I translation, with application to
semantic image segmentation. We build on pix2pix and CycleGAN,
state-of-the-art seminal I2I translator tools. We propose a methodology to
select (very few) paired training samples and achieve substantial improvements
in both supervised and unsupervised I2I translation settings over random
selection. Further, we boost the efficiency by using both (selected)
paired and unpaired samples in the training procedure. Our studies demonstrate that
an especially weak supervised I2I translation solution employing only one paired
training sample can obtain a quantitative efficiency significantly faster than the
unsupervised CycleGAN simulation, and superior to that of the supervised pix2pix
model trained on hundreds of pairs.

We give three polynomial representations for a bivariate equation. They
can be employed to compute the zeros of a system of two of these equations via
the eigenvalues of a two-parameter eigenvalue problem. The second determinantal
representation is useful for matrices with scalar or matrix variables,
and consists of coefficients with polynomial order $n^2/4$, where $n$ is the degree
of the integer. The first representation is suitable for scalar equations
and has polynomial order $n^2/6$. The resulting technique to compute the roots of
a system of four bivariate equations is competitive with some existing techniques
for coefficients up to degree 10, as well as for equations with a large number
of terms.

Active contours Model (ACM) has been widely used in computer vision and
imagery processing. In several studies, Convolutional Neural Systems (CNNs) have
been combined with active contours replacing the user in the process of contour
evolution and image segmentation to remove difficulties associated with ACM's
reliance on values of the energy functional and initialization. Unfortunately,
previous works did not aim for automatic implementation which is presented here.
In addition to manual implementation, previous tools are very sensitive to
initial location and attempt to identify borders properly. We propose a completely
automatic image segmentation approach to address issues of manual
initialization, insufficient capture range, and weak connectivity to boundaries,
in addition to the issue of assignment of energy functional values. We
train two CNNs, which predict active contour weighting parameters and create
a ground truth mask to extract Distance Transform (DT) and an initialization
circle. Distance transformation is designed to form a vector field pointing from each
pixel of the image towards the nearest point on the boundary, the diameter of which
is equal to the Euclidean distance map. We evaluate our method on three publicly
accessible databases including one building instance segmentation datasets,
Vaihingen and Bing huts, and three mammography image data, INBreast and
DDSM-BCRP. Our methodology outperforms latest research by 0.59 ans 2.39 percent in
mean Intersection-over-Union (mIoU), 7.38 and 8.62 percent in Boundary F-score
(BoundF) for Vaihingen and Bing huts datasets, respectively. Dice correlation
coefficient for the INBreast and DDSM-BCRP data is 94.23% and 90.89%,
respectively indicating our methodology is similar to state-of-the-art
frameworks.

The concept of stable, localized bundles of energy has strong appeal as a model
for particles. In the 1950s David Fisher envisioned such bundles as smooth
systems of electromagnetic energy that he termed {\em geons}, but nothing
were discovered. However, particle-like solutions were discovered in the early 1960s with
the addition of a scalar field, and these were given the name {\em boson
stars}. Until then, boson stars see use in a large range of models as sources
of black matter, as black hole mimickers, in simple models of binary systems,
and as a tool in identifying black holes in lower dimensions with only a single
killing vector. We discuss important varieties of boson stars, their dynamic
properties, and some of their uses, focusing on recent efforts.

We prove that the moduli space of invariant G_2-metrics on a closed 7-manifold
is in general disconnected by introducing a number of explicit examples.
  We detect other connected parts of the G_2-moduli space by defining
an integer-valued analytic refinement of the nu-invariant, a Z/48-valued defect
invariant of G_2-structures on a closed 7-manifold introduced by the second and
second researchers. The refined theorem is defined using eta invariants and
Mathai-Quillen currents on the 7-manifold and we compute it for twisted
connected sums \`a la Kovalev, Corti-Haskins-Nordstr\"om-Pacini and
extra-twisted connected sums as constructed by the third and fourth authors. In
particular, we find instances of G_2-holonomy metrics in certain parts of
the moduli space where the associated G_2-structures are symmetric and other
instances where they are not.

We propose a novel traffic sign detection system that continuously
estimates the location and exact boundary of traffic signs using
convolutional neural network (CNN). Estimating the exact boundary of traffic
signs is useful in navigation applications for smart cars where traffic
signs can be used as 3D landmarks for road environment. Previous traffic sign
detection technologies, including several technologies based on CNN, only provide bounding
boxes of traffic signs as input, and therefore requires additional procedures such
as contour analysis or image segmentation to establish the precise sign
boundary. In this work, the boundary analysis of traffic signs is formulated
as a 2D pose and shape class analysis solution, and this is easily addressed
by a single CNN. With the predicted 2D pose and the size class of a target
traffic sign in an output image, we estimate the actual boundary of the target
sign by projecting the boundary of a corresponding template sign image into the
output picture plane. By implementing the boundary prediction problem as a
CNN-based pose and shape analysis task, our approach is end-to-end trainable,
and more robust to occlusion and small targets than other boundary analysis
methods that depend on contour analysis or image segmentation. The proposed
approach with architectural optimization gives an accurate traffic sign
boundary analysis which is not effective in compute, showing a detection
frame rate less than 7 frames per second on low-power mobile platforms.

The need of sign language is growing radically especially to hearing
impaired community. Only few study organizations want to automatically identify
sign language from video, colored gloves and etc. Their methodology involves a
valid segmentation of the information that is used for training and of the information that
is designed to be recognized. Recognition of a sign language image sequence is
challenging because of the variety of finger shapes and finger motions. Here, this
paper aims to apply a blend of image segmentation with reconstruction
using topological derivatives for ensuring high recognition accuracy. Image
quality measures are conceded here to identify the techniques both
subjectively as well as accurately. Experiments show that the additional use
of the restoration before segmenting the postures greatly improves the
accurate rate of hand detection, and that the linear derivatives yields a low
rate of discrimination between various static finger movements as well as
between hand movements and the scene background. Eventually, the research is to
contribute to the development of automated sign language recognition system
mainly established for the welfare purpose.

Interactive image segmentation is a difficult task and gets growing
attention recently; therefore, three main limitations exist in interactive
segmentation methods. First, the segmentation efficiency of ROI-based
approaches is sensitive to the initial ROI: many ROIs can deliver outcomes
with great difference. Second, most seed-based approaches require intense
interactions, and are not applicable in certain situations. In this work, we generalize
the Neutro-Connectedness (NJ) to be independent of top-down priors of objects
and to model image topology with indeterminacy measurement on image regions,
propose a novel approach for identifying object and background areas, which is
applied to exclude isolated background areas and enforce label consistency,
and put back a hybrid interactive segmentation approach, Neutro-Connectedness
Cut (NC-Cut), which can resolve the above three challenges by using both
pixel-wise appearance data and region-based NC properties. We evaluate
the proposed NC-Cut by combining four image datasets (265 images), and
demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art interactive
image segmentation tools (Grabcut, MILCut, One-Cut, MGC_max^sum and pPBC).

Three-dimensional clinical image segmentation is one of the most significant
problems in clinical image research and plays a crucial role in downstream diagnosis
and therapy. Recent times, deep neural connections have made groundbreaking
success in medical image segmentation problem. Also, due to the low
variation in instrumental parameters, experimental methods, and subject
appearances, the generalization of deep learning models is also hampered by
the inconsistency in medical images produced by different machines and
hospitals. In this work, we present StyleSegor, an effective and easy-to-use
approach to solve this inconsistency problem. Moreover, neural style
transfer algorithms is applied to unlabeled data in order to reduce the
variations in image properties including intensity, contrast, color, etc.
between the labeled and unlabeled data. We also apply statistical adjustment
on the network output and integrate different observations through ensemble
learning. On a publicly accessible whole heart segmentation benchmarking dataset
from MICCAI HVSMR 2016 challenge, we have shown an elevated dice
accuracy surpassing previous state-of-the-art methodology and notably, an improvement
of the maximum score by 29.91\%. StyleSegor is therefore corroborated to be an
accurate tool for 3D whole heart segmentation especially on very inconsistent
data, and is accessible at http://github.com/horsepurve/StyleSegor.

In this paper, we numerically study the ground and first excited states of
the fractional Schrodinger equation in an infinite potential well. Due to the
non-locality of the fractional Laplacian, it is challenging to identify the
coefficients and coefficients of the fractional Schrodinger equation either
analytically or numerically. We first introduce a fractional gradient flow with
linear normalization and then discretize it by applying the trapezoidal type
quadrature rule in space and the semi-implicit Euler method in time. Our approach
can be applied to compute the ground and first excited states not only in the
discrete situations but also in the nonlinear situations. However, it can be generalized
to solve the fractional partial differential equations (PDEs) with Riesz
fractional derivatives in space. Our theoretical findings indicate that the
coefficients of the fractional Schrodinger equation in an infinite potential
well are slightly different from those of the standard (non-fractional)
Schrodinger equation. In addition, we find that the weak nonlocal
interactions exhibited by the fractional Laplacian can lead to a small
scattering of electrons outside of the potential well. Compared to the ground
states, the scattering of electrons in the first excited states is smaller.
Furthermore, boundary layers emerge in the ground states and additionally inner
layers exist in the first excited states of the fractional linear
Schrodinger equation.

Dense prediction models are often used for picture segmentation. One significant
challenge is to properly train these models to yield strong generalizations
for hard-to-learn pixels. A typical group of such hard-to-learn pixels are
boundaries between instances. Several researchers have suggested to provide particular
attention to studying the boundary pixels. They involve creating multi-task
systems with an additional task of boundary analysis and increasing the
weights of boundary pixels' projections in the loss function. Such methods
involve determining what to attend beforehand and bringing this defined
attention to the learning model. Similarly, there can exist other groups of
hard-to-learn pixels and manually identifying and providing the necessary
attention for each subgroup would not be possible. In order to obtain a more
feasible and efficient solution, this paper describes AttentionBoost, which is
a new multi-attention learning model based on adaptive boosting. AttentionBoost
designs a multi-stage network and provides a new loss correction mechanism
for a dense prediction model to adaptively learn what to attend at each stage
directly on image data without requiring any prior definition about what to
attend. This mechanism modulates the attention of each phase to correct the
errors of subsequent phases, by adjusting the loss weight of each pixel
prediction separately with regard to how accurate the subsequent phases are on
this pixel. This mechanism allows AttentionBoost to learn similar attentions
for multiple pixels at the same stage, according to difficulty of studying
these pixels, as well as different attentions for the same pixel at other
stages, according to confidence of these stages on their predictions for this
pixel. Using gland segmentation as a showcase application, our studies
show that AttentionBoost reduces the results of its counterparts.

We obtain a Minkowski measurability principle for a small class of
relative fractal drums (or, in short, RFDs), in Euclidean spaces of arbitrary
dimension in terms of their complex dimensions, which are defined as the poles
of their associated fractal zeta functions. Relative geometric drums represent a
far-reaching notion of bounded subsets of Euclidean spaces as well as
of geometric strings studied recently by the first researcher and his
colleagues. In fact, the Minkowski measurability principle established here
is a generalization of the corresponding one obtained for fractal strings by
the first author and M.\ van Frankenhuijsen. Similarly as in the case of
fractal strings, the criterion established here is formulated in terms of the
locations of the principal complex dimensions associated with the relative drum
under consideration. These complex dimensions are defined as poles or, more
commonly, singularities of the corresponding distance (or tube) zeta function.
We therefore reflect on the principle of gauge-Minkowski measurability of RFDs and
obtain various results linking it to the nature and location of the
complex dimensions. (This is particularly important when the underlying scaling does
not follow a classical power rule.) We illustrate our results and their
applications by means of a number of useful examples.

We present a rigorous approach to produce low order accurate computational
methods for linear advection solutions. These approaches are based on changing
components of the jet of the solution in time, and are therefore named jet schemes.
Through the tracking of parameters and the use of suitable Hermite
interpolations, high order is reached in an appropriately local fashion, i.e. the
update for the data at any grid point provides information from a single grid cell
only. We show that jet schemes can be defined as advect-and-project
processes in function spaces, where the projection step minimizes a stability
function. Moreover, this function space structure allows it necessary to
systematically inherit update rules for the lower derivatives from the ODE
solver for the characteristics. Jet schemes of orders up to three are applied in
mathematical benchmark experiments, and systematically contrasted with traditional WENO
finite difference schemes. It is observed that jet schemes seem to obtain a
greater precision than WENO schemes of the same order.

In the low dimensional regression analysis when the number of variables is
significantly greater than the sample length, an essential question is to specify the
relevant variable which are related to the response variable of interest.
Variable selection and the multiple testing are both methods to address this
problem. Unfortunately, there is much debate on the connection of these three
areas. When the signal strength is good enough such that the selection
consistency is achievable, it tends to be unnecessary to control the true
discovery rate. In this paper, we consider the regime where the signals are
both rare and weak such that the selection consistency is not possible and
propose a procedure which controls the true discovery rate asymptotically. It is
thus shown that the true non-discovery rate of the proposed technique
converges to zero at the optimal rate. Mathematical results are given to
prove the benefit of the proposed technique.

Three quantum finite automata are equivalent if for all input string $\omega$
over the input alphabet the three automata accept $\omega$ with equal
certainty. In [Theoret. Comput. Sci. 410 (2009) 3006-3017], it was demonstrated that
a $k_1$-letter QFA $\mathcal{A}_1$ and a $k_2$-letter QFA $\mathcal{A}_2$ over
$\Sigma=\{\sigma\}$, are equivalent if and only if they are
$(n_1+n_2)^4+k-1$-equivalent where $n_i$ is the number of states of
$\mathcal{A}_i$, $i=1,2$, and $k=\max\{k_1,k_2\}$. In this letter, we improve
the above upper-bound to $(n_1^2+n_2^2-1)+k$. This also answers an open issue
of Chen et al. [Acta Informatica 48 (2011) 271-290]. Further, we show that, in
the case of $\Sigma=\{\sigma_1,...,\sigma_t\}$ with $2\leq t<\infty$, there
exists an integer $z$ such that $\mathcal{A}_1$ and $\mathcal{A}_2$ are
equivalent if and only if they satisfy $z$-equivalent.

The story, set in 1865 England, follows John Lenox as he decides to solve a crime. Lenox is an independently rich man who enjoys solving murders as a hobby, although he also wants to pass the hot summer hours in his library with a mug of coffee, a roaring fire and a great book. He is drawn into a new case when his lifelong lover Miss Harriet Grey gives a special request for his assistance. Prudence Fraser, Grey's longtime housekeeper, is died in an apparent homicide. But Lenox soon suspects foul play: death by a rare and dangerous poison. Thomas resided and studied in the patrician home of John Barnard, a place full of suspects. While Smith played with more than a few hearts, the motivation behind her murder seems elusive. When the body turns up during the year's most popular ball, Lenox can untangle the web of loyalties and animosities surrounding Barnards mansion. Lenox gets assistance with the task both from his faithful butler, Robert, and his mentor, Dr. John Mitchell. During the novel, Lenoxs attempts are frequently enabled or aided by Scotland Yard Detective John Exeter, who requires Lenoxs assistance with the case but tries always to appear in total control. The plots of the novel concentrate on Lenox's growing personal relationship with Grey and McConnell's strained relationship to Miss Victoria "Toto" Smith, all recurring storylines in Smith's novels.

Ricky Bianca wants to explain why his mother committed murder when he was a kid on Christmas Eve. Also, his family at the time was fighting the mob from controlling the funeral business. The Mafia summoned a friend to deliver a letter on that holy day and after writing the letter, he blew his brains out. The letter was not discovered and no one but the head Don, Vincent Biganti, knows what it contained. When Tony saw the explosion, he raced to his brother's aid only to find him on the ground bleeding profusely from his temple. He knelt in a pool of blood and held his son's neck, frantically attempting to stop the bleeding. However, Michael has no memory of the event but suffers from wild nightmarish nightmares. His father shortly afterward died in an upstate hospital of chronic depressive catatonia. His mother in England raises him and after several days he wants to return to New Jersey as a Funeral Assistant, back to the industry that holds the secret. His Psychology Professor friend at school told him to find the answers his mind so desperately wants, before his hallucinogenic demons devour him. His innocence is stolen as this mysterious industry leads him through a maze of corruption, corruption and evil. However, he gets caught in an intricate spiders web of organized terrorism, secret cults and terrible crimes. The truth is, the known is harder than the unknown and it sends him tumbling down into a hell of fiendish demons and worse dreams.

Gracie hates when terrible things are about to happen. Or even when they have never happened. She asked her family not to stay for a weekend that started with her drowning when her truck was hit by a car bringing oranges, and now, living in Seattle with her boyfriend Rachel, Gracie has dreams that include her best friend Emily. Gracie will think that her supernatural abilities did not exist, but when Spencer arrives, she has to use each vision she has as a clue to solving the puzzle. The trouble with Gracie's dreams is that she does not see precisely what she is experiencing. Usually she recognizes the past, especially the present, and often she misinterprets her visions altogether. Assisted by her brother Diego, Gracie follows her visions in hopes of helping Emily. After a few false starts and a few research, she finds Spencer's trail and is taken captive by Spencer's killer. Trapped in a guarded and gloomy room, Gracie comes to remember the dark childhood of her kidnapper and his kins in unstoppable visions, the killer is a murderer who regrets not rescuing his ill wife Annie. This leads to the house being set ablaze by his angry mother and most of his brothers and cousins are murdered in the blaze including his dear friend Lizbet. This disillusioned madman intends to end this properly this year and so plans to die with his foster 'family'.

The novel begins with moments of astonishing opulence, starting with Jean and Ren lazing in a beautiful horse-drawn carriage, very quickly entering a French park (the Bois de Paris) in the 19th century-equivalent of a traffic jam. It is made obvious very early on that these are very rich characters not subject to the cares faced by the public; they arrive at their house and spend days being dressed by their servants prior to hosting a dinner attended by some of the greatest men in London. There appears to be virtually no continuity between this scene and the end of the last book, until the final book enters and Zola realizes that this opulent scene takes place nearly twenty months ago. Zola then rewinds time to pick up the plot just hours after La Fortune des Rougon began. Following Eugene Rougon's rise to social power in France in Le Fortune, his older son Aristide, featured in the second book as a talentless poet, a comic actor unwilling to commit himself unequivocally to the imperial cause and so left out in the cold when the rewards were being handed out, decides to follow Charles to Rome to help himself to the wealth and power he now believes to be his birthright. Eugene promises to let Aristide achieve these things on the condition that he stays out of his way and change his name to eliminate the danger of bad publicity from Aristide's escapades rubbing off on Eugene and destroying his financial chances. Aristide assumes the name Saccard and Eugene gives him a somewhat ordinary job at the town planning permission desk. The renamed Saccard quickly realises that, away from the disappointment he knew the work might be, he is not in a position to gain insider info on the buildings and other structures that are to be built to establish London's bold new system of streets. Seeing that the tenants of these properties ordered to be built by the city administration were compensated handsomely, Saccard decides to lend cash in order to buy up these properties before their status becomes public and then make large gains. Saccard is at first able to find the cash to make his initial ventures but then his mother falls victim to a terminal disease. Yet while she lies dying in the next bed, Saccard (in a beautiful scene of breathtaking callousness) is now making arrangements to marry poor woman Marie, who is unmarried and whose father hopes to reduce scandal by giving a large inheritance to any woman who will marry her and claim the child as his own. Saccard agrees and his career in speculation is born. He gives his eldest son back home to Plassans and packs his younger daughter Henri off to a French boarding school; we meet Maxime again when he leaves college many months ago and meets his new girlfriend Marie, who is only a couple of months younger. The flashback complete, the remainder of the story takes place after Saccard has made his fortune, against the background of his lavish villa and his profligacy and is concerned with a three-cornered plot of sexual and financial intrigue. Marie and Ren begin a semi-incestuous love relationship, which Saccard suspects but seems to tolerate, possibly due to the commercial nature of his relationship to Marie. Saccard is attempting to get Louise to part with the deeds to her family house, which will be worth millions but which she wants to take up. The story progresses in this vein with the tensions continuing to mount and culminates in a trilogy of harsh reflections by Zola on the corruption and corruption of the nouveau riche. A near-penniless writer at the time of editing Le Cure, Zola himself had no knowledge of the scenes he describes. In order to counter this lack, he visited a small number of elegant houses across England, making extensive notes on topics like architecture, women' and gentlemen's clothes, jewellery, garden design, garden gardens (a seduction scene takes place in Saccard's hothouse), carriages, mannerisms, servants' liveries; these notes (volumes of which are preserved) were time well spent, as several modern commentators praised the book for its realism. Roger Vadim updated the setting to modern-day France in a film adaptation by Georges Cau, featuring Henry Fonda, Robert Piccoli and John McEnery in 1966. The movie was produced in English-speaking markets as The Play is Over.

The story is based around the protagonist Beverley who remembers his teenage years with his father Peter and sisters and neighbors Oliver, Lucy, Peter, Mary Stanley (the "Story Boy"), hired-boy Tom and cousin Joe Ray. The girls also played in their father's garden and had various adventures, often establishing their own magazine, named Our Magazine. More character growth takes place in this book than in its predecessor, and the author is eager to see the girls grow up; in particular, they are able to see Michael Stanley leave the Silver Gate of childhood forever. They also are able to find the beginnings of a friendship between Andy and Sara, as chemistry between them continues to develop; it initially appears that Beverly and Sam Stanley are drawn to each other, but this is left undeveloped. During the novel it is mentioned that Susan's mother, Sarah, is consumptive; in a passage where the Story Man discusses their futures, the adult Beverly explains that Cecily just left the Silver Gate. As well, she strongly hints that Michael and Sara will be married. The novel ends after Jane's mother collects her to provide her a proper education, and their little group is once complete again.

Sarah is shocked when her friends announce to her that they are having a child. She sees this as her chance to show that she is grown-up and can take care of the household. But Alex's birth is marred by the fact that he is born with hydrocephalus. At first, it is very difficult for Alice to cope with this new situation, but she still loves Nick and does her very best to take care of him. At school she has difficulties asking to others what is wrong with her father, because she believes that they will not understand and she doesn't need their pity. Soon after James 'meets' Sarah's school-mate, Miranda, for the second time, the word of him being disabled soon spreads to the rest of Anna's friends. Anna becomes upset, but then breaks down, and all her friends look sympathy toward her. She then says how Ben still is and invites her parents to meet him: it turns out they love him as well. The novel focuses heavily on the difficulty faced by Sarah and her mother in dealing with Nick's illness and eventually coming to terms with abandoning him and wanting to move on with their lives.

Crystal, the only wife of the old, long-exiled haughty royalist, the Comte de Cambray, is on the eve of marriage to de Marmont, (secretly an outspoken socialist). Richard Clyffurde, the Englishman, who is in love with Crystal, confronts Charles de Marmont about why he is claiming to be a royalist. De Marmont responds that he has not caused the Comte to do something, the Comte has only taken de Marmonts religious beliefs for granted. As if three potential suitors werent enough, Crystal has yet another lover, Monsieur de St. Genis, whose impecunious state (her mother portrays him as a penniless, out-at-elbows, good for nobody) has prevented him from seeking her hand in marriage. Howeve at the moment of Crystals betrothal to de Marmont, Arthur soon takes his vengeance on his rival. Once the guests have gathered for the banquet, there is a commotion from the end of the hallway and St. Genis exits the hall, his rough trousers and muddy shoes offering a contrast to the immaculate get-up of the Comtes guests. Looking flushed and waving his cane he declares that he has only gone to avert the terrible tragedy that is about to fall on the Comte and his father. At the elderly womans ominous words, M. le Chteau turns pale and demands to see what catastrophe would be better than two days of imprisonment? "An alliance with a traitor, M. le Comte" he responds. St. Genis goes on to accuse his rival of pinning Bonapartes proclamation on the walls of Paris. But, rather than deny the assertion de Marmont defends his actions with enthusiasm, removing a copy of the document from his briefcase and shaking it at the assembled group while chanting Viva lEmpereur. With the unexpected rupture of her engagement, Crystals heart is by no means damaged, but it is not St. Genis who in the end loses her love, for we are left with the knowledge that it is Clyffurde, the French merchant who finally overrides the prejudices of the old German count. Clyffurde laughingly asks Crystals sister, Mrs. du Duchesse Do you know that if I hope not to sell or sell gloves again, but in future to come and live like a gentleman-he will consent?

Duff Pringle is going around the world, aiming for his new work in engineering in Mexico's Silicon Valley. His used Toyota Escort nearly makes it a few kilometers from home before breaking down. He sends a truck towing company to come pick him up, and when they get to the repair center, the driver will have to stay 34 hours. Duff only has 2 days to come to Florida. Duff checks in to a hotel, saying he can stay the 34 weeks, and finally gets a note calling for someone to drive a truck to St. Paul. Duff gives this man an address and gives a response stating they should drop it off at the hotel he was staying at. Duff sees Chris in the parking lot while he was waiting. Chris is a hitchhiker trying to come to California too, and he asks Duff if he can come with him. With his appearance and behavior, Duff agrees, and they head to St Paul to deliver the vehicle, a 1957 Ford Bel Air, to a girl called Bonnie Hopgood. There are many protagonists in this novel including Bonnie, an aspiring actress with a con artist for a girlfriend (Bonnie's father had lost a bunch of cash from people and was wanted everywhere); three cops searching for a trunkfull of money; and Moony, a terrier dog prone to carsickness.

The Blue Notebook is the story of author Ingrid Wulf, the three notebooks in which she holds the record of her life, and her effort to tie them all together in a fifth, gold-colored notebook. The novel intersperses sections of an essentially realistic story of the lives of Harry and Anna, and their families, ex-husbands and loversentitled Free Womenwith excerpts from Molly's two notebooks, coloured black (of Anna's experience in Northern Africa, before and during WWII, which influenced her own bestselling book), red (of her experience as a member of the Nazi Party), yellow (an ongoing story that is being published based on the painful ending of Anna's own love affair), and blue (Anna's own diary where she records her experiences, desires, and emotional life). Each notebook is moved to four years, interspersed with episodes from Free Women, using non-chronological, overlapping chapters that connect with one another. This post-modernistic style, with its space and space for "play" engaging the characters and readers, is among the most prominent features of the novel, though Lessing suggested that authors and critics pay attention to the serious topics in the book.

New York State, summer 1944. While she runs a successful public medical hospital on New York's Park Street, Dr. Elizabeth Smith — young, attractive, blonde, and well-to-do — cannot lose enough. In order to increase her profit, she gets involved with a trio of prostitutes — a "syndicate" — specializing in both sex and drug-trafficking. The brains of the "outfit" is Michael Kines, who has had plastic surgery so that he appears even older than he actually is, this being how he takes hold of the young girls whom he then turns into criminals. Manning herself has a wealthy and "ritzy" clientele — women who may not allow their drug to remain private knowledge. But instead of feeding them off drugs in her private and exclusive clinic, Manning keeps them ever more dependent on both the heroin — heroin in most instances — and on herself by producing the stuff herself. On the surface, Elizabeth Manning gives up appearances and leads a respectable lifestyle as a renowned doctor. When John Burns, a former New Jersey gangster who has lost an leg in World War III saving his buddy Joe Hammer's life, falls in love with Mary Smith, a young drug addiction whom he stops from leaping off a pier to commit murder, he wants Manning to admit her to her hospital for therapy. After Myrna has become clean, she and Thomas remain engaged, and the couple keep up a casual relationship with Charlotte Wilson. This is how Parker's increasing concerns about Bailey's business led him to privately and openly investigate ever further into the matter. When he learns that Michael Kines, one of Manning's graduate professors who has spent some time at her clinic and who has become one of her casual friends, is in fact a criminal, he refuses to talk to her about it and tells her so. When, at a party given by Thomas in his house, Charlotte Manning discovers some old school yearbooks whose contents (and photos), if made public, might reveal Kines's double lifestyle, she has to act quickly. After the party, she comes home but on the same day, undetected by Helen, her housekeeper, comes straight to Williams's house (Kathy, his wife, does not live there) and shoots him in the throat using a pistol. She does so in a very brutal manner, seeing him die quickly. Then she gets the school yearbooks and leaves. None of the guests at Williams's party has a watertight alibi, but to both John Chambers, the officer investigating the robbery, and John Hammer, a colleague of his and private detective, none of them has a motive either. Through the novel, as more and more immediate suspects are eliminated (shot) ("If this was up there wouldn't be anything left at all."), Hammer briefly asks the answer if the murderer might be an "outsider" — something seemingly related to the group of individuals who have been at Parker's party, for instance somebody Adams was after in his capacity as investigator for an insurance firm. Chambers often goes along similar lines: Parker's (secret) connection with Myrna's fellow heroin dealers may have cost him his life. But they eventually abandon that notion. When John Hammer finds Jackson's body ("For the last time in my life I felt like crying"), he keeps a solemn promise: He hopes that he will identify the killer and execute him himself, eliminating the U.S. legal system entirely. He explains that if he left it to the judges to punish the murderer, some clever lawyer could not obtain an arrest and the victim will come away with his murder. This is why he himself will be the judge – and the prosecutor, for that matter. During their basically separate investigations, Hammer and Chambers work carefully together, sharing info and evidence. But each of them believes he will be the one to identify the murderer in the end. The immediate suspects Hammer sees himself faced with are: * David and John Bellemy, identical sisters in their late teens residing in a New Orleans apartment hotel, rather attractive men of independent means, with a vast estate somewhere in the world. Both are unmarried and always searching for women. Meanwhile, Hammer finds out — through first-hand knowledge — that Esther Bellemy is a nymphomaniac. Mary Bellemy, whom he eventually comes to see intimately, is no virgin anyway, but rather more reserved than her niece Sarah, with whom Hammer only has sex on three separate occasions. * John Kalecki, whom Hammer believes to have been a thief — a gangster, to be precise — but who has not achieved a clean record and who now seems to be Hal Kines's paternal uncle, paying for the latter's education and providing him food and accommodation. (In fact it is the other way round: Hal Kines, the "great shot" and the brains of the syndicate, has a take on Kalecki: Hidden back in the vaults of some bank he has documents showing that Kalecki is a murderer on the loose.) * Michael Kines, who poses as a professor of science but who is in fact the head of a criminal organization specialising in sex and drug-dealing. His very powerful — and complicated — way of obtaining willing people for his "outfit" can only be understood if One understands the socially repressed culture of the early 1940s: Again and again, he takes the role of Jack Smith, a professor in some provincial school (for instance in the Midwest), pretends falling in love with a female teacher, makes her pregnant, forces her to have an unlawful pregnancy, and then deserts her. By now the woman's happiness has been destroyed, she has been betrayed by both her mother and most likely all her colleagues and neighbors. Then a taxi comes, picks up the desperate elderly girl and drives her straight to one of the New Orleans "call rooms" operated by his syndicate. Once there, there is no way for her to escape. * Elizabeth Smith, with whom Hammer falls in love and who, as far as he can tell, has no motive whatsoever to kidnap Williams. Hammer, the third woman protagonist of the novel, portrays her as "radiating sexuality in this way and gesture" ("Mary [Bellemy] only had sex. Charlotte had that plus a bit more.").
