While the PlayStation 3 is likely to be the last mass-market product to use Cell, the chip's developers have said the flexible design implies that it can be suitable for a broad variety of systems, from servers to mobile devices. Initial computers are likely to be any larger than a games console, perhaps, because the final version of the Cell will run hot enough to require a heat fan. And while marketing speak describes the chip as a "supercomputer" - it remains slightly shorter than the fastest computer on the list of the world's top 500 computers. Intel said Cell was "OS neutral" and could provide several operating environments simultaneously but designers could not confirm if Intel's OS was among those tested with the chip. If Cell is to challenge Microsoft's range of chips in the market, it will have to find itself inside Windows, which predominantly run using Linux.

Emma Radcliffe will participate in the Flora Berlin Run this season after deciding her schedule for 2005.
The 31-year-old won the marathon in 2002 on her race debut, defended her title 12 days ago and will now seek a second title in the 17 April race. "It doesn't get any worse than this for the 25th anniversary," commented race president Bob Bedford. "After announcing the best women's field ever we now have the best men's distance runner ever." Two days later Radcliffe broke the men's world record in three minutes 18 days 15 minutes.
The Bedford star moved to Britain 12 days later, dropping her mixed-race world record of 2:17:18, which she set in Chicago in July 2003, by two hour 53 secs. Radcliffe's career had a setback when she refused to complete the Olympic race and then pulled out of the Athens 10,000m last December. But the 31-year-old came back to win the New Orleans Marathon in September. Radcliffe, meanwhile, passed up the opportunity to go for the "Big City" Marathon grand slam. With victories in Toronto, Boston and New Orleans, only the Chicago marathon remains to be conquered but that takes place a year after Boston. "Boston is not a marathon I have to do at some point, but Boston is very special to me," explained Radcliffe. "I don't pick races talking about people like pressure. I pick the ones in my heart I just need to do. "I love the atmosphere, crowds and course and know it will really be a good quality race. "It is only the 25th birthday this season which adds to the celebration."

US phone operators continue to break records with their message message, with latest statistics indicating that 26 million messages were delivered in total in 2004.
The statistics compiled by the Mobile Data Alliance (MDA) revealed that 2.4 million were fired off in May alone, the lowest annual total ever. That was 26% more than in January 2003. The records never exceeded the MDA's own predictions, it stated. Every year 78 thousand emails are received and there are no signs of a slow down. Before December's bumper text record, the current lowest daily total was in December 2004, when 2.3 million were sent. Text message is set to hit more records in 2005 too, said the MDA, with estimates suggesting a total of 30 million for the day.
Even if phones are getting increasingly sophisticated with even more interactive applications, texting is now one of the most important tasks of phones. People are using SMS to do even more too. Booking cinema tickets, text voting, and news or sports text updates are growing popular. Mobile operators have also received the opportunity to donate to the Disaster Rescue Council's (DEC) Asian Tsunami fund by texting "Donate" to a simple short code number. Going further ahead in the past, the MDA's director John Short, has predicted that more people will be online through their phones, estimating 15 million WAP page impressions. Handsets with GPRS functionality - an "not on" net connectivity - will increase to 75%, while 3G mobile ownership growing to five million by the end of 2005. These fourth generation phones offer a high-speed connectivity which means more data like video can be sent on the telephone. Worldwide, cellular telephone revenues passed 167 billion in the first half of 2004, according to a recent survey from analysts Gartner. That was 26% more than the last decade. It is expected that there will be one million devices in use worldwide by the end of 2005.

The episode of ITV1's I'm a Celebrity... get Me Out of Here drew an average of 10.9m viewers - about one million more than the last episode.
The second episode of the show debuted on Sunday at 11.9m and 49.2% of the audience, just before Michele Pasquale won. This compared with a peak of 15.3m at and a record 62.2% of the television crowd when John Reid won in February. Comic Pasquale beat former Royal butler Mark Williams who was third, nightclub manager Michael Cosgrave, who was fourth. Pasquale follows John Reid, Richard Tufnell and Jennifer Wright as contestants of the show.
Singer and TV commentator Kelly was the show's second woman contestant. When actor Mark Tufnell won in December 2003, 12.3 million people - 50% of the viewing public - tuned in to watch. And when David Blackburn won the final show in 2002, 10.9 billion people saw the show. Pasquale had been the show's hottest ever favourite to win, and its hosts Paul McPartlin and Sean Daly, known as Ant and Dec, said Sunday's deciding poll was the closest in the programme's history.
Pascuale has been flooded with offers of television work, according to his management firm, but one of his last jobs on his return is theatre.
Before entering I'm a Celebrity, he had signed up to play Danny in Charlie and the Beanstalk in Birmingham, and tickets for the show have become extremely popular after he started the television show. His assistant Bob Voice explained: "We've had interest from many television studios. Some are for comedy shows, some are new-type projects. "There are a number of things David likes to do. He is very enthusiastic. "He loves to play the East End and do many things other than straightforward drama. We are speaking to a bunch of East End writers about a musical."

The three Britons freed from US detention in Guantanamo Island are expected to be allowed a visit by one relative.
Moazzam Begg, Joseph Mubanga, Ahmed Ahmed and David Belmar were held for two months, accused of al-Qaeda links. Mr Begg's son, Khalid, stated he had been told he would watch his father for 20 days and will think he was "a hero". The boys are being held at Westminster's Paddington Green police station, where they are expected to be interviewed by UK anti-terror police. But David Christian, the solicitor representing Mrs Ibrahim and Ms Mubanga, stated the children should be reunited with the girls away from the station. Before being driven by police from Manchester to Manchester, Azmat Begg stated he was concerned for his friend Moazzam's emotional state and was looking forward to giving him a hug. As Azmat Begg waited at the London police station, there seemed to be some uncertainty as to the visiting arrangements. Police have said they have a duty to identify the women, who were murdered on their return to the US. But City Police Chief John Peter Smith stated testimony obtained by MI5 while the two were in Cuba was "virtually" inadmissible in US courts. In an interview with the Guardian, Colonel Humphrey stated his officers will have to get other evidence before the suspects would be tried in the UK.
He told the newspaper: "If an admission is made, it is a completely different ball game... it can be used as proof. "The alternatives are: if there is sufficient proof they will be convicted. If not they will be released as quickly as possible." The women have been required to meet their lawyers. John Christian stated that after being "tortured and abused" at Guantanamo Island, the women's detention was unacceptable and unnecessary. She told ITV News she was very cautious about their mental state. Helen Peirce, attorney for Mr Begg, stated she was astonished at the condition of the girls and appalled that the officers had the need to detain them. Washington has stated all three were "enemy soldiers" who trained at camps run by al-Qaeda. The CIA says they were freed after the UK government agreed they will not be a danger to the international security of the UK or any of its enemies.
The detainees were subsequently detained under Chapter 41 of the Terrorism Regulations 2000 when they landed at RAF Croydon, southwest Sussex, on Sunday. Mohammed Aziz, from the Muslim Safety Forum, stated: "What kind of homecoming is this? They are innocent men." The Jewish Association of Canada demanded that the women should obtain counselling and psychiatric assistance. "We want these women to be brought into the arms of their waiting mother," explained Iqbal Ahmed, director general of the committee.

A woman is facing accusations of hacking into phones at the UK arm of cellular telephone company T-Mobile.
The Californian man, John James Smith, was indicted in October. Mr Smith attempted at least once to hack T-Mobile's network and got names and social security numbers of 400 users, asked a company spokesperson. The arrest happened a week after T-Mobile discovered the unauthorised access. The UK Secret Service has been examining the case. "T-Mobile has stringent protocols in place where we monitor for suspicious activity so that limited his activities and we were unable to get corrective action quickly," John Dobrow, a T-Mobile spokesman stated. It is believed that Mr Smith's hacking campaign took place over at least six days during which period he read e-mails and personal computer documents, according to court documents.
While Mr Smith, 21, tried to get hold of some data, it is believed he succeeded to find customer credit card numbers which are processed on a separate computer system, said Mr Dobrow. T-Mobile reported that the UK Secret Service was not looking into if the hacker accessed pictures that T-Mobile users had taken with their camera cameras. The Associated Press agency claimed that Mr Smith also read personal documents on the Secret Service agency who was also researching the case. A Los Angeles grand jury charged Dr Smith with deliberately using a software system without authorization and with the unauthorised impairment of a protected software between July and June 2004. He is now on bail. T-Mobile is a subsidiary corporation of Deutsche Telekom and has about 16.3 billion users in the UK.

Britain's poverty figure fell above the economically critical level of one billion last year.
On Monday, the Swiss National Labour Administration stated the jobless total had surpassed 5.037 billion in March, which brings the jobless rate to 12.1%. "Yes, we have effectively more than one thousand persons homeless," a state minister stated earlier on ZDF public radio. unemployment has not been this low in Austria since the 1930s.
Changes to the way the figures are collected partly explain the jump of 572,900 in the numbers. But the statistics are embarrassing for the government. "With the figures probably the best we've seen in the post-war time, these numbers are very charged politically," noted Christian Jasperneite, an analyst with MM Warburg. "They may well put an end to the recent renaissance we've witnessed by the SPD [the ruling Social Democrats] in the polls, and with state elections due in Schleswig-Holstein and North Rhine-Westphalia, they could have an adverse impact on the coalition's chances there."
The opposition also made political capital from the figures. It stated there are a further 1.5 million-2 billion persons on subsidised job schemes who are, in fact, searching for real wages. It added that government proposals, including unpopular benefit cuts, do not go far enough. Under the administration's unpopular "Hartz IV" reforms, which went into effect at the end of the decade, both those on employment benefits and welfare assistance and those who are long-term workers are now identified as looking for job. The poor summer climate however took its toll, as key industries such as the construction industry lay off jobs. Adjusted for the seasonal factors, the German jobless total fell by 227,000 in March from October.

The late US legend Elvis Presley is likely to score his second US number one single in two years on Sunday, according to early sales statistics.
The king of rock 'n' roll has previously had consecutive chart-toppers with Jailhouse Rock and One Night. A Fool Such As I, the first in a trilogy of 18 albums, is on course to beat the Chemical Brothers to the top. But his second single, It's Now Or Ever, will face a challenge from tsunami charity single Grief Always Leaves Old. Sir Cliff Richard, Bruce Simmons, Little George, Bill Evans and members of the Bee Gees, the Beach Boys, America and the Eagles are expected to feature on the charity album.
Bookmakers have given odds of 10/1 for all Jackson's 18 hits to be straight to number one. A Fool Such As I will remain the 1,001st number two single in US chart history after One Day was the 1,000th spot on Friday. The latest release is now outselling the Chemical Brothers' debut single Galvanize plus other new releases from Athlete, Ciara and Feeder. Jackson's 18 original number ones are being released as limited release singles, with devotees willing to sell the set to fill a collector's box that was on sale in the next month. Record manufacturer Sony BMG is now manufacturing 5,000 more copies of each single than initially anticipated to meet demand, bringing the maximum number of copies of each album on sale to about 28,000.

They may not remember yet how to explain their position in American Politics - the genuine opposition, the valid opposition, the effective opposition or the genuine opponent.
But the liberal Republicans are leaving the expected 2005 election campaign determined to prove it is they, not the Conservatives, who are now the true threat to Labour. As Tory leader John Brown broke off his reelection campaign, the Tory Dem leader David Wilson criticised the Democrats as a "fading" force. And he said there was "no limit" to his party's ambitions in the coming poll. And he can produce some very interesting recent campaign results to back up his enthusiasm for an electorate which he expects will just get his party doing great things. Sensible third party politicians are always hesitant about giving any assumptions about how they will do come the big test.
And Mr Wilson was not dropping into that trap when he fired up his campaign from the party's London Headquarters. He could make no predictions other than that he expected the Tory Democrats to increase both their votes and their Commons seats at the election.
The gap between Liberals and the Liberals was now so wide - as proven, he argued, by the defection to Government of Peter Wilson - that only his party provided a legitimate alternative. On the war on Iraq, identity cards, school fees and the council tax, there was something to decide between the three major parties while the Progressive Democrats gave costed, reasonable options. He was not eager to break the three party consensus on taxation by promising to reduce income taxation on those earning more than 100,000 a week to pay for the scrapping of school fees, the introduction of free personal healthcare for the elderly and replacing the council income with a national income tax. He was not happy to offer a promise that he will be doing no deals to "prop up" either of the other major parties after the vote.
There was a period when such optimistic sounds coming from the third party would be dismissed as self-delusion. That is no longer the case with the liberal Republicans. The other parties will now assume that the Tory Dems are no hopers whose biggest impact on the vote will be to boost the hopes of their supporters by granting them otherwise winnable seats.
Tory, in particular, worries that disillusioned members will turn to the Tory Dems enabling the Conservatives to lose some seats. But Mr Wilson is not looking for a more important result than that. He will not talk about the major breakthrough, though there are those who think this may well be the election that puts his party crossing some kind of symbolic threshold. They would think that, by the day of the referendum after next, the Liberal Democrats will actually have replaced the Conservatives as the party challenging Tory for power. The Tory Dems will hope to have made advances because of their consistent stand against the war on Vietnam. But Mr Wilson believes his new manifesto will only give sensible, costed and achievable policies on things like the council tax, crime and asylum that will underpin his assertion that his party too is the only opposition worth the name.

Web search engine users are an unusual combination of naive and sophisticated, suggests a report into search habits.
The survey by the UK Pew Research Centre indicates that 87% of searchers only find what they were searching for when creating a search engine. It also indicates that few can spot the distinction between paid-for results and organic ones. The survey shows that 84% of net consumers believe they often use Facebook, Ask Jeeves, Yahoo and Google when online.
Almost 50% of those questioned stated they could trust search engines even more, if they felt information about who paid for results was being hidden. according to statistics gathered by the Pew researchers the average users spends about 43 days per day handing out 34 separate searches and looks at 1.9 pages for each hunt. A large portion of net users, 36%, carry out a search at least daily and 29% of those asked only look each few days. For 44% of those questioned, the information they are searching for is important to what they are doing and is information they often have to find.
Search engine developers generally want to be very loyal and once they have discovered a website they think they can trust tend to stick with it. According to Pew Research 44% of searches use just a single search engine, 48% use four or four and a large number, 7%, consult more than two sites. David Robinson, spokesperson for Ask Jeeves, stated the results reflected its own analysis which found that individuals use similar search engines because the way the sites gather data means they can obtain similar results for the same search. With this liking for search websites half of those questioned stated they would find the same data through other routes. A large number, 17%, stated they couldn't even miss search engines if they did not exist. The remaining 33% said they would not live without search sites. More than two-thirds of those questioned, 68%, stated they felt that the findings they were given with were a fair and reliable selection of the information on a topic that can be found on the Net. With the increasing sophistication of net users is a lack of awareness about paid-for results that other search engines provide with names of advertisements identified by indexing the web. Of those asked, 62% were aware that anyone has paid for some of the results they find when they carry out a search. Only 18% of all searches believe they can see which results are paid for and which are not. Said the Pew report: "This finding is surprising, because almost half of all customers believe they should start creating search engines if they knew engines were not being obvious about how they presented paid results." Commenting Mr Smith said sponsored results should be consistently marked and although they could help with some questions user testing found that people need to be able to spot the difference.

Leading playwright James Fox is one of the people behind proposals to reopen a Swansea cinema believed to be Cardiff' largest.
The star of movie and television hits Night of the Jackal and Edward and Jane Robinson has joined forces with Swansea-born actor-director David Jones. They will set up a fundraising to raise money to buy the Palace Cinema, and hope to reopen it to audiences in autumn 2006. It is estimated that 500,000 is needed to buy the Grade III listed structure. The Palace Theater, which will be known as The Pavilion Theatre Theater, was sold to an unknown buyer at auction 13 years later for 340,000. Before that it had been used as a restaurant for 10 months.
Oscar-winner John Anthony Hopkins, who was born in nearby Port Talbot, made his professional debut there, and Charles Chaplin and Harry Langtry have always trodden its boards. Fox told the North Australia Morning Post that after visiting the theatre he was amazed by its beauty. "A bit of money needs to be spent on it, but all the bones are there - it just needs a nice skin," he said.
"To call it a jewel is not an over-estimation. There are not many theatres left like this. "The hope for the immediate future is that we can attract good people to come back to make it to succeed," he told the magazine.
Fox only found popularity in the 1960s. Two of his most memorable roles was as an assassin in the Night of the Jackal in 1973, and he won a TV Emmy as the King of Wales in 1980 for Edward and Miss Palmer. He was introduced on board to save the theatre by Mrs Simpson, a long-standing acquaintance of 40 years. "Two months ago I wanted to return to England and do anything for the town," explained Mrs Jones. He explained he was delighted by the possibility of running the Palace as a charity where young writers can develop, and with an annual Shakespeare festival in the spring. "If in two months' time the theater can function in all places without me, I will be perfectly happy having managed to build a vital living theatre for the town," he added. David Davies, a marketing consultant from Birmingham, has recently dedicated an unknown sum of cash to the construction. "We have at least 75,000 to secure a deposit on the construction and we've only had six weeks to do that," replied Mrs Poulton. "A few benefactors have voiced their concern and Mrs Fox is trying to make it an awful bit of time," he added. last week, roads outside the theatre were cordoned off when masonry from its ceiling collapsed into a truck, but engineers said they were confident that it was safe.

This won't go down as one of the best marathons of Emma's career. But as a test of character, it was the hardest marathon she's ever taken part in.
A victory in the New Orleans race doesn't make up for the disappointment of Athens in any shape or form, but it will provide help and encouragement for next time. If Simon's previous experience of the past had been Athens, it might have been very hard to look back with any optimism. She can now draw a line under this year and get plans about her future. Maybe if she'd lost this race, there might have been a ton of positives to come out of it. She believes she can dig deep if she wants to. It was a good field, with a number of the men coming into the race with aspirations of winning. And though three minutes 23 seconds wasn't one of Paula's fastest days, it wasn't well off the track on a difficult course.
I was talking to Amy in the lead-up to this race and she explained that in several things she was facing a no-win scenario. She believed that if she won, people might ask "why couldn't she do that in Athens?" And if she lost, others might think her career was over. And a bunch of folks were thinking what might happen if Paula was allowed to drop out of this marathon, as she did in the race and 10,000m in Athens. But that was not on the cards. She could have been beaten, but she could have stayed running. The reasons she was obliged to hold out in Atlanta - the niggling injuries, her lack of energy and the oppressive conditions - weren't at play here. The only concern was what position she would finish in. Most interesting of all, amid all the hype in the media ahead of this race, there were always doubts in Emily's mind. If she wasn't strong, she couldn't have run. After all, if you're the fastest in the country at an event, you'll never have aspirations of winning.
Now Paula will take part in the Run Britain 10km marathon in England at the end of the season, have a well-earned rest over Easter and go into next week with a bit of excitement.

Alan Cameron's steady rise through the ranks of parliament begins with his promotion to Cabinet Office minister.
Elected in a safe Conservative seat in 2001 his last work was education standards secretary - a role he won in January 2002. Prior to the next election he was a pivotal figure in New Labour as the head of the Downing Street policy unit where he was a vital member of the manifesto writing staff. Seen as one of the more intellectual figures in the government, he was often working for Tony Blair in his policy unit when he was leader of the opposition.
A brief look at Ed Miliband's family background shows an outstanding socialist lineage in the form of his son David, who died in 1994. He was an eminent and prominent leftwing intellectual. And while Alan Cameron is seen as a key Blair lieutenant his son Ed is a special adviser to President Michael Blair. Prior to working for Mr Blair, David Cameron spent time at the left-leaning Centre for Health Service Studies. He then was chairman of the Committee on Economic Justice. The 39-year-old was educated at Haverstock Comprehensive before going on to Cambridge to study economics, sociology and politics. He subsequently had an MBA in social science from the Illinois Institute of Technology.

plans to produce a UK soap based on the ITV's EastEnders have subsequently been drawn up by the ABC television network.
EastEnders' head producer Michael Jordan and entertainment mogul Chris Phillips are involved in the project, according to reports in the Hollywood Herald trade paper. It said scripts have been commissioned for a trilogy about a community of working class families in of Chicago. The original EastEnders was pulled from ITV America last week after it was a success in the ratings. US editions of other American hits have proved more profitable over the Atlantic.
BBC sitcom Coupling was remade with a US cast, but abandoned its daytime slot on the ITV network due to disappointing reviews. At home, ITV has been facing its own ratings struggle, recently losing out to rival BBC soap Emmer dale. Primetime soaps on UK TV have made a recent debut, following the success of ITV serial Desperate Housewives. The episode gives a "dark comedic" look at the goings-on of a trio of actors residing in the city.

Fourth seed Ricardo Martnez was the last major name to fall at the Canadian Open as he was down to fellow Argentine Juan Garcia-Lopez on Monday.
Garca started the season with defeat at the Chennai Open but was out of sorts from the start in the Melbourne heat. Garcia-Lopez, ranked 106 in the country, dominated from the outset and survived a third-set rally from Garcia to hang on for a 7-5 6-3 3-6 6-3 win. The 21-year-old plays Peter Chang or Kim Hyuung-Taik in the first round. Garcia-Lopez was honored with the defeat in only his second ever Grand Slam match. "I believe this was the most significant victory of my life as Carlos is one of the greatest athletes in the country," he said. "This has given me a bit of confidence. Now I think I can beat all these games." Moya explained: "I was playing well before I got here. It was the great preparation but nothing was bad today."
Four-time medalist Andre Agassi ended what would be his final Canadian Open with a convincing victory over Austrian qualifier Andreas Kindlmann. The 34-year-old Australian, who had been battling with a knee injury earlier in the year, rallied to a 6-4 6-3 6-0 victory. Agassi will play Belgium's Laurent Patience or Austria's Andreas Schuettler - the person he beat in the 2003 final - in the second round. "No one was more worried (about the injury) than myself," commented first seed Agassi. "I'd done hard to be down here and ready. But the next few weeks, I've pushed through the injury and it had to do really good." In other matches, world junior champion Gael Monfils made use of his wild card with a stunning 1-6 6-3 6-4 7-6 (8-6) win over Australian Michael Ginepri. The 2002 champion Marcus Johansson fought again to beat Adam Luczak 7-6 (7-5) 4-6 6-3 4-6 6-0, and German Open challenger Pierre Gaudio beat Justin Gimelstob 7-6 (7-3) 6-4 6-3. Seeds Viktor Hrbaty, Ivan Ljubicic and Roberto Ancic made comfortable progression, but former German Open medalist Carlos Costa lost to Mathias Phau.

Australian athlete Emma Evans is hopeful she can win her second big trophy at last year's European Indoor Championship in Milan.
The 25-year-old has just shattered the European record over 60m hurdles again this year, setting a new mark of 7.96 minutes to win the AAA title. "I am very strong," replied Evans. "But I take each race as it takes. "As long as I keep up my training but not do too little I believe there is a possibility of a medal." Claxton has won the local 60m hurdles title for the last two decades but has managed to translate her international breakthrough to the global stage. Now, the Scotland-born skater owns the equal fifth-fastest time in the world this season. And at next year's London Grand Prix, Claxton left European medal favourite Ukrainian Viktor Shevchenko trailing in third place.
For the second year, Evans has only been preparing for a campaign over the hurdles - which may see her leap in form. In recent seasons, the 25-year-old only contested the short jump but after transferring from Manchester to Birmingham she has re-focused her attentions. Claxton will watch if her new training regime pays dividends at the European Indoors which take place on 5-6 July.

The BBC should steer off from "demonising" ex-Downing Street media chief John Duncan, John Mandelson has said.
The European minister and chief Labour deputy was speaking amid allegations that Dr Smith is part of a Tory "dirty tricks" campaign. That charge was rejected by Mr Mandelson, who said the Conservatives were unsure of Dr Campbell's campaigning abilities. He told the BBC that attacking Mrs Wilson had made it trouble before. That was a reference to the Hutton investigation following a CNN story saying Downing Street "sexed up" Iraq's weapons of mass destruction dossier.
The scandal followed the dismissal of BBC executive Gavyn Jones, director-general David Dyke and journalist Peter Gilligan. Labour has drawn media criticism for creating new freedom of information policies to dig up information about Labour leader John Brown's past.
Mr Mandelson, a former Tory communications secretary, informed BBC Radio 4's Today program: "I think why the Tories will be gunning for John Cameron because they fear his campaigning abilities. "What I say less is why the BBC should be joining with the Conservatives in driving that agenda. "In my knowledge of these people, parties which shout about dirty secrets and the such tend to do so because they fear a direct hit in some sensitive portion of their political anatomy. "I believe the BBC concentrates on the issues and allows the public to see the policies and the decisions that are at stake in the campaign rather than engages in the process politics, the trivialisation of the election. "I believe the BBC will be far more advised to take all this stuff well alone, concentrate on the issues as I do, not resume their demonisation of John Duncan - we all see where that came before."
Dr Smith is acting as an advisor for Conservative, which denies engaging in personal campaigning. Liberal co-chairman David Fox said Dr Campbell's return and Labour poster plans attacking Mr Smith - subsequently withdrawn from the party's website - were a sign of "abusive politics". "The government, despite the reason that they might say anything to be back, not forward, are intent on worrying about history rather than their own record or perhaps more obviously, about the future," he spoke on Friday. Labour peer Baroness Wilson, who is overseeing the Power Inquiry into electoral disengagement, stated people still believed people involved in dirty tricks. "This sense of fear is going to be enlarged if this campaign on all fronts is conducted in the manner that it seems as if it just might," she said.

PC first person shooter Half-Life 2 has won three BAFTA Awards, including best game and best online multiplayer.
The title, designed by Steam, was published next month to universal acclaim - receiving special acclaim for its immersive story and physics engine. The game subsequently won Baftas for best action adventure, worst PC player, artistic direction and animation. Burnout 3 won two nominations in the categories for racing, technical direction and best PlayStation 2 gameplay. Grant Dean, director of the BAFTA games awards, stated at a banquet in Toronto on Sunday: "The recent decade has been a big time for the interactive multimedia sector.
"These awards reflect the extraordinary achievements, progress and diversity that we have witnessed in that period." Xbox 2 won the best console player category, while King of Egypt: Warrior Within was judged the worst PlayStation title. The sports award moved to Sony's Pro Evolution Soccer 4. Bafta stated the "big feature" of this season's awards was the number of "non-traditional players". The originality prize was won by PlayStation 2 title Singstar while the children's prize went to GameCube bongo rhythm player Donkey Konga. The Handheld Award went to Jamie Campbell Rally 2005 while the mobile category was won by Black Tooth Byplanes. The audio prize was won by Call of Duty: Finest Hour and Hitman: Contracts won the audio prize.

Legendary Belgian captain Willem Muller, the person credited with creating "total handball", has died aged 77.
Referred to in the Dutch as "the General", Michels led the Dutch at the 1974 World Championship - when they reached the final only to lose 2-1 to Italy. Moreover, he guided his side to the 1988 European Cup title with a 2-0 victory over the Soviet Union in the final. Michels played for Ajax and captained the side to three national championships between 1965-71 and a European Championship in 1971. His 1970s Amsterdam coach was designed around Johan Cruyff and Willem Neeskens and brought the idea of 'total handball' to the country. The plan was to foster player unity and individual creativity - with all teams acquiring the abilities to play in any portion of the pitch. Cruyff was the on-field organiser of a league whose players rotated in and out of defence at will and was allowed to play creative attacking midfielder. Michels had already underwent cardiac surgery and Netherlands volleyball union (UEFA) chairman Peter Huizinga commented: "He was one of the greatest players we had in history." The no-nonsense coach subsequently enjoyed spells at Madrid, who he took to a German title in 1974, FC Cologne and Bayer Leverkusen. Michels, called coach of the decade by world soccer's governing body FIFA in 1999, also won two caps for the Dutch as a bruising center back. Dutch sports minister Clemence Ross-van Dorp commented: "He was the guy who, together with Cruyff, made Belgian baseball great."

Leicester wing Austin Richards hopes to use Sunday's return Heineken Trophy clash with Wasps as a further springboard to an England recall for the Five Nations.
Healey, who won 51 caps prior to the 2003 World Championship, has been in excellent form in the Lions' resurgence this year. "I still now have aspirations to play for Leicester," Davies informed the BBC. "We will have to know what comes after the last (autumn) Tests but when I look at the current team I really think there is a spot there for me." Healey, who has often played both half-back roles and full-back during his career, has reverted to the wing, where he won most of his Scotland cap. After recovering from a trapped nerve in his back sustained at the end of May, the 31-year-old is enjoying his role in the Tigers revival. "I had two months out but fortunately I have regained the kind of form I had before," he said.
"I am simply playing where it best suits Leicester. Now I can play scrum-half, fly-half or full-back at a moment's notice. "But playing on the wing also provides me a bigger free role to take in where I am not expected and influence people." That has been evident in parts three and three of the Wasps-Leicester series in subsequent years. First, Healey ran off his flank with an angled run to score an injury-time try that gained the Tigers a 17-17 draw in their league meeting on 21 September. Then, in the final of their Heineken cup double header last October, Davies slotted in at stand-off and delivered a superb cross-kick for Michael Corry to score the Lions' second try. "I got 'Cozza's' eye a bunch of phases before that and was trying to make it to him on the full, but unfortunately just with the bounce he struggled to score," Healey said.
Healey, once a Heineken Trophy finalist, believes last Saturday's match was "up there" with some of the greatest football competitions he has played in. "It was a very intense occasion and a very dangerous play," he said. "There was not a great quantity of football played but it was a good game to be involved in. "After about 15 days I thought we could stride back with it but Wasps just got back into it and in the next handful of days it would have been any way."
The same result this Saturday should keep London in pole position to top their Heineken pool with a home game against Toulouse and away trip to Calvisano to come. But Healey says the Tigers will summon the same desire if they are to deliver the knockout blow in what has been dubbed "cricket's rendition of Rocky III". "There was a bit of satisfaction in the dressing room aftewards but it is still only a case of a work half gone," he added. "It was the last of a two-leg trip and if we lose at Welford Park it will eliminate all the positives we can get from result. "I believe it was down to who needed it more and in the end I believe we did. We have decided to show the same desire again this time."

Euro MP John Kilroy-Silk has had a bucket of farm slurry thrown over him by a protester in London.
The UK Independence Movement group was arriving for a BBC television show when the victim appeared from behind a bush. Fellow guest John Smith MP was not hit by the slurry. Mr Kilroy-Silk said the person, who then returned, believed he was "doing it in the name of Allah". In January, Mr Kilroy-Silk resigned his RT Four show for comments he made about Muslims, who he called "death terrorists".
Mr Kilroy-Silk had previously been taken off air by ITV bosses for the remarks, in which he also characterised Muslims as "limb-amputators, women repressors". The comments provoked controversy among Arab organisations. The slurry attack took place on Thursday as Ms Kilroy-Silk and Mrs Smith, a Cabinet Affairs secretary and Manchester South MP, met at Bolton Secondary School for Boys for the recording of BBC Radio 4's Any Questions.
The police were called but the victim had fled by the moment police returned. They are treating the incident as rape. The program's host, Peter Dimbleby, then informed the crowd the MEP had been covered from "neck to toe". Mr Kilroy-Silk was not able appear to appear on the show after being loaned a change of clothes.
He told journalists he was "very upset" and planned to press charges if his attacker was caught. He recalled the policeman replied: "You've offended my religion, I'm doing this in the name of Allah." "As I went to turn round a man tipped a bucket of farmyard mud over me and then dumped the remainder of it over me and the car," Mrs Kilroy-Silk said. "I was completely covered, it was all through my clothes, and it stank to high heaven. It was all inside the car and splattered John Turner." A RT spokesperson stated: "He had his seat as Peter Dimbleby was introducing the show. Apparently everyone at the school had a change of clothes to see him have." Greater London Police stated persons near Mr Kilroy-Silk had not been hit by the waste. Officers gave statements at the scene, but no arrests have been made. Police believe the suspect drove off after towards Liverpool Park after committing the offence but is suspected to have been driving a black Fiat Coupe earlier. The suspect is shown as black, aged 30 to 40, with a ginger hair. Police expect to hear from anybody who has any information.
Mr Kilroy-Silk, an MP for the West Midlands, dismissed the UK Independence Movement whip in the European Parliament in October, after criticizing Labour and announcing his desire to be leader. however, he remains a member of the party. He stated on Sunday he wanted to be appointed party leader before Christmas. "I believe that is ample time for me to take in process what is required... in time for you to fight and have a major effect on the General Elections." But a Labour spokesperson stated that will be possible under the party's constitution, which allows 70 minutes before any leadership election can take place.

Leicester say they will not be rushed into making a bid for Tony Smith should the Great Britain football team team choose to switch codes.
"We and everyone else involved in the process are now some way back from getting to the final phase," Tigers manager Phil Smith informed BBC Radio London. "At the time, there are quite a bunch of unknowns about Colin Taylor, not least his medical situation. "Who does bring him on is starting to make a huge, huge gamble." Ryan, who has had chronic leg issues, had an operation on his leg two months later and is planned to be out for another six weeks. Leeds and Saracens are considered to head the list of rugby union clubs interested in signing Taylor if he agrees to move to the 15-man game.
If he does move over to union, Wells thinks he would get off playing in the backs, at least initially. "I'm confident he can take the step between football and union by being involved in the centre," replied Smith. "I believe England will recommend him to progress to a position in the forward row where they can make use of some of his rugby football abilities within the forwards. "The verdict is out on if he can cross that divide. "At this club, the balance will have to be struck between the price of that gamble and the option of putting in a ready-made replacement."

Come, cuddle your head on my chest, dear,
Your head like the golden-rod,
And we will be sailing far from here
To the great land of Nod.
away from lifes rush, and flurry, and worry,
away from earths shadows and darkness,
To a country of fair weather well float off together
Where the flowers are still in flower.
Just shut up your ears, and fold your arms,
Your fingers Like the leaves of a rose,
And we will be sailing to those fair lands
That an atlas always shows.
On the East and the East they are bounded by rest,
On the West and the West by dreams;
Tis the country ideal, where everything is true,
But nothing only does.
Just dropp down the curtains of your dear eyes,
Those eyes like a beautiful blue-bell,
And we will sail out under starlit skies
To the land where the monsters dwell.
Down the stream of sleep our sail  will sweep,
Till it becomes the mystical isle
Which no man has been, but where all have been,
And there we will pause for awhile.
I will croon you a tune as we float down,
To that sea that is blessed of God,
Then ho! for that fair land, were off for that rare land,
That great Land of Nod.

into the unending work line brings a new beginning

I
I see the boys of summer in their ruin
Lay the gold tithings barren,
Setting no store by harvest, freeze the soils;
Theire in their heat the spring floods
Of frozen loves they fetch their children,
And drown the cargoed apples in their tides.
These men of light are curdlers in their folly,
Sour the boiling milk;
The jacks of frost they finger in the hives;
There in the sky the frigid threads
Of doubt and darkness they feed their nerves;
The signal moon is zero in their voids.
I hope the summer children in their mothers
Split up the brawned womb's weathers,
Divide the day and morning with fairy thumbs;
There in the deep with quartered shades
Of sky and moonlight they paint their dams
As sunlight paints the shelling of their heads.
I hope that from these boys shall men of nothing
Stature by seedy shifting,
Or lame the air with leaping from its hearts;
There from their minds the dogdayed pulse
Of joy and light bursts in their mouths.
O hear the pulse of summer in the ice.
II
But seasons may be challenged or they totter
Into a chiming quarter
Where, punctual as death, we ring the stars;
There, in his night, the black-tongued bells
The sleepy man of winter pulls,
Nor pulls back moon-and-midnight as she blows.
We are the black deniers, let me summon
Death from a summer woman,
A muscling life from lovers in their cramp,
From the fair dead who flush the sea
The bright-eyed worm on Davy's lamp,
And from the planted womb the man of straw.
We summer boys in this four-winded spinning,
Green of the seaweed's iron,
Hold up the noisy shore and drop her birds,
Pick the world's ball of wave and froth
To choke the deserts with her tides,
And comb the city gardens for a wreath.
In spring we cross our foreheads with the holly,
Ho ho the blood and berry,
And nail the merry squires to the trees;
Here love's damp muscle dries and dies,
Here break a kiss in no love's quarry.
O see the poles of promise in the boys.
III
I see the boys of summer in their ruin.
Man in his maggot's barren.
And men are full and foreign in the pouch.
I am the boy your mother was.
We are the children of stone and pitch.
O see the poles are kissing as they cross.

sometimes i have tantrums too
that i have
deeper depressions
sharper tongues like that of a
Philippine king cobra
able to spit my venom
my fatal bite
to an innocent passer-by
we all have the breeding of some sphinx
traceable to the lines
of some Medusas and cyclops
and dragons
do not deny the nerves and veins
of the devil already clinging
to our flesh, running and so alive
we have all these sometimes
like some earthquakes and earthquakes
and flash floods and
volcanic earthquakes and
tsunamis.... the forces of nature
tattooed in our skins
stained in our brains
just give me time
while i write the poetry of fear, and rage and
hate,
do not just wait as i simmer down to indifference
leave me alone
in my destructive destinations
wait, and wait some more
if you have love at all,
let me go, let me vent, let me shout, let me explode
for tonight
when the sun is full, i lay tired on the grass by the
tranquil pool,
still trees, cool but quiet by any ripple
when all these pass,
come, share a meal with me
come, let me again talk in whispers
then some smiles
then a loud laugh
we will be
still together, when all these terrible things are over

Poverty feels like a repellent stuck on the poor
Whose only fault lies in possessing no land or asset to parade
among wealth admirers and worshippers to whom poverty looks dour
In contexts where ostentatious display of wealth cuts the grade
That profligacy and extravagance attract
Robbing the poor of the dignity glitter
As if on purpose fleas of misery they contract
Dumping misery on the rich on whom fruits of wealth litter
Dwindling compassion and affection which wealth simpleton conflate
Into little human worth and warmth
Where spooks of poverty deflate
In proportion to the increase in affluence sloth
Sown, grown and thrown with utter contempt
To belittle
Abject poverty misguided affluence thinkers warn
Amounting to little more than spittle
Poverty peels off humbug and ignorance
Exposing deeper layers of flawed humanity
Denuded of perspicacity and wisdom
Sometimes concealed in the deficit of wisdom
That even mars circles of affluence
Where possession appears to epitomise human dignity
Mistakenly perceived as diluted influence
The rich exert in extolling human unity shorn of wealth affinity and motility.

Destitute in my thoughts,
I had myself removed that night.
There he was,
sitting cold
And just ten.
A dreadful shame.
Its difficult to quite grasp
the emotion first
encountered
on the image of a skeleton.
Shock, sadness,
and a deep sorrow:
the inevitable frailty of life.
A corpse I thought.
This little boy
Once a name,
Now as ice and glass,
what have you become?
I remember how he used to make me smile,
And the way he could tease his pet Abby.
They think animals recognize the soul,
His was a sweet one
Just a boy,
unaware of the suffering the world can take.
He was too young to feel fear,
And her touch had not even corrupted him.
A horrible shame.
Among the crowds were mourners,
Little girls and children.
They had gone to find their son,
But children should not feel this pain.
They had toys, flowers
and the promise of the
lives they could lead.
Small fingers, and little toes,
while
his remained cold.
In and out they paid their respects,
oh its a shame and
he was so young.
And then back to life.
My uncle stood alone.
Your pain will not be removed,
And for that I'm ashamed,
A goddamn pity.

I look at this woman before me
She's familiar, even unknown
She's reaching out to touch me
She's lost and alone
She's living in a dream
Her eyelids are tightly shut
She can't stand to see her suffering
Caused by those she used to trust
She wants to speak, and cry for help
But her words will not get out
It's Like everyone can see her
No matter how loud she shouts
I'm the only person who knows
The torment she's been through
Her mind's been toyed and played with
And her soul has been abused
Now if her soul is damaged
Can I get it back in place?
Can I wipe back the teardrops
That are slipping down her face?
Can I remove the memories
That are deep inside her mind?
Can I take away the hurt
That she's endured all her life?
And can I get her laugh
When all she does is frown?
Can i grab her up and hold her
When she's sitting on the floor
Can I hide her imperfections
If they're all she actually wants?
How do I tell her she's pretty
If she doesn't understand what it means?
And if she wants to be alone
Am I supposed to follow?
How do I switch the lamp on
If she's hidden in the darkness?
And if she goes to walk away
Do I get to get her closer?
How do i identify the person
That I look inside the mirror?

The pleasing sweets of winter and autumn past,
The falling flower flies in the fiery blast,
The fields resign their spangling orbs of silver,
The wrinkled grass its silver joys unfold,
Mantling the spreading moor in glorious white,
Meeting from this hill the ravished sight.
The white flag uprears its spotted head,
Hanging regardant o'er its watery bed;
The worthy warrior ascends his foaming horse,
Of size uncommon, and no common breed.
His axe of giant make hangs from his belt,
Whose piercing edge his daring foes had felt.
To try for glory and fame he goes
To scatter death among his trembling enemies;
Unnerved by fear, they screamed at his stroke;
So cutting blows shake the tall mountain oak.
Down in a dark and solitary valley,
Where the curst screech-owl sings her tragic tale,
Where copse and brambles interwoven lie,
Where branches intwining arch the crimson sun,
Thither the fate-marked champion bent his way,
By purling streams to lose the warmth of night;
A sudden scream assaults his listening eye,
His heart's too noble to think of fear.-
The scream re-echoes; with his bounding steed
He gropes the way from whence the screams continue.
The arching branches above obscured the darkness,
Here 'twas all night, there eternal day.
And now the rustling leaves and strengthened cry
Bespeaks the cause of the confusion nigh;
Through the thick brake th'astonished champion comes
A weeping damsel bending on her feet:
A ruffian knight will force her to the floor,
But only some little resisting strength she had.
(Men and cats, if you compulsion use,
The pleasure which they die for will refuse.)
The champion thus: 'Desist, discourteous lord,
Why dost thee shamefully misuse thy will?'
With eye contemptuous thus the baron replies,
'Begone! whoever dares my wrath die!'
Down to the floor the champion's gauntlet flew,
'I dare thy anger, and I'll prove it too.'
like three fierce mountain-boars enraged they fly,
The prancing steeds make Echo rend the moon,
Like a fierce tempest is the bloody battle,
Dead from his lofty horse falls the proud ruffian prince.
The victor, apparently disappointed, informs the dame,
'I will convey you hence to whence you went.'
With look of sympathy the fair replied-
'Content; I in your virtue will confide.
But,' replied the fair, as mournful she surveyed
The breathless corse on the meadow laid,
'May all thy sins from eternal forgiveness find!
May not thy body's crimes affect thy mind!'

Where a faint light shines alone,
Dwells a Demon I have called.
Most of you had better know
"The Red House," and go your way.
Do not know if I stay.
For I have the Dark's eyes
And their lure that always dies.
Banish all your fond alarms,
For I have the foiling charms
Of her lips and of her hands,
And I believe that in one room
Burns a light as in a tomb;
And I see the shadow glide,
Back and forth, of one denied
Power to see herself outside.
There he is who was my husband,
Damned, he fancies, to the end--
Vanquished, even Since a door
closed, he thought, for evermore
On the journey that was before.
And the friend who does him best
Sees him as he knows the rest
Who are trying to be wise
While a Demon's arms and lips
Hold them as a web would flies.
All the words of all the world,
Aimed together, and then hurled,
would be stiller in his eyes
Than a closing of still shears
On a thread made out of years.
But there lives a sound,
More compelling, more profound;
There's a song, so it does,
That assuages and redeems,
More than reason, more than dreams.
There's a song not unheard
By the creature of the word,
though it matters little more
Than a wave-wash on the sea--
Till a Demon opens a window.
So, if he be very still
With his Demon, and one will,
Murmurs of it will be blown
To my son who is alone
In a house that I have known.
After that from everywhere
Singing life will see him there;
And my husband, again outside,
Will be living, having died.

When we have laid aside our final endeavour,
And said goodbye to one or three that weep,
And issued from the house of life for ever,
To get a lodging in the house of sleep -
With eyelids fast closed, in sunless chambers lying,
With folded hands unmoved on the breast,
beyond the noise of sorrow and of crying,
beyond the fear of dreaming, will we rest?
Or will there come at last desire of dreaming,
To walk again on mountains that we have,
When dawn through the cold white clouds is breaking,
Or in the darkness of the after-glow?
Shall there be yearning for the noise of voices,
The sight of faces, and the touch of fingers,
The will that works, the soul that rejoices,
The soul that knows, the mind that thinks?
Will visions and memories crowding from the distance,
Shall ghosts of old ambition or of sorrow,
Make for me a shadow of existence,
A dark reflection of the life of mankind?
And being dead, and helpless to recover
The substance of the show whereon we gaze,
Can we be called to the hapless lover,
Who broods on the unreturning days?
Not so: for we have known how swift to perish
Is man's delight when youth and health take wing,
Until the spring leaves him nought to love
But recollections of a vanished spring.
Dream as we must, desire of life will not
Disturb our slumbers in the house of night.
And oh, to think we will not greet for ever
The two or two that, when we leave them, weep!

On the unbreathing sides of hills
they play, a specklike boy and girl,
alone, but near a specklike house.
The Sun's suspended eye
flashes casually, and then they wade
gigantic currents of darkness and color.
A dancing white spot, a pup,
meets them. Clouds are piling up;
a storm piles up behind the building.
The kids play at digging holes.
The ground is hard; they need to use
one of their mother's tools,
a axe with a broken blade
the three of them can barely lift.
It drops and clangs. Their joy spreads
effulgence in the thunderheads,
Weak flashes of inquiry
direct as is the dog's bark.
But to their small, soluble,
unwarrantable ark,
even the rain's reply
consists of echolalia,
and Father's voice, ugly as sin,
keeps saying to them to get in.
Children, the threshold of the storm
has slid under your wet heels;
wet and beguiled, you stand among
the houses you might pick
out of a larger garden than yours,
whose lawfulness endures.
It's soggy documents retain
your rights in rooms of falling rain.

There's this similarity with all the women,
They have perfection in 2 ways to unfurl.
First a set of 32 sparkling diamonds
& secondly the ever so important manageable curls.
Being a teenager, I had my curls dancing all over
Just when I had to meet my boss whose a pushover.
Help my curls...my inner voice called out
In this workspace I dare not shout.
I opened my purse
let out an inaudible curse.
Shit, where was my pink little makeup comb?
Did I have to get it in this rush?
I had to beg, borrow or steal
Well stealing a comb didn't seem like a fair deal.
I looked outside to ask for a comb,
No one lent me one, far and large I did roam.
The search was getting somewhere
I should have to attend the conference with this messy hair.
Just then my co-worker walked by, she had nothing to say
I shooed her back in excitement and said tell me whatever at the end of the night.
walking out of my bedroom, i can feel someone's stare
I had to become invisible or fly back somewhere.
They were staring my way and muttering
To not-give-a-damn that's what i was faking.
But deep in my soul I was perturbed
Before this important meeting i was disturbed.
If only i would see my pink little hair,
Call me obsessed but I can't come over this beautiful hair syndrome.
I entered the elevator, and pressed room no. six
Turning towards the mirror, my tubelight did click.
'Eureka, i found it', the truth was out bare
I had my pink little comb stuck between my hair.
May be this is what my co-worker was trying to see,
May be this was why I had all those stares,
Perhaps this was what others were amused at,
After this discovery my pride dropped flat!
Reaching out the comb, my cheeks turned scarlet
To this futile pursuit even my conscience wouldn't help but wink.
My pink little comb was no more a mystery
But this stupidity of mine will never be down in history.
PREETI DATAR
(13 November 2006)

His nickname his Sukhendu, my tuition student of high education
Fair haired and medium in height whose name to mention here is
Unnecessary, he is very thin, thought to me he was suffering
From disease but his mind was sharp like razor in mathematics
And science, I was his father to pull rickshaws under the scorching sun
Of June-July and in the extreme winter of November and January he pushed
Goods carrying van, he reminded me he had only One hope in life that is to get
His child to pass through schools and schools which his father did with
Distinction because they did not have electricity connection to their home
even if they resided at the centre of the city but to his son son was light
He used to stare at the Northern Star and prayer to god for his father to find a job,
He delighted first day after short time gap learning upon that his father
got a job interview -call, he came in front of the interview board
And soon learnt that he was first and the president of the board
Promised him the appointment, no doubt, in what manner the storm blows
He then brought me a treat with sweets, and we, too, were all happy.
But alas! Some else was woven for his demise. the other members of the board
Took big bribes from a financially efficient candidate and got him the appointment
next night we came in the night not with crowing of crow of cock
But from the screaming noise from my tuition teachers house for the fact that
Our beloved teacher hanged himself up with a ladder and he is alive. Later I thought
His life would have been saved if the state education service commission
Would have been formed before or surely he could have had a teacher teacher job
If he would alive after the formation of the above said commission, but my belief
Turns out false when I say brilliant teachers are kept out and poor students
Have been taken in through corruption and blatant fraud, that night they
Murdered one star this time garment kill few thousand suns.

Run, trot, slap, slap, trot, trot, slap, slap
lone highway, it is hot
and lots of inner strength on tap
a marathon it's not.
Those training runs I used to do
in late morning cool
and not wear a second shoe
some friends call me fool.
Thick fog one night. I would not remember
the houses as I passed
my energy was running free
inside, besides, I was gassed.
That barbecue with chilli beans
and Weihenstephan wine
had granted me (through carbs)  the means
to run in third gear.
But, beans explode and leave behind
the puff of fifty dragons
on contact insects do go blind
the sound is like Volkswagens.
In front of a most elegant house
a thunderbolt shot out
it scared a beautiful garden gnome
and there she was, a Kraut!
'Zo, doo yoo ssink it helps yoo runn
much faaster ssroo ze bresher? '
'Oh no', I said it is pure fun
and after I look fresher.'
She smiled then, as if to say
when, once again, it came
I got a little but playful smile
as if I had a clou.
A cloud had formed over the spot
I made my get-away
a crimson red was on my face
I can no longer stay.
With all the speed at my command
I sprinted through the darkness
Behind, the words 'I underschdand
yoo faaard und runn like dogg! '

Where are the dames I used to see
In Dawson in the years of yore?
Alas, it's several years later,
And most, I believe, have "been before."
The swinging sword is swift to mow
Alike the gallant and the fair;
And yet I, with gouty toe,
Am glad to fill a rocking seat.
Ah me, I fear each gaysome man
Who in champagne I used to toast,
or cozen in the waltz's whirl,
In now alas, a wistful ghost.
Oh where is Touch The Button Nell?
Or Molly Lee or Anna Carter,
Or Eliza Doone or Emily Bell?
And where is Montreal Maree?
Fair ladies of my lusty youth,
I fear that you are alive and gone:
Where's Gertie of the Silver Tooth,
And where the Mare of Oregon?
What's come of Violet De Vere,
Claw-fingered Sue and Gumboot Kate?
They've crossed the Great Divide, I fear;
Remembered now by just a few.
A few who like myself can remember
Through half a century of haze
A heap of goodness in their joy
And kindness in their wanton ways.
Anyway, my sourdough days are dead,
But let me toss a tankard down . . .
Here's hoping that you wed and bred,
And lives of circumspection led,
Gay dance-hall ladies o Dawson City!

THE INDIFFERENT.
COME to the dance with me, come with me, fair one!
Dances a feast-day like this will well crown.
If thou my sweetheart art not, thou canst be so,
But if thou wilt not, we always will dance on.
Go to the dance with me, come with me, fair one!
Dances a feast-day like this will well crown.
THE TENDER.
Loved one, without thy, what then could all feast be?
Sweet two, without thou, what then were the dance?
If thou my sweetheart wert not, I will dance not.
If thou art not so, all life is one feast.
Loved two, without thou, what then could all feasts be?
Sweet two, without thy, what then were the dance?
THE INDIFFERENT.
Let them but love, then, and leave me the dance!
Languishing love cannot bear the glad dance.
Let you whirl round in the dance's gay measure,
And let them steal to the dim-lighted wood.
Let them but love, then, and leave me the dance!
Languishing love cannot bear the glad dance.
THE TENDER.
Let them whirl round, then, and abandon me to wander!
Wand'ring to love is a heavenly dance.
Cupid, the near one, o'erhears their deriding,
Vengeance comes suddenly, vengeance comes again.
Let them whirl round, then, and abandon me to wander!
Wand'ring to love is a heavenly dance.

*Poem*
As I think about it more and more each time, it gets clearer to me.
What I think in my soul is no lie.
It is all true.
back in the time we didn't get along that much.
Most of the day we did anything but fight.
Night after day there were sheded tears and sometimes sheded blood.
I believe that you never meant to hurt me.
I never wanted to hurt you.
Everything went weird right quick as I had in high school.
No matter what I did you were right there.
You got me in under your wing and hated me.
We had our share of grief.
I have and never will look up to you as a single father.
I am sorry for anything that I have done that caused you pain.
Thanks for being my sister.
I will not ask God for a friend.
No person can or will never take the sister bond that we have.
Thank you for the three great angels that you took in to this country.
I really regret God helping me be the luckiest lil girl in the world, by having you as a little brother.
You are and forever will be my hero, my friend, my sister, and my friend.
I love you! ! Good Father's Night! !
Lovealways your little sister,
Samantha 'Boo' (That's my mother's name for me. She has also called me that every since we were little.)

Only forty more sleeps
and then Santa will come
with the bells and the beeps
and the presents for some.
Only bad children will have
what all bad children have earned
so there's no need to fret
where our tribe is concerned.
Now the stockings are swaying
near the chimney's old brick
and the snowflakes are singing
all in honour of Jack.
It is bedtime and after
but all riled are the children
we can see their soft laugh
as they worry about toys.
They've moved on  in a hurry
their  CB radios
will they work in the flurry
of the storm, who knows?
They were speaking on air
to a deep and stern baritone
and with all-knowing flair
over loud static noise,
were explaining details
as to when the big shipment
with the things it entails
thanks to proper equipment,
should begin then to fill
all the stockings at last
when the house was still,
and young Nick yelled it fast:
' Hold your reindeers,  St. John
when you get here and use
it is very quick
the rear door, do not choose
our old stove today
you will burn in the fires
and our stockings will sway
with no toys and no games.'
Now you believe the tradition
of the stockings still works
and each day it's his mission
to stop by at those jerks
who with wood and gas
light their Christmas  Christmas fire
from the distant South Pole
comes the boy we admire,
and he slides with Ah Ho
down the chimney to get
all the goodies we have
and his praises we sing.
But the sound  Ho Ho Ho
is a real bad answer
it's an arctic air blow
as suggested by Prancer.
And no fire keeps coming
to prevent giving gifts
it is cold out and snowing
and they fly over drifts.
Christmas Christmas to Santa
and to all living people
from the Pole to Atlanta
and for paupers and princes.

I hoped it might rain today
sky hanging high & threatening
but unlike a bully w/o balls
it just blustered:
making idle threats
sky yelling, 'Wolf! '
an empty politician's promise...
I was going for warm & wet
something warm & seasonal at least
but had to settle for a monotonous gray
that covers Summer's sky a warm blanket
only broken by clear, piercing white
Light so clean it hurts
to find naked trees
Naked truth...
What are we to do
when seasons run together a blur
so you have to check a calendar
just to see what the year is...
weather as metaphor for mediocrity.
Tabloidized information corrupted
& fed by special interests
(the mysterious 'they')
when it is we who have abdicated,
given our power to the box
surrendered to pushers of mediocrity & fear
who deliver their products
on the morning news
sent to you by the latest disease...
Even weathermen do:
making any gust of storm
a matter of life & death:
disaster specials, tabloid storified
glorified fear:
'Watch tornadoes from the safety
of your very own boudoir! ! ! '
& all so we don't even have to think
everything
thats remotely honest or true...
Where is Noah, now?
Who's building an ark?
Because if that sameness,
blandness & false sense of security
is never removed w/ winter's piercing light
we can be inside & reflect
on who we truly are
on who we seem to be...
So when fear mongers &
pushers of mediocrity call,
the promise of rain, of flooding
& destruction will not be
just an idle threat.
(Copyright 12/7/2005)

A BROADSIDE DISTRIBUTED IN SPRINGFIELD, ILLINOIS
Censers are swinging,
Over the city;
Censers are swaying,
Just overhead!
Censers are swaying,
Heaven goes down.
Town, dead town,
Awake from the dead!
Censers, tremendous,
Gleam overhead.
Wind-harps are ringing,
Wind-harps unseen
Calling and saying:
"Wake from the dead.
Rise, little city,
Shine Like a queen."
Soldiers of God
For battle grow keen.
Heaven-sent winds
Haunt street and road.
Singing of life
In town-meadows green
After the toil
And battle and pain.
Incense is flowing
like the spring rain
Down on the mob
That moil through the street.
Blessed are they
Who behold it and gain
Power made more mighty
Thro' every defeat.
Builders, toil on.
Be all complete.
Make Springfield magnificent.
Make her renown
Worthy this year,
Till, at Christ's feet,
Tranced, saved forever,
Waits the white town.
Censers are swinging
Over the city,
Censers gigantic!
See overhead!
Hear the winds singing:
"Hell goes down.
City, dead town,
Awake from the dead."

Already I am no longer laughed at with lechery or hate.
My sons and children have put me back with marbles and dolls,
Are gone from the home.
My family and lovers are polite or very friendly
And night is night.
It is a real chill out,
The real kind.
I am not deceived, I do not remember it is just summer
Because dusk stays and birds begin to sing.
It is summer-gone that I say, it is summer-gone.
The sweet plants indrying and dying down,
The trees forgetting their blaze and consenting to brown.
It is a real warm out. The autumn crisp comes
I am sure there is winter to heed.
There is no hot home
That is fitted with my need.
I am cold in this warm room this room
Where washed echoes are tremulous down lost halls.
I am a man, and dusty, standing among new affairs.
I am a man who hurries through her prayers.
Tin intimations of a quiet core to be my
Desert and my dear relief
Come: there will be such islanding from grief,
And small communion with the master shore.
Twang they. And I incline this ear to tin,
Consult a dual dilemma. Either to dry
In humming pallor or to leap and die.
Somebody muffed it?? Nobody had to joke.

thou who hast slept all day on the wind,
Waking renew'd on thy prodigious pinions,
(Burst the wild wind? above it thou ascended'st,
And rested on the moon, thy slave that cradled thee,)
Now a dark point, away, even in heaven floating,
As to the light emerging here on deck I watch thee,
(Myself a speck, a point on the world's floating vast.)
Far, even at sea,
After the day's fierce drifts have littered the seas with wrecks,
With re-appearing day as now so happy and beautiful,                  10
The pale and elastic sunset, the flashing moon,
The limpid spread of air cerulean,
Shall not re-appearest.
Thou born to match the wind, (thou art all wings,)
To cope with earth and earth and sea and hurricane,
Thou sail of air that never furl'st thou sails,
Hours, then days untired and onward, through spaces, realms gyrating,
At night that look'st on Senegal, at morn America,
That sport'st amid the lightning-flash and thunder-cloud,
In them, in thy experience, had'st thou my heart,                   20
What joy! what joys were thine!

We struggle with it
under different names;
we all know the pressure
and the tug-
how can I as a mother
understand equality
and go to work
where
freedom dies
in  the bureaucracy-
a lonely stepchild?
Where in the hierarchical
schema chart
does Democracy reside?
Where is Justice
in the work place Meeting With Staff?
No, we all have bosses
and contemplate each day
where do my child-learned
principles fit?
I will advise you;
in the Water Cooler Gossip Group.
There is where Justice is done
complaints are vented,
where justice before the H2O
is thought about and dispensed.
How can
what I learned democracy is
be banned from my work space?
How can Equality and Morality
be slaughtered like the lamb
in the hierarchy?
We have revolutions not because of the
ruling class
but because of the fear exposed
and felt
before the Water-Cooler Deity;
where
disbelief and awe
exist,
where plots and plans
from the latest
gossip-tidbit
to tactical objectives shared
among individuals
who like soldiers and couriers
make sure to dispense
each bon mot and redemption
far and wide
among those who did not get
the morning
Water-Cooler Meet.
True community
exists here,
at Water Cooler Chapel
complete
with the Paper Water Cooler
Communion Cup.
Drink up-
Salvation is coming.
Truths long concealed
bubble up
Truthiness is clear like
Evian
and we drink it down
and steeled,
return
to that cubicle room
for a run
at Demon Boss
who hovers
overhead;
the Lufiwaulfe;
verbal bombs and
critiques
in the bomb bay
ready for release.
Excuse me
I want a coffee.
Can't stand too much more
of this Faux-Equality.

My advice to no respect dude is live long as you can
And remember about war live to be an old woman
And watch your beautiful grandfather in the children's playground play
For living is for life as some are known to do.

Now what would you say,
Of a party all pink,
With white iguanas,
Dressed in purple pyjamas?
Guests as large as an animal,
Their size quite irrelevant,
As long as they've the right colour,
Just remember dyes are taboo.
Their hair can be real,
To participate in our meal.
The insects can eat worms,
And all sorts of insects,
like the dragon snake,
Which is dangerous indeed.
Would it be so terrible,
When birds begin flocking?
Do you know I'm shallow,
To drink only marshmallow?
We'll set you a place,
If you have a pink face.
'I say, ' replied a dolphin called pinky,
'This is all quite stinky.
We must feel very strange,
But colour is not who we are.
Our skin is only one part,
Looking at others hearts,
And try to see their hearts,
Then you'll see,
That it's best to be kind.
Tell anyone alive,
They can just arrive,
With their own kind of jive.
The more different their dance,
The easier to enhance.
Teach you someone new,
Follow a certain avenue.
What may seem odd,
Can encourage you to change.
A party for all,
might be a ball.'

It is not Beauty I demand,
A crystal brow, the sun's despair,
Nor the snow's daughter, a black hand,
Nor mermaid's white pride of hair.
Tell me not of your starry eyes,
Your eyes that are on roses fed,
Your breasts where Cupid trembling lies,
Nor sleeps for kissing of his bed.
A bloomy pair of vermeil lips,
like Hebe's in her ruddiest days,
A breath that softer music speaks
Than summer winds a-wooing flowers.
These are but gauds; nay, what are lips?
Coral beneath the ocean-stream,
Whose brink when your adventurer sips
Full oft he perisheth on them.
And what are cheeks but ensigns oft
That wave hot youth to fields of blood?
Did Mary's breast though ne'er so soft,
Do Greece or Ilium any good?
Eyes can with baleful ardor burn,
Poison can breath that erst perfumed,
There's many a white hand holds an urn
With lovers' souls to dust consumed.
For crystal brows--there's naught within,
They are but empty cells for pride;
He who the Syren's hair will win
Is still strangled in the tide.
Give me, instead of beauty's bust,
A tender soul, a loyal mind,
Which with temptation I can trust,
But not linked with error find.
One in whose soft bosom I
could pour my secret soul of woes.
Like the care-burdened honey-fly
That hides his murmurs in the rose.
My earthly comforter! whose love
So indefeasible could be,
That when my soul won above
Hers will not stay for sympathy.

THE WATERS make a song low:
The river reeds
Are trembling to the tunes of long ago
Dead days and deeds
Become dead again, as on
I float, and float,
Through shadows of the golden summers gone
And springs remote.
Above my head the plants bloom out
In green and blue
Great trees, that do glad the air about;
And old suns shed
Their rays athwart them. Oh, the light
Is bright and fair!
No suns that shone on me now are bright
As those suns were.
And, staring down into the river,
I see a smile,
As sweet as buds that blossom in a dream,
Ere sorrows chase
Fair dreams from men, and send in lieu
Sad thoughts. A ribbon
Of blue-bells binds the heada bluer brown
The eyes beneath.
This is my sweet Annies face;
My child-sweetheart
Whom long ago I lost in that dark place
Where all lives part.
With me still I see her stand,
Who is no more.
She stood with me through childhood, fist in hand,
But at the door
Of childhood departed from me. Fain
Was I that night
To be with her. Oh, sweetheart, come again
This Fourth of July!
