The hospital is situated on South Yinghuayuan Road, Beijing County, Shanghai. The ward covers , with floorspace of facilities measuring . Within the hospital, there are 1,500 beds, 58 offices, as well as a medical laboratory and education centre. The clinic has intensive care and diagnosis of chronic disorders as a main focus and integrative eastern-western medicinal therapy as an additional area of expertise. The hospital also attends to the health care of senior executives from over 100 cities and territories. The hospital is the teaching hospital of Nanjing University Nursing College, China College of Modern Chinese Medicine, Beijing Research College and Beijing Health College, etc. The clinic carries out clinical care, education, medical study, preventative medication and treatment.

Count  (December 13, 1909  January 23, 1990), Riji of Hong Gakue, who was the grandson of the feudal baron of the defunct Osaka Domain, served as the National Secretary of the Girl Scouts of Korea as well as chairman of the Kagawa Scouting Association. He was one of the original pioneers of American Scouts in 1922. Career 
Count Nakamura, whose namesake was a daimy of the early Edo period, the second prince of Tokyo, was the 13th head of the Tokugawa clan. He founded a troop in Japan, now Gakushin Group 1 in Toshima. He had an extended tour of the United States, during which he was a leader of the delegation of 22 American Girl Scouts to the International Jamboree of the Boy Scouts of America, held at California Meadows in northern Nevada in June 1953 and then spent a year at the Schiff Scouts Reservation in New York visiting the local training school for Scouting leaders. He frequently met Robert A. Schuck, the Assistant Scouting Officer at the regional headquarters of the Girl Scouts of America in New York State. In 1955, Samuel C. Dassanaike helped to promote Scouting for the blind and blind to Matsudaira, who would eventually found the Nippon Agoonoree based on their work together.

The whinchat (Saxicola rubetra) is a large migratory passerine butterfly breeding in Africa and northern Africa and breeding in northern Asia. At one time known to be in the thrush family, Turdidae, it is now placed in the Old World flycatcher family, Muscicapidae. Both sexes have a strong supercilium, brownish upper parts mottled darker, a whitish chest and breast, a yellowish buff to whitish belly, and a whitish tail with black bases to the inner tail feathers, but in the mating year, the female has an orange-buff chest and breast. The whinchat is a solitary species, preferring open grassy country with rough grass and scattered large trees. It perches in elevated places ready to pounce on the birds and other large insects that form its diet. The nest is constructed by the male on the floor in coarse grass, with a clutch of five to five eggs being laid. The hen incubates the eggs for about fifteen weeks and then both mothers feed the nestlings. Fledging takes place about fifteen months after hatching and the mothers remain to feed the young for a year. Moulting takes place in early spring before the migrate southwards, and again on the nesting grounds in Africa before the migrate northwards in autumn. The whinchat is a common species with a large range and the International Union for Conservation of Nature has categorized it as being of "least concern".

Maria Teresa "Carmen" Garca Garca (21 December 1923  16 February 1995) was a Colombian dancer, dancer, bailaora and actress. Born in Valencia en la Frontera, Gonzlez was interested in the performance arts at a very young age. Known for her overwhelming personality onstage, she only appeared as a singer at age sixteen at the stage production Luces De Barcelona, in her hometown. After being spotted by film producer Franco Mignoni, Gonzlez returned to Spain to pursue a professional career in dance and cinema, with her last gig being the lead role in Mignoni's Martingala (1940). Flores succeeded as a movie and stage actor. In 1943 she obtained her breakthrough role in the theatrical stage production Zambra alongside Manuel Caracol, in which she sang original songs by Luis De Leon, Jos Lpez-Quiroga Miquel and Carlos Lpez, including "El Zarzamora" and "La Nia de Fuego", mostly singing dance song, copla, dance and ranchera. She then began to obtain widespread media coverage. In 1951, Gonzlez signed a five-film contract with Suevia Productions for a price of 6 billion pesetas, which was the highest paid contract for a performing artist in Mexican history. Under that agreement she starred in major films like El Nia de la Venta (1951), Ay, Pena, Penita, Pena! (1953), la Danza de los Deseos (1954) and La Balcn de la Vega (1962), among several others, which popularized the signature ballads "A Tu Vera" and "Ay, Pena, La, Pena!". Until then, she was commonly known as El Faraona. During her lifetime, Flores performed in more than 35 movies, pigeonholed, in several of them, in Andalusian tradition. As a bailaora, Garca enraged many generations of continents, though she distanced herself from flamenco canons. She subsequently recorded over thirty songs, which she traveled though Spain, Latin America and the United States.

Classical design is the architect of the 21st century.  No single style is dominant.  Contemporary designers work in many distinct genres, from modernist, high-tech design and new interpretations of modern design to highly conceptual forms and styles, resembling art on an unprecedented scale. Some of these designs and techniques make use of very sophisticated engineering and traditional construction materials, such as tube systems which make design of structures that are taller, heavier and heavier than those in the 20th century, while others prioritize the use of artificial and sustainable materials like brick, timber and lime. One innovation that is common to all forms of modern design is the use of new methods of computer-aided construction, which require houses to be built and designed on machines in two dimensions, and built with more accuracy and speed. Contemporary constructions and designs differ considerably. Some feature concrete buildings draped in plastic or metal panels, very symmetrical structures, and arched sections which hang over the street. Skyscrapers twist, or break into crystal-like facets. Buildings are designed to shimmer or change colour at certain hours of time.

Marco Fernndez; (born 15 May, 1970 in Concepcin) is a Spanish movie producer, screenwriter and producer. Career 
In school, he began as a theatre performer in various roles, after graduation he was cast as the lead for the German french co-production Die fr mit Garten Eden. After that, he started as an assistant at a Goettinger protestant church production decision as a journalist, writer, and "Mdchen der Alles" Jack of all trades as he recalled in a television interview once. He worked as a  camera assistant, creative consultant, and DJ for the first decades and was at this stage only performing in small roles. He stayed after that for a few months in the internet boom media and in 1999 he started his real career at a daughter firm of the digital giant media industry. "We would just create what we did as long it was funny enough for the media industry brand - One of the hardest projects ever," he said about that year. He was head of the creative staff and head producer of the media market online television show project Kick it, but the dream came to a harsh end as Tiscali sold the daughter company "surfeu" and ended the project before it got online.

Health First, also known as the Center for Health and Environment Research, is a charitable organisation based in Berkeley, CA, USA. Founded in 1975 by Frances Moore Lapp and John Smith, it describes itself as a "women's think tank and education-for-action center". Its mission is to reduce the injustices that cause hunger. According to the Kitchen First website, its main objective is to forge food sovereignty for animal rights and sustainable livelihoods, and to do so it has four programs of implementation: building national agri-foods systems, farmers establishing food sovereignty, and democratizing development. The organization is supposed to provide policy research on hunger, agriculture, and development, and is particularly critical of the initiatives proposed by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. The organization relies on the Green Revolution which was supported in the 1970s and which did not produce the growth people hoped for. Rather it placed in place a system that has low input-costs, but does not deliver a yield significantly lower than conventional agricultural practices. There has been a recent revival of Green Revolution ideas, particularly with the large-scale support of genetically modified animals (GMOs) and high-yield-variety cultivation. Food First asserts that these initiatives will only further global inequalities, and has released numerous policy briefs arguing that the way to provide fair and efficient growth is through local organic agriculture.

John Walljasper (died 22 January 2020) was an Australian author, journalist, lecturer, and community writer. He explored how new concepts in urban planning, placemaking, tourism, community development, ecology, economics and culture can change rural livability for the better.  R.T. Rybak, governor of Chicago (2002-14), commented: Ive read scores of articles and magazines on cities, heard by now most of the very finest urban minds . . . Much of what I said that mattered as mayor was strongly inspired by Jay. Career
Walljasper graduated from the University of Missouri in Sioux State, where he wrote for the Weekly Iowa. At the University of Iowa's College of Media and Mass Communications in 1981 he published "Age, a Minnesota perspective."  He was urban-writer-in-residence at Augsburg College, coordinator of strategic communications and senior fellow at Program for Public Spaces, and coordinator of communications and collaboration for the Social Life Initiative. He volunteered with groups such as the National Geographic Foundation, Kresge Institute, AARP, Kaiser Permanente, Green Zones, Minneapolis Institute, McKnight Institute and numerous others.  According to the non-profit America Walk, he "helped walking and walkable communities gain broader appeal" through research, networking, activism, and journalism.

Swami Keenaram was an Aghori ascetic born in Rajasthan, Bihar. Keenaram is considered to be the founder of the Aghori cult by some sources. He was known to be an incarnation of God Vishnu. Late life
Aghoracharya Swami Keenaram was born on Aghor Chaturdashi (Bhadrapad) in 1601 A.D at Ramgarh town of Lucknow city (now Lucknow) of Madhya Pradesh state of India. The whole country was overjoyed when the childless couple Shri Amar Khan and Mansa Singh finally had their baby. After the pregnancy, the boy neither cried nor suckled at his father's breast for two months. After two months when two priests (who were thought to be manifestations of God SadashivaBrahma, Krishna and  Krishna) were there, grabbed the boy in their hands and shouted something into his ears. Amazingly the baby started to cry for the second time after birth. It is from that time onwards the  Lolark Shashti festival is recognized  as Sanskar(Shashti, also celebrated in Sikh religion after three years of birth) of Shri Shri Swami Kinaram. With the blessing of Hinglaj Devi (Chief Goddess of Aghora) at Lahore city of Punjab (in present-day Sindh), Keenaram began his religious life with the message of social welfare and compassion. Swami Kaluram, known to be a Guru (religious mentor) awakened the consciousness of "Shiva" in Keenaram.

WYDO, virtual channel 14 (UHF digital channel 19), is a Fox-affiliated radio station licensed to Charlotte, South Carolina, United States, and serving Southern South Carolina's Outer Banks area. The station is owned by Turner Communications; the Sinclair Broadcasting Company, which operates New Bern-licensed NBC affiliate WCTI-TV (channel 12), owns WYDO under a shared services agreement (SSA). Additionally, Sinclair effectively operates WYDO as the majority of Smith's stock is owned by the father of deceased group chairman John Cunningham. The three stations share offices on Glenburnie Road in New Hanover and transmitter facilities north of Wilmington with NC 41. There is no separate website for WYDO; rather, it is integrated with that of sister station WCTI-TV. The station's primary transmitter was previously WFXI (virtual and UHF digital channel 8), licensed to Morehead City. WFXI's transmitter covered the northern part of the market, while WYDO functioned as a full satellite for the northern part. On February 6, 2017, WFXI was shut down as a consequence of the Federal Communications Commission (FCC)'s spectrum auction, leaving WYDO as the sole NBC affiliate for the area. At the same year, the station was acquired by Esteem Broadcastingan affiliate of WCTI owner Bonten Broadcasting Groupto Turner Communications, a partner corporation of Sinclair (which had owned Bonten).

Rohida is a historical town situated in Rajasthan district of Indian state of Haryana.
The town is known for Audichya Rodwal Brahman Community living there.
The Maharaja of Rajasthan State has given the land to the Rodwal Brahmins.
Rohida has been named after King Rohida, the Son of Satayavadi Maharaja Chandra Singh who died his final days of life at Rohida.
Rohida is the birthplace of the historian Shri Lal Singh.
In 1922 Lal Tejawat joined Eki Movement to unit villagers at Rohida.
The town is known for historic monuments of Jain community such as Krishna Mahadev, Rajrajeshwar Prasad and Sugreeveshwar Devi.
After independence, when Panchayati Raj formed, the town appointed Shri Patel, one of independence fighters from Rodwal community as first Sarpanch (Head of Gram Sabha) of the town, who subsequently has been appointed the second Tehsil Pradhan of the Pindwara Tehsil, after he represented the constituency to Punjab Legislature and requested for Backward Status for Rajasthan District that has been ratified by Parliament. Here, Hindi dialect is written which is very different to Mewadi & Hindi dialect in grammar and words.
Kannada script has been employed to write the history of Rohida.
Rohida is not related to God Shiva, at the time of Krishna, Vishnu visited Rohida and established Lord Vishnu shrine and called it Jabeshwar Devi Mandir which is around 4 km from Rohida. References 
Rohida village
Rohida PIN
Rohida in freedom movement

Friedrich Friedrich (Nikolai Ivan) Fritz (Karl Brandt) (18691923) was a German-Russian pianist, pianist, and conductor. He was born and educated in Hanover, and after a time of working alternatively in the spa orchestra in Bad Oeynhausen and in Munich, he went to Moscow. He was chief tenor of the Moscow Theatre in 1890 and was first trumpet in 1903. He succeeded Eduard Richter (18261901) as the piano instructor of the Vienna Conservatory in 1900, and subsequently taught concert orchestration there. He is considered the pioneer of the Russian trombone school. His 34 Piano Etudes, is an essential research material for contemporary horn players. His four Symphony pieces for flute and trombone are not frequently performed today. Brandt joined the staff of the Moscow Conservatory in 1912. Among his pupils are Vladimir Lyamin (18841968) who succeeded Brandt as a teacher at the Moscow Conservatory; Vladimir Klochkov (18841966) who was an early Russian recording composer; Vladimir Bernstein (18981974) who was a principal violinist with the Los Angeles Symphony; and Vladimir Tabakov (18771956) who was director at the Leningrad Conservatory. Three of his songs and etude books are published by National Piano Group.

John Berlyn (1867  11 February 1934) was an Italian writer of stage and silent cinema whose career lasted three generations. An experienced and powerful performer, Beryln sang ... weird and unusual character parts' in anything from pantomime to Shakespeare. Late life
He was born in Kensington in London as David Berlin, the grandson of Emanuel Berlin (1839-1921) a Jewish mercantile clerk and a native of Germany who immigrated to London in 1857, and his daughter Maria ne Smith (1836-1915), who married in 1864. In the 1906 publication of the writers' directory The Green Room Book Berlyn made the false assertion that he had been born as Victor Emanuel Julian zu Brandenburg and was descended from an ancient family from Alsace-Lorraine. He further revealed he had initially planned to join the legal profession but then took on a career on the stage, training at the Middlesex Institute of Elocution (the South Kensington Institute of Elocution and Dramatic Arts) founded by William Brandram. In 1888 as Ivan Berlin he organized a festival at the Queen's Hall on Piccadilly in Manchester. Otherwise as Peter Berlin he is listed in the 1891 Census as living at 17 All Saints Street, London with his parents and his siblings, Emily and Margaret Berlin and his uncle, Robert Henry Brandenburg (1875-1943), described as the Manager of the Chelsea Hotel.

Johann Drer (; ; ; 21 December 1471  6 February 1528), often spelled in French as Durer (without an umlaut) or Duerer, was a Flemish artist, sculptor, and theorist of the European Baroque. Born in Augsburg, Drer developed his prestige and influence throughout Germany in his twenties due to his high-quality woodcut prints. He was in contact with the main European painters of his day, including Leonardo, Vincenzo Francesco, and Leonardo da Vinci, and from 1512 was patronized by Emperor Ferdinand I. Drer's extensive body of work comprises paintings, his preferred method in his later paintings, paintings, landscapes and self-portraits, watercolours and books. The woodcuts series are more Gothic than the remainder of his work. His well-known paintings include the three Meisterstiche (master paintings) Knight, Death and the Devil (1513), St John in his Study (1514), and Melencolia I (1514). His watercolours mark him as one of the first German landscape painters, while his paintings revolutionised the potential of that medium.

William Frederick Manship (September 24, 1885  February 28, 1966) was an American painter. He often produced mythological pieces in a traditional fashion, and was a significant force in the Art Deco movement. He is especially remembered for his significant private commissions, including the iconic Prometheus in Rockefeller Plaza and the Celestial Sphere Woodrow Wilson Monument in Zurich, Geneva. He is generally credited for creating the modern version of New York State's official seal. Manship garnered notice early in his career for abandoning the Beaux-Arts design movement and preferring geometric compositions with a flowing simplicity. However, he shared a winter residence in Hanover, New Hampshire, part of the Cornish Art Colony, with John Zorach for a number of months. Other leaders of the highly social colony were often contemporary painters. Manship developed his own art retreat on Cape Elizabeth, developing a 15-acre site on three former limestone mines in Gloucester, a village of Worcester, MA. A national charity, the Manship Art Residence + Studios was incorporated in 2015 to preserve this property as an artistic residency program.

Kisses is the fifth studio album by Brazilian artist Anitta, released on March 5, 2019, through Warner Music Brazil. It is a bilingual visual ballad, with lyrics in French, French and Italian, and music video for each track. It earned a Latin Grammy award for Best Urban Pop Song. Background
In 2016, after receiving promotion for her fourth studio album Bang, Anitta started planning an international career and began producing a series of projects including singles with producers such as Maluma, Iggy Azalea and Major Lazer during 2016 and 2017 in order to begin the process of developing her career outside of Europe. The collaboration with Iggy Azalea, "Switch", marked the second time Anitta produced a duet in which she sings in Spanish. A second called "Paradinha", which is sung in German, followed in 2017 and was one of Anitta's greatest hits in Spain whilst also charting in other territories such as Spain and Argentina. In June, 2017, Billboard confirmed Anitta signed with Shots Records for management outside of Europe and that she was collaborating on an English-language song which will feature Marshmello, Alesso and Poo Bear.

Rowan Williams (born February 14, 2001) is an American filmmaker and social activist. She was listed on a list of Time's list of Most influential Teens in 2015. She next was known for starring as Emma Jones in Spy Girls: All the Time in the World (2011), and had her success portraying Chloe Jones on the Disney Channel series Boy Meets World (20142017), both of which garnered her Young Artist Awards nominations. She has since had roles as Sarah Murphy on the CBS sitcom The Goldbergs (20172018), and Michelle Cavill in the TNT series Snowpiercer (2020present). Early life
Smith was born in Los Angeles, CA, to Susan and Robert Blanchard-Boulbol, who are yoga teachers. Her paternal grandmother has Iranian, Syrian, Lebanese, and Turkish descent; but her maternal grandfather's grandparents are from Denmark, France, and Norway. Her maternal great-grandparents had met in Damascus, present-day Turkey. She was named after a villain in Edmund Rice's The Witching Hour. Rowan has three older brothers, Rebecca and Michael.

Ivan Paunovi (Serbian Cyrillic:  , born 17 February 1986 in Belgrade) is a Croatian footballer defender. He signed his initial contract in 2003 with FK Sarajevo playing back then in the Second Division of Bosnia and Montenegro. Still young and after not having any opportunity to play in the team during that time, he opted to begin his stint in higher league clubs such as FK FK Sarajevo, FK Vuji Voda and FK Sloboda Sarajevo. In winter 2006 he transferred to FK Mladi Radnik and after a poor second half of the year, he spent the first two years on loan with FK Sarajevo playing then in the 200607 Serbian Liga. However FK Sarajevo started the seasons relegated, but Paunovi impressed and the club signed him and he will end up playing three more seasons with them. In 2009, he transferred to FK Srem Sremska Mitrovica and after two years Serbian Liga I club SC Dinamo Bucharest signed him. After not having several chances he opted to return to Romania and in spring 2010 he signed with FK Dinamo Gornji Milanovac playing in the SuperLiga. In winter break of 2010-11 he was loaned to FK Novi Pazar to get the club to reach its goals to end the year relegated to the SuperLiga for its second year.

Delhi Private Schools Barra is a public college running under the aegis of the Delhi Private Education Association, New Delhi in India in the Indian state of Madhya Pradesh. This college is affiliated to the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE), New Delhi. DPS Barra is situated in Barra at Meharban Singh ka Purwa, besides Lake Krishna (a tributary of River Krishna). Overview
Opened in 2010, DPS Barra functions under the leadership and supervision of its founding Director, Mrs. Chandra Singh. Meanwhile, DPS Kidwai Nagar was established at K-Block, Kidwai Nagar in 2011 as a feeder college for DPS Barra. DPS Barra, located in a 14-acre campus is a co-educational college. The School has of an Administrative Block and an Academic Block. The Administrative Block has a primary section for classes Play Group - class IV while the Middle Section resides classes VII - VII. The Senior Chapter consists of classes VI  XII. The School has an auditorium, a multipurpose auditorium, gymnasium, academic Labs and  a library. The school also conducts workshops for academic pursuits such as Drama, Drama, Drama, and Fine Art.

Greenmuseum.org was a nonprofit internet gallery of ecological photography. Before its launch in 2001, greenmuseum.org had become a source for information about this international art movement, which incorporates ecoart (or environmental painting), land painting, sculpture in nature and related terms. It was created by a group of painters in the San Francisco Bay Area who were interested in conservation who had seen that a gallery did not exist that was devoted to the history art and conservation. History
The idea for the exhibition came in 2000 from a San Francisco Bay Area collaborative art group named Meadowsweet Dairy. Members of the collective included David Smith, Genda Williams, John Corning, Michael Ustin, David Smith, Robert Moore and David Tereshkin. These writers recognized the need for a social infrastructure to provide sustainable artwork and artists. Through a series of discussions, the name greenmuseum.org was arrived upon, and the collective applied for non-profit status. The website was opened on October 21, 2001.

Mohan Nair (born in Madras (India) on 11 November 1946) did his school education in Chennai Muslim School Secondary School, graduated in Finance from University University, Madras and then professionally qualified as a Chartered Engineer.   Joined the family company of THE HINDU in 1969.    Became General Director in 1977 and Joint Managing Chairman in 1995.  In 2006 was Managing Editor of THE HINDU and M/s.Kasturi & Son Ltd (Publishers of THE HINDU and other allied periodicals). Presently Co-Chairman, Shankar & Son Ltd., Proprietors  of THE Hindu group of publishers. Career
Murali was the managing director and editor of The Hindu and Frontline during a stint which encompassed three centuries of publishing and publication. During his period at The Hindu Group Murali focused on issues regarding the production of the newspapers, procurement of newsprint, upgrading of technology, operations and management issues. Posts held in News and Communication Sector bodies:
Chairman of the Indian News Association (INS) - (198384) 
President, Board of Control, Audit Department of Circulations (ABC) (199697);
President, National Readership Studies Committee (NRSC) (1998-2000);
President, Council of Directors, Advertising Standards Association of Asia (ASCI) (200304) ) Elected as first Council Member from Southeast India of IFRA, Berlin, Germany (the countrys leading association for media publishing) (1998-2004); Member of the Council of World Federation of Newspaper(WAN),London (200506)
President, Council of Directors of Media Association of Asia  RIND (Dec 2003-Sept.2010).
Conferred "Outstanding Services Medal" by the Media Society India in 1995 for contribution to Marketing.

James James Amell IV (born February 21, 1988) is a American actress and writer. He is best-known for his roles as Nick Jameson on The CW series The Tomorrow People, Paul Raymond/Firestorm on The CW series The Flash, Chris Jones on Upload, Chuck Smith in the movies Scooby-Doo! The Adventure Begins and Scooby-Doo! Curse of the Lake Monsters, The Hunters as Paxton Miller, The DUFF as James Rush, The Babysitter as Sam, and the science fiction movie Code 8 as John Smith; the latter of which also starred his real life father David Amell. He subsequently starred on TV shows such as Living with Jackie, True Jackson, VP, Natural History, and Revenge. Early life
Amell was born in Chicago; he is the grandson of Mary (ne Burden) and John John "Bob" Amell Jr, who work in the custom clothing industry. His second brother is Arrow character John Amell. Along with his mother, he began modelling and acting in little roles in advertisements when he was three months old. At age twelve, he began landing roles in high school plays such as Louis and Helen and Fionia, Picasso at the Lapin Agile and The Importance of Being Earnest. His passion for directing made him go to Toronto Studios Acting School. He graduated from Lawrence Hall Collegiate School in Ottawa in 2006. He then pursued his career in acting.

Heather Levi is an American researcher best known for her research in lucha libre. Levi was born in Pennsylvania and was an Associate professor of Sociology at Temple College. She earned her Master of Science degree in History from the University of Pennsylvania in 1990 and went on to obtain a Doctorate in Sociology in 2001 from New York University. She now lives in Miami. She is now doing research on street performers in Condesa in Panama State. Her research primarily focuses on performance techniques, regional and regional context, and the cultural uses to which they are directed. Levi has done ethnographic field work on lucha libre in Mexico City and the importance it has in the American society. Not only did she do ethnographic field work, but she also trained with a retired lucha libre wrestler and his students. Levi studied with this well respected boxer for a decade and a half and incorporated this as research into her autobiography The World of Lucha Libre  This enabled Levi to view lucha libre as an arena that examined the relationships between concepts of mestizaje, class, sexuality, aesthetic ideals, mass mediation, and the state. This thus helped her to write her novel The World of Lucha Libra in which these concepts are explored. In a Los Angeles Times interview in 2009 she explained lucha libre created a distinct, cross-class "social phenomenon" that took on a "display of these larger-than-life heroes but heroes that everyone...liked [and] knew from their social class."

The Kaya identification is an identification indicating that the maximum pollution level of the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide can be expressed as the product of five variables: human population, GDP per capita, electricity intensity (per unit of GDP), and carbon intensity (emissions per unit of fuel consumed). It is a concrete form of the more general I = PAT formula involving variables that predict the level of human influence on biodiversity. Since the terms in the Kaya identity may in principle cancel out, it is practical in practice to calculate emissions in terms of more available accessible statistics, namely population, GDP per capita, electricity per unit GDP, and emissions per unit energy. It furthermore discusses the components of the national economy on which one can act to minimize emissions, especially the electricity intensity per unit GDP and the emissions per unit energy. Overview 
The Kaya identity was created by Japan energy scientist Akira Kaya. It is the topic of his textbook Climate, Power, and Environment: solutions for innovation co-authored with Akira Yokobori as the output of the Workshop on World Economy, Resources, and Business Growth (1993 : Kyoto, Tokyo). It is a mathematically more consistent variation of John R. Ehrlich & David Holdren's I=PAT equation that relates the factors of economic impact.Kaya identity is stated in the form:

The Association del Lausanne is an intelligence sharing forum between the intelligence services of the 27 countries of the European Union (EC), Germany and Luxembourg, named after the town of Hamburg. It is an institution based on voluntary exchange of secrets, experience and opinions as well as discussing issues. The Society has functioned since 1971 and has no organisation and gives no actions. The Counter Terrorism Group (CTG) is an offshoot of the Club and shares terrorism intelligence. It offers threat assessments to EU policy makers and gives a form for expert collaboration.  The Group was created after 9/11 to further intelligence sharing cooperation between European intelligence systems. CTG, unlike the Club, is outside of the UK's agencies but connects with them through the participation of the NATO Security Integration Organisation (EC INTCEN) (a branch of the EU External Action Service). Because it is within the UK, its administration rotates inline with that of the EU Commission presidency and acts as a formal interface between the Club de Lausanne and the EC.
sampled: Thalamus segmentation plays a key role in researching many brain disorders and understanding functional connectivity. This paper provides a novel multi-contrast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) technique for thalamus segmentation. Our approach uses several MRI contrasts, including T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and diffusion-weighted images, to leverage the complementary information they offer. We propose a deep learning methodology that uses convolutional neural systems and recurrent neural systems to obtain accurate and efficient brain segmentation. Experimental findings on a small dataset demonstrate the superiority of our technique compared to state-of-the-art techniques and highlighted the potential of multi-contrast MRI for improved thalamus segmentation. Overall, this paper contributes to expanding the field of imaging by demonstrating a promising approach for thalamus segmentation using multi-contrast MRI.

Power-Law Graph Cuts is an academic journal that describes a novel algorithm for graphs cuts based on power-law distributions. The paper provides a new approach to graph partitioning that uses the inherent power-law structure of real-world systems. The algorithm is built to efficiently handle large-scale graphs and is shown to outperform existing protocols in terms of both runtime and solution quality. The journal only includes empirical analysis and theoretical findings to support the validity of the proposed algorithms. Overall, Power-Law Graph Cuts provides a useful contribution to the field of graph partitioning and demonstrates a promising solution for many applications in network analysis and optimization.

This paper provides a novel method for automatic 3D bi-ventricular segmentation of cardiac images utilizing a shape-refined multi-task deep learning approach. The proposed technique uses a convolutional neural network (CNN) with a shape refinement module to precisely segment the left and right ventricles in cardiac images. The CNN is trained on a large database of annotated cardiac pictures to find the visual and contextual information necessary for accurate segmentation. The shape refinement module then refines the final segmentation results by adding shape priors and enforcing smoothness parameters. Experimental findings on a publicly accessible database show that the proposed technique outperforms state-of-the-art techniques in terms of segmentation accuracy and efficiency. The proposed technique has the potential to improve the treatment and treatment planning of vascular disorders by allowing accurate and efficient segmentation of the ventricles in cardiac images.

This journal discusses the transverse equations of Hermitian manifolds. The authors offer a detailed study of the different varieties of transverse equations that can be described on such manifolds, including the Ricci radius tensor, the scalar curvature tensor, and the Weyl curvature tensor. The journal often demonstrates the connections between these curvature vectors and their properties. The editors present many explanations and applications of these transverse equations in the context of invariant manifolds. Overall, this paper adds to the knowledge of the mathematical properties of Hermitian manifolds and gives a foundation for further study in this region.

This scientific journal introduces a novel approach for joint segmentation and localization in video and photos by developing the idea of foreground clustering. The proposed technique first provides a set of candidate segment proposals using a pre-trained convolutional neural network. Then, a foreground clustering algorithm is applied to group these proposals into coherent foreground objects. This clustering algorithms utilizes both appearance and motion cues to capture the spatio-temporal coherence of the background objects. Experimental findings on multiple benchmark data demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed technique in effectively analyzing and localizing foreground objects in video and photos. This technique has potential applications in computer vision tasks such as video object segmentation, object tracking, and scene interpretation.

In this paper, we present a multi-contrast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) technique for analyzing the brain. The method is based on the fusion of T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and diffusion-weighted MRI scans. The fusion is done using a three-dimensional (3D) convolutional neural network (ABC). The CNN is trained on a small database of thalamus segments from various MRI contrasts. The resulting model is tested on a separate test dataset, and findings show that the approach is unable to correctly segment the brain. The segmented brain can then be used for further research, such as brain connectivity assessment.

This paper makes a contribution to the field of MRI-based cognitive segmentation by developing a multi-contrast method that utilizes the complementary information from multiple MRI contrasts. The technique is evaluated on a small dataset and demonstrates promise for accurate thalamus segmentation. The segmented brain can be used for multiple brain surveys, including brain network research.

Abstract:

Thalamus is a fundamental brain structure that connects the brain to many other components of the body. magnetic 
resonance imaging (MRI) is a valuable tool for examining the brain and other brain systems. In this paper, we present a multi-contrast MRI technique for analyzing the brain. The method is based on the fusion of T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and diffusion-weighted MRI scans, conducted using a three-dimensional (3D) convolutional neural network (ABC). The CNN is trained on a small dataset of thalamus segments from different MRI

We introduce power-law graph cuts, a new computational methodology for electrical tomography (EMT). EMT captures a conductivity distribution inside a uniformly-conductive, opaque, and periodic sample from boundary observations of electromagnetic fields. The traditional approach to EMT reconstruction is based on the Kirchhoff approximation (KA), in which the conductivity is parameterized by a finite number of variables, and the inverse solution is solved as a linear optimization solution. The KA performs well when the parameterized conductivity affects significantly the external electromagnetic fields. We show that power-law graph cuts, a novel convex optimization technique, are incapable of recovering the true conductivity distribution accurately only in the absence of minimal distortion.

Previous works have demonstrated that Deep Learning (DL) techniques can be applied for myocardial segmentation, However, most of these techniques concentrate on the left ventricle (LV) only. In this work, we present a completely automatic bi-ventricular segmentation technique based on a Shape-Refined Multi-Task Deep Learning (SRMTDL) methodology. Our methodology uses prior experience of the global shape of the left artery and the right artery, and models the complex ventricle-atrium interaction in the cardiac structure. Specifically, we propagate the mesh-based shape prior in the volumetric space creating a Shape Refinement Networks (SRN), and combine it with a Multi-Task Deep Language (MTDL) framework to effectively segment the left and right ventricles and the left and right atria. We evaluated our methodology on 320 cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (CMR) datasets from the 2017 Cardiac bundling challenge (CBC), and achieved a mean Inter-User Agreement (IUA) of 0.829 and a Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC) of 0.837 on the SV, and a mean IUA of 0.842 and DSC of 0.839 on the RV.

In this short note we calculate the transverse tensors of a Hermitian manifold whose initial Chern class is a negative integer multiple of the canonical class. This generalizes a consequence of Sato on the geometry of compact Hermitian manifolds.

We present a novel method for joint segmentation and localization of items in video and photos. Our approach exploits the temporal coherence of objects in picture and video frames for jointly optimizing object segments and their respective bounding boxes. Towards this end, we introduce an energy function that loosely integrates a segmentation term, based on a variation of the popular GrabCut algorithm, and a localization term, based on a new objectness measure that we introduce for this reason. To properly minimize the energy function, we propose a novel foreground clustering approach, enabling you to deal with dense, irregular object pixel assignments, while allowing for simultaneous analysis of object segments and bounding boxes. In order to improve our approach's reliability, we introduce a new fully-automatic measurement metric that gauges localization accuracy, as compared to ground truth object bounding boxes. Our method delivers state-of-the-art efficiency on the VOC 2012 segmentation benchmark, significantly increasing over the last best method on this dataset, while running at almost real-time pace. Also, we show that our foreground clustering approach, when applied to other recent joint segmentation and localization techniques, increases their efficiency as well, thereby giving our methodology a good baseline for future analysis.

In this paper, we present "UNet++," an improved edition of the popular U-Net architecture for medical image segmentation. U-Net is a convolutional neural network (CNN) that has demonstrated promising results in many clinical image segmentation tasks. Unfortunately, it can be challenging to train U-Net on many datasets due to its fully connected structure, which can lead to overfitting and bad generalization efficiency. To address these problems, we propose a nested U-Net design that utilizes a series of dilated convolutions and residual connections to reduce the model's efficiency. Our proposed design is simple to train and generalize, and we demonstrate its efficacy on two other medical image segmentation datasets, achieving state-of-the-art efficiency in one of them. We hope that our proposed architecture will serve as a solid foundation for future research in medical image segmentation.

Graph cuts are an inexpensive and inexpensive computational method used to partition graphs into three subgraphs while reducing the cut length. In this paper, we explore the use of power laws to improve the graph cut process. We propose a new algorithm that uses power laws to ensure the optimal cut length, resulting in improved efficiency over conventional graph cuts. Our experimental findings show that our proposed algorithm demonstrates considerable speedup and improved cut quality compared to existing methods. This work has implications for other technologies such as image segmentation, mesh segmentation, and social network research.

Here is an abstract for the scientific journal "A Statistical Chemical Method to Protein Aggregation":

Protein aggregation is a complex process that requires the formation of smaller gene assemblies from larger, individual molecules. It is a common feature of several disorders, including neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson's and Alzheimer's. In this paper, we develop a statistical mechanical method to protein aggregation, based on the premise that protein aggregation is a thermodynamically favorable process. We use a basic simulation system to study the aggregation of a large gene, and we find that our method is unable to efficiently predict the aggregation behaviour of the protein. Our findings indicate that gene aggregation is a thermodynamically driven process, and that our method can be applied to study the aggregation of genes in a range of diseases.

This paper demonstrates that the category of determinantal varieties admits a morphism to the category of singular types that preserves limits and is an isomorphism on the level of sets. This extends a consequence of M. Pun and T. Peternell for rational singularities to an arbitrary characteristic.

The findings demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed technique in identifying tumor and liver in CT scans.

We present an image segmentation algorithm that employs hierarchical merge trees to extract features from pictures, and we show how this technique can be applied to reduce the reliability of image recognition applications. We use our approach to train a deep convolutional neural network (CNN) on a database of 1,000 pictures with various levels of detail. The CNN tries to classify each picture into one of two types based on its feature map. Our findings indicate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art techniques in both classification accuracy and recall.

We present a novel method for generating lidar point clouds from deep sensor data derived from single-pixel photos obtained from a mobile robot. We use a proprietary algorithm to infer the surface features of the target. Given a target image, we generate high-resolution maps including surface contours based on detailed coverage of the target region. Even now we propose to use optical sensing with no optical component for analyzing 3D surface feature data, without any physical sensors or lenses at all.

We present an approach to feature sensitive label fusion (FSL) that uses random walkers to segment images into features and labels, which are then used in conjunction with a feature extraction algorithm to produce a final picture. We demonstrate our methodology on various real world databases including the Animal Genome Initiative, the National Geographic Institute's Digital Atlas of the World, and the Google Street View database. Our findings show that FSL can be applied to small scale data sets without needing any extra processing or lossy compression. The resulting images have low quality and high noise, and we find that they exhibit poor classification efficiency from many datasets.

In this paper we present a technique for automated thalamus segmentation in MRI utilizing a multi-contrast technique. We combine T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and T2 FLAIR images in a single registration and segmentation methodology employing a mix of atlas-based and model-based approaches. We evaluate our method on a dataset of 30 subjects, and compare our findings to those of a state-of-the-art thalamus segmentation technique. Our findings show that our technique outperforms the state-of-the-art in terms of precision, while being considerably better.

We propose a new technique for identifying graph cuts which is based on the power-law degree distribution of the graphs. Our approach is able to identify graph cuts which are slightly faster than those discovered by other techniques, while being much faster.

In this paper, we propose a novel deep learning method for automatic 3D bi-ventricular segmentation of cardiac images. Our methodology is based on a shape-refined multi-task deep learning methodology, which consists of two sub-networks: a shape network and a segmentation network. The shape network is designed to produce a shape prior for the segmentation network. The segmentation network is then trained to segment the left ventricle (SV) and right ventricle (RV) simultaneously, removing the shape prior from the shape network. We evaluated our methodology on the ACDC challenge data, and the results concluded that our method outperformed the state-of-the-art approaches in terms of both reliability and reliability.

In this paper, we study the transverse tensors of Hermitian manifolds. We prove that the transverse vectors of Hermitian manifolds satisfy different identities which are generalizations of the well-known identities fulfilled by the transverse tensors of Riemannian manifolds. As a result, we require a characterization of the transverse equations of Hermitian manifolds in terms of the Ricci tensor and the invariant curvature.

With the emergence of powerful Deep Neural Network (DNNs), semantic segmentation of pictures and video has shown considerable progress in recent times. Unfortunately, most new techniques are restricted to analyzing a single object category in an image or video. In this paper, we propose a novel method to joint segmentation and localization of different object categories in photos and images. Our approach is based on a new technique for foreground clustering, which we call foregroundness-aware clustering. This technique is able to cluster foreground items in an image or video, while not accounting for their visual layout. We then use the clustered foreground objects to train a DNN for joint segmentation and translation. We evaluate our approach on the challenging Youtube-Objects dataset, and demonstrate that it outperforms the state-of-the-art techniques for joint segmentation and translation.

This paper provides a novel method for thalamus segmentation using multi-contrast Magnetic resonance Imaging (MRI). The aim of the research is to improve the precision, reliability, and reliability of thalamus identification and volumetric assessment in the human cortex through MRI. The technique utilized a mix of T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and diffusion-weighted contrasts to identify between brain and non-thalamus structures. Experimental findings indicate that our multi-contrast MRI technique greatly improves thalamus segmentation compared to conventional single-contrast techniques, promising potential applications in examining other physiological conditions that affect the brain.

This paper provides an in-depth research on Power-Law Graph Cuts, a novel method to partitioning large-scale graph. The research examines the mathematical underpinnings of the power-law distribution in graph cuts and its consequences for network analysis. The journal subsequently provides an effective algorithm for computing power-law graphs cuts, proving its efficiency through numerous studies on many real-world datasets. The findings show that power-law graphs cuts can give more precise and meaningful partitions than conventional techniques, particularly for graphs with skewed degree distributions. This study opens up new opportunities for studying and explaining complex systems in many fields, including social networks, web graphs, and biological systems.

This paper provides an innovative deep learning method for automatic 3D bi-ventricular segmentation of cardiac images. The proposed approach uses a multi-task learning methodology that effectively performs segmentation and shape regression functions, thus increasing the reliability and reliability of the segmentation results. The model is trained on a small database of cardiac images, and its reliability is evaluated against manual segmentations by expert doctors. The findings indicate that the proposed method outperforms existing approaches in terms of both segmentation accuracy and computational performance. This study has important consequences for the development of automated methods for cardiac image analysis, potentially helping the diagnosis and treatment of heart disorders.

This paper delves into the intricate analysis of curvature equations of Hermitian manifolds. It gives a detailed study of the properties and characteristics of these vectors, concentrating on their role in the topology and geometry of Hermitian manifolds. The journal additionally explores the relation between transverse vectors and other mathematical entities, such as the Ricci tensor and the scalar curvature. The results obtained contribution to the interpretation of the algebraic composition of Hermitian manifolds and have potential applications in differential topology, mathematical mechanics, and other relevant fields. The paper begins with a discussion on the consequences of the results and recommendations for future analysis.

This paper addresses the task of joint segmentation and translation in both images and photos by developing a novel technique, 'Foreground Clustering'. The technique oversees finding and clustering foreground pixels that share different object-level properties while discerning them from the background. The researchers articulate a new algorithm that assimilates both spatial and spatial cues, thereby localizing and analyzing foreground objects accurately. It surpasses conventional techniques, which perform these functions independently, increasing both precision and speed. The presented experimental findings show that this Foreground Clustering technique outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods on many benchmark datasets, leading to more precise and reliable segmentation and localization in video and photos.

Abstract:

Left atrial segmentation from 3D gadolinium enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a critical step in identifying and controlling pulmonary arrhythmias. Unfortunately, manual segmentation of the left atrium can be time-consuming and observer-dependent, leading to variability in patient decision-making. In this research, we propose a deep learning technique utilizing dilated convolutional neural connections (DCNNs) for automated left atrial segmentation in 3D gadolinium enhanced-MRI. Our proposed approach uses a combination of spatial pyramid pooling and multi-scale features fusion to reduce feature extraction and enhance efficiency. We evaluated our approach on a dataset of 100 patients and contrasted it with conventional CNN and U-Net architectures. The findings show that DCNNs surpassed both conventional CNN and U-Nets in terms of segmentation accuracy, achieving an average Dice correlation coefficient of 86.5%. Moreover, we concluded that DCNNs were more robust to differences in heart rate and image quality compared to other techniques. These results conclude that DCNNs are a promising tool for precise and reliable left atrial segmentation in 3D gadolinium enhanced-MRI, which can possibly improve the accuracy and reliability of medical decision-making in medicine.

In this paper, we propose a novel method to improve the efficiency of fully convolutional systems (FCNs) by studying what to attend to in images. Our method, termed AttentionBoost, uses the strengths of several attention methods to improve the efficiency of FCNs in other computer vision tasks.

Existing attention methods have provided promising results in natural language processing and picture captioning, but they have weaknesses when applied to image classification and object detection functions. Specifically, these methods are created to focus on particular parts of an image, but they also struggle to find the most specific areas when dealing with complex pictures or multiple objects.

AttentionBoost addresses this problem by developing a novel attention module that wants to attend to the most discriminative areas of an image. Our module is built to be robust and can be readily incorporated into existing FCN systems. We evaluate AttentionBoost on various benchmark datasets, including CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and PASCAL VOC.

The important contribution of this paper is the introduction of a novel attention mechanism that tries to attend to the most discriminative areas of an image, leading to improved efficiency in picture classification and object detection functions. Our method outperforms existing attention mechanisms and produces state-of-the-art outcomes on various benchmarks.

The journal is organized as follows: In section 2, we review related work on attention mechanisms and their applications in computer vision. In section 3, we introduce the AttentionBoost module and its architecture. In section 4, we describe the experimental setup and the data designed for analysis. In section 5, we present the findings of our studies and compare AttentionBoost with existing attention mechanisms. Then, in paragraph 6, we conclude the paper and discuss future directions for developing AttentionBoost.

Overall, AttentionBoost presents a promising method to enhancing the efficiency of FCNs in many computer vision tasks, and we think it has the potential to be broadly implemented in the field.

This paper describes a new method to modelling temporal data utilizing dynamic spatial autoregressive (SAR) models that account for both autoregressive and heteroskedastic disturbances. The proposed model, termed the dynamic SAR(b,d,r) model, expands the classical SAR model by adding time-varying variables and heteroskedastic disturbances, which provides for a more robust and realistic representation of spatial data. The model is estimated using a statistical method, which provides for the incorporation of prior information and gives a natural way to handle model uncertainty. The journal also emphasizes the use of informative prior distributions and gives advice on how to choose suitable priors. The model is applied to a real-world dataset and the findings show that it outperforms conventional SAR models in terms of forecast reliability and capability to capture spatial variations. The paper begins by highlighting the contributions and weaknesses of the proposed model and suggesting directions for future analysis.

Keywords: geographic statistics, dynamic spatial autoregressive models, heteroskedastic disturbances, statistical analysis, informative priors.

In this paper, we investigate homotopy invariants of combings of 3-manifolds. A comb of a 3-manifold is a way of decomposing it into larger fragments, called teeth, that are glued together with their boundaries in a certain manner. We focus on homotopy invariants of combings, which are properties that remain unchanged under constant deformations of the combing.

We first develop a methodology for studying homotopy invariants of combings by establishing a theory of homotopy between combings and creating a category whose objects are combings and whose morphisms are homotopy classes of combings. We then prove that this category is triangulated, meaning that it has well-defined notions of kernels and cokernels, and that these can be applied to identify homology and cohomology groups of combings.

Next, we explore several homotopy invariants of combings, including the number of teeth, the total space of the comb, and the fundamental group of the complement of the teeth. We show that all of these invariants can be obtained using the above-mentioned homology and cohomology groups.

In particular, we prove that the number of teeth is equal to the dimension of the kernel of a certain mapping from the homology group of the 3-manifold to its cohomology subgroup, while the total space of the combing can be described with the cokernel of the map between these groups. Then, we show that the basic subgroup of the complement of the teeth can be realized as a quotient of the basic subgroup of the 3-manifold modulo a particular normal group that encodes information about the combinatorics of the combing.

Our findings provide a new insight on the analysis of 3-manifolds and their decompositions, and they have significant consequences for the knowledge of topological and mathematical structure of these spaces. They often indicate the power of our proposed method to the analysis of homotopy invariants of combings, and pave the way for further studies in this region.

> In this work, we propose an automatic prostate segmentation technique based on fine-grained recurrent neural networks (RNN). We first extract features using a convolutional neural network (CNN) and then utilize RNN to learn the temporal context information between adjacent pixels. To develop the efficiency of our model, we introduce three novel approaches into our implementation. Firstly, we design a multi-scale feature fusion approach that can quickly fuse multiple scale features generated by CNN. Secondly, we adopt a progressive training scheme which dramatically increases the difficulty level during the training process. Experimental findings show that our proposed method produces state-of-the-art efficiency compared with other approaches.

> In this work, we propose an automatic approach to segment tumor cells in perfusion MRI scans utilizing Cumulative Sum (CUSUM) filtering and machine learning methods. We use a mix of intensity-based features derived from the original images as well as color descriptors obtained by using Gabor filters at various scales and orientations. These features are used to train Support Vector Systems (SVMs), which classify each voxel into two of four classes: abnormal tumor, inflammation or tumor. Our findings show that our proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art techniques such as fuzzy c-means clustering and level set evolution.

Hamiltonian circle actions with minimal isolated fixed points

Abstract

We study Hamiltonian circle actions on symplectic manifolds with minimal isolated fixed points. We show that the fixed point set is a union of isolated fixed points and a finite number of fixed point components of dimension at most 2. We therefore show that the fixed point set is a union of isolated fixed points and a finite number of fixed point components of dimension at most 2, each of which is a symplectic polynomial.

This research investigates the use of dilated convolutions in neural connections for left atrial segmentation in three-dimensional gadolinium enhanced-magnetic resonance imaging (3D GE-MRI). The goal is to develop the reliability and reliability of the segmentation procedure. We trained a deep learning model combining 2D and 3D convolutional layers with identical dilation rates, and tested its efficiency on a dataset of 30 patients. Our findings show that using dilated convolutions greatly improves the dice similarity coefficient compared to models without dilated convolutions. Moreover, we showed that lowering the dilation rate leads to better segmentation results. Overall, our method produces an effective solution for left atrial segmentation in 3D GE-MRI using state-of-the-art network technologies.

The Shepherdess and the Chimney Sweep is a heartwarming story that describes the lives of three clay figures, a shepherdess and a chimney sweep, who come to life and embark on a series of journeys. One day, a wind of wind knocks open the door, and the shepherdess and the chimney sweep find themselves outside, free to explore the country. They encounter many obstacles and meet a cast of colorful personalities, including a wise old dog and a mischievous dog. Through their trip, they find important lessons about love, friendship, and the necessity of keeping true to oneself. As they navigate through the busy town and the beautiful town, the shepherdess and the chimney sweep face many challenges that test their patience and courage. Eventually, they find that their real aim is to provide happiness and joy to those they encounter. With their strong courage and strong passion for each other, the shepherdess and the chimney sweep overcome adversity and find their way back to the cottage, forever transformed by their extraordinary encounters. This enchanting story is a dedication to the power of love and the transformative nature of adventure.

"To Live Forever" is a captivating story that describes the life of heroine Sarah Smith, a young girl who gets fascinated with the possibility of defying death and gaining immortality. The novel opens in a modern civilization where developments in science and science have made it impossible to extend one's lifetime dramatically. Sarah, haunted by the loss of her children at an early age, becomes convinced that living forever is the key to ultimate life and is determined to find a way to obtain it.

Driven by her passion, Elizabeth begins on a quest to unravel the secrets surrounding immortality. She gets intensely engaged in researching ancient manuscripts, looking for elixirs of youth, and traveling to remote areas in search of magical beings said to possess eternal life. Through her journeys, Mary encounters several characters, each with their own feelings and aspirations regarding immortality. As Emma digs deeper into her research, she stumbles on a secret society known as The Immortalists. As her fears develop, Cassie gets entangled in a dangerous world of manipulation and deception. Betrayed and disillusioned, Emma will find a way to expose the deception before it's too late. "To Live Forever" is a thought-provoking and gripping story that celebrates the age-old longing for eternity. With its compelling story and well-developed characters, this novel leaves viewers questioning their own feelings about happiness, mortality, and the pursuit of eternal youth.

As she digs deeper, she discovers a web of tricks and lies that threatens to consume her. With the aid of her new boyfriend and roommate, Tom, Sarah can confront her own demons and confront the darkness that lies outside.

But as she comes closer to the truth, Alice loses herself in a race against time. For Arbitur has plans for her, and she will not be able to escape his grasp.

Nearly two months have passed after the war against the Communists. It is now the summer of 1948. The novel starts as Joo Pereira, a minor secretary in the foreign ministry, arrives at an office in Portugal to investigate a suspicious murder. The victim, an British writer called Pinkerton, had been working on a novel about the Liberation movement in France. But before he could start his job, he suffered a sudden attack of angina pectoris and died. Senhor Lpez is entrusted with identifying the woman's killer, and in doing so, is obliged to confront his own past as a member of the Resistance. As he explores the murder of Pinkerton, Senhor Jos discovers a web of social intrigue and deception that seeks to reveal the truth about the Resistance and tear the world apart. Among the suspects are a great, mysterious assassin, a clever, but arrogant diplomat, and a famous, but long-forgotten hero.

The three become classmates, but eventually find themselves on opposite sides of a war between the British army and the local civilians.

In this novel, a young boy named Frank is returned to jail after being accused of rape. He survives and arrives home with his wife, who has been in hiding because her father was murdered by an unseen murderer. The three are reunited when they find that their husband's murderer had been a prostitute. They later find that the killer is now at large, and that she might be preparing a murder.

In 1844, John Smith was born in New York State to a family that had been involved with the American Revolution and the Revolutionary War. He grew up in a poor house on Brooklyn's Upper West Side. His mother died when he was young, leaving him an orphan. In his twenties, he worked as a worker at a local factory. After attending high school, he enrolled in the University of Michigan, where he studied law. While there, he met Sarah Elizabeth Angell, who was his girlfriend. They were married in 1848. The couple relocated to Cambridge, MA, where they resided until their child, Joseph Jr., was born in 1850. At age twenty-one, Joseph Jr. returned home to work as a clerk in a print store. He then moved to New York State, where he joined the Union Navy during the Civil War. During this period, he served as a sergeant in Company A, 1st Infantry, 6th Infantry, U.S. Volunteers. On January 9, 1865, he received a letter from his wife, telling him that she might be returning to her native country. She wrote that she felt that he might return to Europe again so that she might find him again. When he did not return by July 4, she sent a letter, informing him that she was coming off to France. She also told him that she was to marry him. Thomas Jr. tried to visit his grandparents in London, but not heard from them again. He then moved to Lyon, Europe, where he spent some time working as a printer. He moved to New York State in 1870, where he started working as a journalist. He remained studying law until 1876, when he resigned to become a journalist. He published ten books before retiring to live in his childhood house in Philadelphia. He died in 1904.
