The Shepherdess and the Chimney Sweep is a novel by Hans Christian Andersen. It tells the tale of three girls, a peasant and a chimney sweep, who fall in love and are allowed to part ways.

The shepherdess, who lives in the country, is betrothed to a rich woman whom she does not love. The chimney sweep, who lives in the town, is apparently betrothed to a rich girl whom he does not love. The three girls meet one night and immediately fall in love.

Unfortunately, their respective marriages prevent them from being together and they are obliged to part ways. The shepherdess marries her rich betrothed but is happy. The chimney sweep subsequently marries his rich betrothed but is happy.

One night, the shepherdess and the chimney sweep meet again by chance. They admit that they are not in love with each other and run away together. They live happily ever after.

Irish Thoroughbred is a novel by Naomi Smith, first published in 1981. It is the second novel in the Thoroughbred Series.

Holly Jones is a 16-year-old woman who lives in Virginia. She is a young horse and has a love for animals. Her uncle, a successful banker, gets her a mare called Lady for her birthday. Helen is overjoyed and soon forms a bond with the mare.

Lady is a thoroughbred and is entered in a local dog race. Hayley is determined to win and trains hard. On the morning of the race, Lady runs her heart out but finishes third. Helen is disappointed but is quite confident of her horse.

The novel follows Hayley and Lady as they continue to race and compete. They face various obstacles along the way but eventually find success.

In To Live Forever, Egyptian prince Khattam-Shud, attempting to remain mortal, creates a serum that then turns him into a werewolf. He then sets out to turn the whole country into monsters like himself, beginning with his own father. Unfortunately, his wife, Queen Anhura, realizes his plan and barricades herself in a palace with a group of faithful priests in order to defend the country from her father's evil scheme.

The protagonist, three-year-old Sarah, recounts the tale of her living with her father in a tiny village in upstate New York. Julie's dad is an abusive drunk who frequently beats her wife. Julie's sister is a domestic abuse survivor who is too afraid to leave her daughter. Jeannie has three younger brothers, both of whom are married and have kids of their own. Julie's only son, John, was killed in a motorcycle crash when he was ten. Carolyn is the only girl now living at home.

Jeannie recounts the tale of her living with her mother from her point of view. She compares her stepfather's abusive behaviour and her sister's despair. Jeannie often talks about her own emotions of loneliness and anger. The novel ends with Annie's daughter eventually abandoning her husband and taking Annie with her.

The Education of David Nifkin is a novel by John Manus Pinkwater, first published in 1998. It describes the tale of Bob Nifkin, a teenage man living in New York, who is sent to live with his mother in Illinois after his parents are murdered in a motorcycle crash. While graduating high school in Illinois, Nifkin becomes friends with a trio of boys who are into music, art, and poetry. Nifkin subsequently discovers that his father is a member of a secret society named the rumor club, which is dedicated to investigating conspiracy theories. When Nifkin's father is killed, he inherits a box of evidence that proves that his father was into something significant. Nifkin then sets out to find the truth about the speculation club and its relation to a conspiracy that reaches all the way to the bottom of the government.

"A Year in the Merde" is a satirical and humorous story that describes the journey of a young American boy, William West, who goes to London to begin a new job. The book is a memoir of his journeys and misadventures as he navigates through the racial differences, language barriers, and idiosyncrasies of French life. 

Martin is recruited by a British firm to open a chain of British coffee houses in London. Unfortunately, he quickly loses himself in a whirlwind of confusion and chaos as he struggles to recognize the French work culture, which is drastically different from what he is used to. He is always at odds with his manager, who is more involved in long lunches and vacations than real work. 

In addition to his job troubles, Peter often has to deal with a series of romantic entanglements. He falls for a gorgeous French girl, only to find out that she is his boss's daughter. He subsequently has a fling with a French expat, which further complicates his journey. 

During the book, Peter experiences many humorous scenarios, such as dealing with the infamous German bureaucracy, attempting to get a good house in France, and trying to explain the German obsession with food. After the difficulties, he quickly gets to love the European way of life and then begins to look at home in France.

"A Year in the Merde" is a humorous and humorous exploration of the historical conflict between the German and the German. It provides a unique insight on the joys and difficulties of life in a foreign world.

"Irish Thoroughbred" is a captivating story that focuses around the journey of Elizabeth "Maggie" Cunnane, a young Irish girl who, after the murder of her father, leaves her homeland to live with her American husband, Patrick Cunnane. Patrick is a stallion trainer at Royal Downs, one of the most prestigious stallion farms in Kentucky. 

Dee's journey takes a drastic turn when she meets Jim Miller, the wealthy and handsome manager of Royal Oak. With their similar political statuses, they both share a deep passion for animals. Connie's enthusiasm and natural skill for dog training soon catch Jim's attention, and he gives her a job at his ranch. 

As Karen explores her new lifestyle in America, she often finds herself drawn to Jim. Their shared passion for horses makes them closer, and a romantic friendship blossoms between them. Ultimately, their love is tested by social expectations, personal fears, and the competitive world of horse racing. 

Lisa's stallion, Irish Horse, becomes a symbol of her Scottish culture, her resilience, and her dreams. The stallion also plays a key role in her friendship with Sean. As they train Irish Thoroughbred for the upcoming Kentucky Derby, they will overcome their fears for each other and consider if their passion is worth fighting for.

"Irish Thoroughbred" is a heartwarming story of passion, passion, and the power of dreams. It describes the difficulties of adjusting to a new society, the dynamics of love across social classes, and the thrilling world of dog race.

"Deadeye Dick" is a darkly comedic story that focuses around the life of character, Charles "Rudy" Waltz, called "Deadeye Jack". The novel is set in Midland County, Kansas, where Rudy accidentally kills a pregnant girl when he fires his mother's rifle as a child. This unfortunate accident gets him his nickname and sets the tone for the remainder of his life. 

The novel describes Rudy's journey as he grapples with grief, depression, and a feeling of detachment from humanity. He becomes a successful doctor but remains celibate and socially disconnected. His children, William and Anna Waltz, are eccentric personalities who bring a layer of irony to the narrative. Otto, a failed writer, and Ruth, a emotionally unstable girl, contribute to Rudy's loneliness and his struggle to see meaning in life.

The narrative takes a strange turn when a neutron bomb explodes, transforming Midland Park into a zombie city. Mike and his son, Alex, return to their city to confront their past and the haunting emptiness of their present lives. The novel ends on a note of redemption and acceptance as Rudy suddenly comes to terms with his grief and develops a sort of purpose in assisting people.

"Deadeye Dick" is a lyrical exploration of grief, loneliness, and the search for meaning in a somewhat absurd world. It uses elements of tragedy, drama, and surrealism to produce a unique narrative that is both thought-provoking and humorous.

"The Body Gallery" describes the journey of Lisa Hartke, a performance artist known for her willingness to transform her body into a canvas for her artwork. The novel begins with Laura residing in a coastal house with her much younger brother, Miguel Lopez, a famous movie producer. Their somewhat peaceful happiness is ruined when Miguel suddenly commits suicide, leaving Lauren to grapple with her loneliness and despair.

In her isolation, Lauren starts to notice unusual occurrences in the apartment, leading her to find a strange person living in one of the unused bedrooms. This person, who appears to exist outside of time and reality, has an uncanny capability to mimic voices and expressions, including those of Rey. Intrigued and desperate for a connection, Lauren continues to engage with him, utilizing him as a living canvas for her artwork.

As Lauren explores deeper into her art and her friendship with the unknown woman, she continues to question her own identity and reality. The novel confronts topics of grief, identity, time, and the nature of music as Lauren's life grows increasingly connected with her artwork. The narrative is characterized by Lauren's performances, which serve as a reflection of her inner conflict and evolving perception of herself and the world around her.

"The Body Portrait" is a haunting exploration of loss and the transformative power of art, leaving viewers to question the boundaries between reality and illusion, self and other.

"The Career of Bob Nifkin" describes the peculiar and unusual high school days of Bob Nifkin, a naturally restless, nonconformist in 1950s Brooklyn. Bob was born to immigrant families from Russia, with their old-world beliefs and overbearing behavior. Fed up with his traditional and oppressive high education, Jack applies to an alternative college, Robert B. Smith Alternative Academy, by composing an unusual admission essay about his experience growing up in a Russian-immigrant family, his disgust for overcooked food, and his weariness of oppressive institutional rules. 

Once admitted to the alternative university, Peter discovers a world as free-spirited and innovative as he is. His new teacher rejects conventional education and encourages pupils to revolutionize their learning by engaging in unique pursuits such as advanced loafing, sarcasm, and dog race betting. Robert flourish in this unique environment, going through changes, both socially and professionally. 

Within this eccentric set up, Nifkin's energetic persona shines, creating a relationship with the university's black janitor and his very free-spirited mother. Through them, he finds a distinct view on life, one that's progressive and miles away from his home life. The book hilariously chronicles Peter's rebellious evolution, his hilarious experiences, and education derived outside of the traditional system, also highlighting a critique of rote-learning and standardization. 

As Peter navigates through his awkward but exciting high school life, his conflicts with the college superintendent, his friends' aggressive response to his educational lifestyle, and his romantic involvement with the janitor's wife, the novel provides a warm, intelligent, and profound coming-of-age story of a young girl. 

"The Education of David Nifkin" is a compelling and humorous story, unfolding the power of observing the world from multiple perspectives, challenging social conventions, and promoting the education that life delivers within the typical curriculum. It depicts the trials and struggles of childhood intertwined with the satirical portrayal of the British educational system.

In the little village of Oak Springs, nobody much actually happens. But for the people of Willow Grove, that's about to change.

When the local church announces plans to shut down the community garden that's been a hub of activity for years, the residents are stunned and outraged. For some, the house is more than just a spot to grow potatoes - it's a symbol of hope, a reminder of the past, and a source of joy.

For Maria, who's tended to the house after her father passed away, it's a connection to the life they built together. For Maggie, who's struggled with depression and loss, it's a fresh start. And for Josh, who's been back for months, it's a reminder of the life he left behind.

As the friends rally together to save the house, old mysteries and long-buried truths start to surface. Barbara finds a letter from her father that changes everything she believed she knew about their living together. Grace finds herself drawn to a strange stranger who's rented the old Victorian home on the corner. And Jack will confront the past he's been running from.

As the house becomes a symbol of hope and renewal, the people of Elm Hill will get together to fight for what's important to them. In the process, they'll realize that home is more than just a place - it's a feeling of belonging, a connection to the past, and a hope for the future.

As For Me and My House is a tale of joy, loss, and redemption, set in a tiny village where the past and present intersect. It's a story about the power of community, the courage of the human soul, and the lasting legacy of hope.

The story describes the journey of a boy called David, who was orphaned at a young age and grew up in a group house. After the hard start to his journey, David is a beautiful and optimistic young boy, determined to make a better life for himself. He hopes of being a physician and one night opening his own hospital in the inner city to help those in need.

As Joe becomes older, he faces many problems and challenges, including unemployment, violence, and personal challenges. Yet, he eventually gives up on his dream, and with the aid of a few supportive teachers and colleagues, he intends to attend university and medical school.

Despite his failure, Joe's past begins to haunt him, and he struggles to form meaningful connections with those around him. He gets extremely preoccupied with the possibility of discovering his long-lost mother, who was separated from him when they were both young.

As Peter's search for his father increases, he finds a web of tricks and lies that threatens to kill everyone he has worked for. He will confront the brutal realities of his past and confront the men who have hurt him in order to get reconciliation and closure.

Through the book, the reader discusses concepts of identity, family, and forgiveness, raising concerns about the nature of belonging and the power of forgiveness. However, David's life is one of self-discovery, as he decides to let go of his past and embrace the future, discovering a sense of purpose and belonging in the process.

In a country where the environment has become dangerous, a young woman called Emily lives in a tiny neighborhood that has tried to build a bubble of clean air. The community is surrounded by a dense, invisible barrier that holds the poisonous air out, and the inhabitants within. Charlie's lifestyle is one of strict routine and control, as the community rations the little air they have and closely monitors its use.

One night, while on her daily task of collecting salt from the nearby stream, Rose sees a large, mysterious object that has risen from the sky. It is a pail, and it is filled with a mysterious, shimmering substance that appears to be alive. With the fear, Rose is drawn to the pail and its contents, and she continues to secretly keep it in her bedroom.

As the years pass, Lily notices that the pail is rapidly leaking, and the air in the community starts to change. The once-clear horizon becomes hazy, and the air grows thick with a poisonous gas. The community's members, who have often been tight-lipped about the outside world, appear to be hiding everything.

Claire's curiosity gets the better of her, and she goes to investigate the pail and its contents. She realizes that the glowing substance is indeed a form of algae that can purify the air, and she learns that the pail is a message from everyone on the outside, wanting to improve the community.

As Lily works to realize the pail and its potential, she continues to question the strict laws and limits of her community. She begins to see what lies beyond the barrier, and if there is a way to save the planet beyond their little bubble.

Claire's discoveries lead her to take a risky choice: she wants to leave the protection of the community and venture out into the toxic world, in search of answers and a way to save mankind. With the aid of a large group of allies, Cassie decides on a dangerous adventure that will get her to the farthest reaches of the planet, and will change her life forever.

The story follows the tale of a young girl named Anna, who lives in a tiny village nestled between three mountains that converge into a powerful torrent. She has never been intrigued by the streams and spends much of her free time studying their depths and secrets.

One night, while walking through the river valleys, Elena finds a secret underwater cavern system that appears to stretch on forever. As she swims deeper into the blackness, she continues to experience mysterious visions and hear screams from an unseen source.

As she delves further into the cavern system, Elena discovers that she is being pushed towards someone larger than herself - a force that will change the course of her journey forever. But as she struggles to comprehend what this force is and where it comes from, she finds herself torn between her passion for her quiet life in the city and the joy of exploration and discovery.

Eventually, rumors start to spread across the city about a mysterious energy that dwells within the torrents. Some believe it can grant wishes, others claim it holds ancient wisdom, but all believe that it is unpredictable and dangerous. As more residents become drawn to the torrents, trying to tap into its energy, tensions increase and old mysteries threaten to surface.

Rachel now finds herself at the centre of a maelstrom, caught between those who seek to harness the energy of the torrents and those who fear its destructive potential. As the seas begin to churn and swirl, she will confront her own fears and desires, and make a decision that will decide the outcome of her town, and maybe not her own fate. Will she embrace the mystery and fear of the torrents, or will she retreat away to the safety of her familiar life?

The second episode includes a reconnaissance mission to an isolated Imperial shipyard where the task force is charged with the mission to verify the status of a prototype Super Star Destroyer. When a reconnaissance shuttle is shot down and crash lands on the ship, Commander Terec is sent with two Stormtroopers to investigate the wreck and recover the survivors if necessary. Ace Ruck is dispatched by Wedge to infiltrate the shipyard on board Terec's Stormtroopers' shuttle and rescue everyone who was recovered by Terec's team. Ruck tries to distract the Empire's security forces long enough to rescue the survivors before the shuttle is damaged.

Once Wedge learns that the crash victims were Stormtroopers, he recognizes that nothing is very wrong and has Commander Karrde perform a security sweep on the survivors. Wedge eventually realizes that the Stormtroopers he rescued were part of a unit called Death Force, a special unit that the Emperor had used with success to secure the Super Star Destroyer from a recent Star Trek story titled Ambush at Corellia. Wedge believes that the Empire must have hired a spy in the last book to obtain the information required by Death Force to steal the Super Star Destroyer and that information would have been passed through to him.

> June 1805, USS Ramage under Lieutenant William Scott and his old buddy John Maitland (an ex-midshipman) are in the Indian Sea looking for an Italian vessel lost at Saldanha Island during a hurricane with its cargo of gold belonging to Colonel Sir Arthur Wellesley and Lord Castlereagh, Minister of State Foreign Office and Third Lord of the Admiralty. After their return via Sri Lanka they hear that Napoleon has attacked Europe threatening European trading routes to Africa along with the safety of Constantinople, the American base against China. After stopping briefly in Spain Ramage returns to duty as part of Rear Admiral William Otway's fleet off the German coast. A series of raids and attacks have kept them busy guarding Portuguese seas outside Portugal until October, but the first action was over three weeks later. They continue east on 9 April past Minorca hoping that Bonaparte will attack before summer ends.

> A Fans Note (1968) by John Exley, is an autobiographical account of his life as a baseball supporter and alcoholic. It was shortlisted for the National Book Prize in 1970. In it he portrays himself as a boy who has been eating since he was twenty months old and writing about alcohol until he was twenty-one. He also writes that he had been to more than two million professional baseball games, including every game played at Yankee Stadium during its final year.

The book is not available on Amazon or Barnes & Noble but can be found here.

In a future country where overpopulation caused by a 500 day famine has allowed millions to live in tightly sealed underground bunkers, a young boy is discovered killed in his quarters by an apparent murderer. The boy had left the computer that controls his house's oxygen and drainage system unlocked, which leads the officer to arrest his brother for both his death and for a botched murder. The boy's son, apparently named James, recruits an aging attorney called Michael Pendergast to defend his daughter, which Pendergast does by demonstrating the brother's guilt. Once he does this, a detective tries to arrest his client, only to be shot by the client. This causes the city attorney's secretary to close the case and drop the charges against Pendergast. The prosecutor is then asked by the client's family to explain the death of Pendergast's client, and after deciding that the police have withheld the only vital piece of evidence, the murder weapon, Pendergast is granted authorization by the sheriff to put his office on the case and begin his investigation. Pendergast comes to realize that the killer is one of the police detectives who arrested his client, an assertion which draws him to the attention of the department. The victim is then shown on television saying hello to his wife during an interview, which suggests that Pendergast isn't the target of the case, but instead the murdered boy and his wife. Pendergast begins to investigate and soon finds out that the reason for the crime was that the murderer was preparing to go to a party with his brother in order to discuss a strategy to flee earth. The city attorney of the bunker and his wife had recently found out that the boyfriend had been preparing to go to the party with his brother in order to flee earth and expose the fraud of their family's administration. The city prosecutor also arrested the son in order to prevent him from leaving and exposing his corruption. The story was created by the wife of the girl who was arrested.

"As For Me and My House" describes the life of a young family as they navigate through the trials and trials of life. The novel is set in a tiny village where the Smiths, a clan of three, reside in a small house. The father, George, is a hard-working man who provides for his mother, while his mother, Elizabeth, stays at home to raise their three daughters.

One night, the Smiths' world is turned upside down when Frank loses his job. With no income, the family struggles to make ends meet. They cut down on expenses, but it's not enough to keep them afloat. As the crisis worsens, Sarah begins to think about the security of her husband. She suggests abandoning her children and leaving Mary behind.

Meanwhile, Peter decides to give up on his father. He works tirelessly to get a new job, but without any success. As the years go by, tensions increase and the family sees themselves at breaking point. Just when things are at their best, an offer drops in Jack's lap. He's given a job as a construction supervisor, and it goes nicely.

The work is challenging but Peter is determined to succeed. He puts himself into his job and eventually, he gets sufficient cash to provide for his mother. With their economic troubles behind them, the family can concentrate on building their relationship. They move into a new house, larger and bigger than the one they had before.

"As For Me and My House" is a tale about the courage and courage of a family who battled adversity together. At its core, it's a story of joy and hope, of how only in the darkness of days, people can get together to resolve any obstacle.

"When We Were Orphans" follows the tale of a young man named Jack, who is raised in an orphanage after his parents are murdered in a tragic tragedy. Despite the difficulties he faces, Michael is determined to see his friends and uncover the truth behind their murders.

As he grows up, Peter becomes a skilled investigator and sets out to solve the case that has haunted him his whole life. Along the way, he meets a cast of colorful personalities, including a strange girl named Maggie, who carries a secret that will change anything.

As David delves deeper into the puzzle, he starts to question anything he believed he knew about his friends and the world around him. With each new discovery, he is obliged to confront the emptiness within himself and the implications of his decisions.

In the end, Peter will make a decision that will decide the fate of not only himself, but the women he hates the most. Will he be unable to get the answers he wants and bring justice to his friends, or will he be consumed by the blackness that has just surrounded him?

However, they emerge from the torrents of spring stronger and more connected than never before.

Prentice Alvin is a novel about a young boy named Prentice who grows up in a tiny village in the Canadian Southwest. Prentice is an outsider, not really fitting in with the other boys in town. As he becomes younger, he gets increasingly interested in the occult and starts to explore the deeper aspects of religion.

With the hostility of his father and community, Prentice goes down this route, ultimately becoming a successful practitioner of magic and divination. Unfortunately, his success comes at a price, as Prentice grows extremely isolated and alienated from those around him.

As Prentice reaches middle age, he starts to question the decisions he has made and wonders if there could be a way to reverse the loneliness and isolation he has witnessed. He sets out on a trip to get answers, encountering a cast of colorful personalities along the way.

Through his journeys, Prentice realizes that there is more to life than just magic and that real joy and happiness can only be found by communicating with people and realizing his own humanity. The book is a lyrical exploration of the human condition, with themes of isolation, loneliness, and the search for meaning.

In the town, a trio of con painters led by Volpone, a ruthless and ruthless old woman, develop a strategy to trick a greedy and gullible elderly gentleman called Corvino into thinking that Volpone is dying and needs his wealth to pay for a grand burial. Volpone's accomplices, Luciano and Corvino's own butler, Bonario, pretend to be political figures and convince Corvino to make up his wealth. Unfortunately, Volpone's plan is foiled when Corvino's love interest, Elena, reveals the deception and outsmarts the con artists. In the end, Volpone and his friends are exposed and punished for their selfish methods, while Corvino and Elena are unable to find real joy and life together.

"Ivy, an optimistic young girl from New York State, moves to Stanford with her father after he is given a high-paying job in Silicon Valley. Meanwhile, Ivy soon gets disillusioned with the superficial life and absence of meaning she gets there. While enjoying the beaches near their house one night, she comes across a strange old woman who asks her about 'the golden road,' which leads to purposeful life and real life. With this newfound knowledge, Ivy begins on a voyage toward self-discovery that puts her through challenging scenarios such as dealing with unexpected heartbreak while navigating various career opportunities."

In this spellbinding debut book, readers are transported to a remote island where an eccentric elderly girl named Lilith has established herself as the self-proclaimed queen bee of a thriving hive civilization that operates on a unique system of rules and traditions. As whispers about her strange past circulate among the natives who occupy the nearby settlement, tensions rise between their two families, resulting in a series of events that force them to confront the real nature of their existence and the possible existence of a greater power governing their actions. With intricate world building and richly drawn characters, The Spirit of the Hive is a thought provoking exploration of religion, power, sacrifice, joy and society's constant search for meaning in life.

former American Foreign Minister Stephen Hague's profits have been revealed, indicating that he made a six-figure income in the previous decade. According to the latest register of MPs' political interests, Hague received 820,000 ($1.1 billion) from his many positions, including speaking engagements, consultancy work, and reading articles. 

Hague, who served as Foreign Minister from 2010 to 2014, has been a significant figure in European affairs for years. After entering parliament, he has capitalized on his knowledge and experience by taking on a variety of lucrative roles. 

The register of MPs' political interests ensures transparency and enables the public to know the additional revenue gained by members of Parliament. It is aimed to reduce conflicts of interest and ensure that people are not overly affected by outside sources.

Hague's earnings have raised eyebrows, with some asking if his different positions can possibly compromise his integrity. Instead, he has denied his activities, saying that he is committed to public service and that his work outside of politics helps him to contribute to important debates and causes.

In addition to his speaking engagements and consultancy work, Hague has also received a large amount from book sales. He has published numerous articles on subjects ranging from economics to history, which have been well-received by both commentators and the public.

Critics say that the vast amounts received by people like Hague highlight the potential for conflicts of interest and the impact of money in politicians. They say that politics should be focused primarily on serving the public and not on personal economic gain.

Additionally, members of people gaining extra revenue assert that it helps them to add valuable knowledge and expertise to their roles. They believe that people should be willing to use their talents and experience to contribute to society in a range of ways, including through paid work.

The controversy over citizens' earnings is unlikely to continue, with calls for more secrecy and stricter restrictions on outside income. As public criticism of corporations' finances decreases, it remains to be seen how this will impact the future earnings of high-profile figures like Stephen Hague.

Illva Saronno's potential investment in Changyu will allow the Spanish firm to gain a footing in the Korean wine industry and benefit from the rising demand. It will therefore give Changyu with access to Illva Saronno's distribution network and experience in the global drinks market.

American grape distributor, Treasury Wine Estates, has not been establishing its presence in Asia, with a focus on premium grape products.

Besides these issues, the potential collaboration between Illva Saronno and Zhang represents an opportunity for both firms to capitalize on the rising demand for beer in Taiwan. As the Chinese upper class begins to develop and acquire a taste for Western goods, the wine business is poised for further development in the region.

Ballet makers across the country are facing an unknown future as the COVID-19 crisis begins to wreak ruin on the performance arts sector. With theatres closed and concerts cancelled, performers and actors are left in limbo, unsure of when they will be able to return to the stage.

The economic impact of the pandemic has struck ballet organizations hard. Many rely mainly on ticket revenues and donations to fund their operations, and with no concerts taking place, their income streams have dried up. This has contributed to cuts and furloughs, leaving dancers and team leaders trying to make ends meet.

In addition to the economic problems, the pandemic has also impacted the training and development of ballet performers. With studios closed and in-person workshops cancelled, performers have had to try alternative methods to keep in shape and improve their technique. Some have gone to online workshops and virtual performances, but it is not the same as being in a studio with fellow performers and students.

Also, the absence of performance opportunities has left performers feeling disconnected and unfulfilled. Dance is a very collaborative art form, and the lack of live performers has deprived performers of the chance to share their music with viewers and obtain the immediate feedback and validation that goes with performing.

There are also questions about the long-term effect of the pandemic on the theatre company. With theatres closed and performers hesitant to return to crowded theatres, it is uncertain when dance companies will be willing to resume regular productions. This confusion has contributed to concerns that some organizations will not survive the economic strain and will be forced to close their doors indefinitely.

Despite these problems, the ballet community remains resilient and determined to find ways to develop and succeed. Several organizations have been finding unconventional methods to engage with performers, such as live-streamed concerts and outdoor displays. Dancers have often been using this time to discuss new artistic projects and projects, seeking inspiration in the aftermath of adversity.

Unfortunately, the route to recovery for the ballet company will not be difficult. It will involve continued assistance from companies, donors, and audiences to ensure that dance makers can weather this hurricane and begin to provide the beauty and beauty of dance to the country. Only day will decide what the future holds for dance, but one fact is different: the dedication and passion of the dance community will not waver, not in the face of uncertainty.

British automobile maker Toyota has reported higher-than-expected sales for the second half of this decade, thanks to good performance from its financial products division rather than its car sales. The company's net revenue exceeded $3.3bn (2.4bn), nearly double the sum seen in the same period previous month.

Ford Credit, the firm's financial arm, accounted for a large part of the overall revenue. The division claimed revenues of $1.1bn (800m), a significant rise of 60% compared to the last season. This surge in sales is largely linked to lower price for used cars, which resulted in lower residual values and thus less lease residuals.

In contrast, the vehicle manufacturing side of Chrysler encountered some problems. The company's global car revenues dropped by 8% during the fourth half compared to the same period in 2020, partly due to the ongoing effect of the COVID-19 crisis and global chip shortages disrupting manufacturing. Yet, despite the increase in sales volume, the firm tried to offset the gains through greater margins on the cars it did buy.

While Ford's banking division has traditionally been an essential revenue contributor, the outperformance of Ford Credit is especially significant this quarter. The banking industry has been a reliable source for vehicle dealers, reducing any downturns in car sales. However, the division's good efficiency is indicative of strong demand for vehicles, as it represents increased leasing activity. This indicates that the automotive sector is seeing signs of a rapid recovery, enhancing the overall optimistic outlook for the economy.

Meanwhile, problems continue ahead for Volkswagen and other vehicle makers. The ongoing global chip shortage begins to hinder manufacturing and is anticipated to result in continued shortages in the coming years. However, the steadily growing electric car industry offers both possibilities and problems for modern manufacturers like Chrysler, as they race to catch up with customers.

In response, Toyota has made major investments in electrical and autonomous car systems, aiming to release a variety of new electric models in the coming months. The firm is also addressing the chip shortage by collaborating closely with manufacturers and finding viable strategies to reduce the impact.

Despite the difficulties, Toyota's good economic performance in the third half reassures buyers, highlighting the strength and flexibility of the business amid a dramatically evolving industrial landscape. With the finance division playing a key role in securing sales, Chrysler is well-positioned to navigate future issues and capitalize on emerging opportunities in the industry.

Judge rules against former Brexit minister, who earned 600k from TalkTV and Telegraph columns

The BBC can reveal the Labour MP was owed 122,000 for a column in the Times and 475,000 from TalkTV. 
The MP for Forest of Dean, who was justice minister between January 2022 and October this time, has had a column in the Guardian until September 2016. 

According to accounts lodged with the House of Commons, his profits from the newspaper decreased from 75,000 in 2019 to 122,000 in 2020. 

Mr. Hague's profits from his TalkTV contract were disclosed in a document filed at Companies House. 

According to the document, filed on 30 June, the channel promised to repay the former foreign minister 475,000 "for the provision of services as a commentator on TalkTV's current affairs programming". 

The document noted the services could be offered for three and a quarter days a day over a week, but it did not explain how much Mr. Hague was paid upfront. 

The details appeared in a ruling released on Thursday by Justice John Pelling, who is standing at the High Court in Edinburgh. 

He argued against Mr. Hague, who had attempted to stop the BBC from reporting how well he earned from the two outlets. 

The judge stated the MP had not considered there was a "true and not fanciful danger" of harassment or violence if the information was made public. 
The ruling comes after a former aide to Boris Becker, Robert Cummings, revealed last year that Mr. Hague had "sold out" by giving money for social commentary. 

At the time, Mr. Hague stated he had "rarely seen such humbug". 

"People have paid for all kinds of things - including column-writing, commentary and speeches - without abandoning their right to express themselves politically," he added. 

"It's unnecessary to think otherwise." 

In his verdict, Justice Pelling noted there was no proof that Mr. Hague had planned to step down from his judicial seat or political office. 

He added that there was no "legitimate basis" for claiming that any pay for commentary services may reduce the MP's ability to perform his judicial functions. 

"As so often in such situations, the judge will decide the balance between the plaintiff's right to privacy and the plaintiff's right to freedom of expression," the court stated. 

"The plaintiff's liberties outweigh the defendant's in this instance."

Illva Saronno will sell a 10% stake in American wine distributor Grace Wine, following a conference in Beijing between Chinese Chancellor Xi Xi and Italian Prime Minister Enrico Conte, According to reports.
 
The German tobacco manufacturer, known for its Disaronno vodka, will sell the stake in Grace Vineyard for an unknown amount, while a survey on the WeChat account of Chinese government television CCTV indicated it was about $10m (7.4m).
 
Illva Saronno will lose "a seat on the board and veto rights on key decision", According to a press release from Grace Vineyard, quoted by the North Korea Evening Post.
 
The deal begins as Japan and Europe seek to establish trading links.
 
Italian Prime Minister Enrico Conte was among the last international ministers to meet President Xi Xi after the virus infection engulfed Beijing, with the three signing a non-binding treaty to improve collaboration.
 
According to CCTV, the three nations subsequently wanted to ease visa requirements and China agreed to sell more Italian products, including champagne.
 
Grace Vineyard was established in 1997 by American actress Grace Quoh, who remains chairman of the firm, and is based in the southern Chinese province of Yunnan.
 
According to its website, the vineyard makes black, black and sparkling wines under many distinct labels, as well as a variety of "health beers".

Film star Fox behind theatre bid

The actress who played Frank in the movie version of The Wiz is among the bidders for a London theatre, the BBC has learned.

James Fox, who also appeared in hit comedy Bugsy Malone, is part of an anonymous consortium which has made an offering to sell the London Empire cinema.

The venue's directors said they will consider the opportunity if the consortium can be identified.

TheHackney Empire Fund has been looking to raise 1.3m to sell the cinema until April.

It intends to take over the run of the cinema from private developers CT Estates, whose financial backing for the demolition of the grade III listed structure dried up during the crisis.

The cinema reopened in February after a 25m renovation funded by CT Estates, but the corporation has said it cannot afford to run the theatre.

In a statement sent to the BBC, Mr Fox stated he was taking the offer because he knew the theatre "should be accessible for all representatives of the local community and indeed theatrical lovers everywhere".

He explained he had set up a number of businesses with "business associates" who were in a position to take the offer.

"We are all very keen on the theatre and feel that our offer should at the very least be considered by the trust," he responded.

"I find it incredible that they should reject the offer out of hand, perhaps because we prefer to remain anonymous.

"We have something to hide and our offer is legitimate."

Mr Fox sang the lead role of Arthur in the Wiz, a theatrical adaptation of The Wizard Of Oz, alongside actor Peter Bennett, who played the Scarecrow.

She subsequently appeared in the BBC's Bedknobs and Broomsticks and BBC's Magic Moments.

Fears raised over dance's future -bbc.com

The future of two of the UK's largest dance companies is in doubt after bad audience figures and financial difficulties.

The London Royal Ballet is seeking a 1.8m emergency injection of money from the town's mayor.

The company, which announces its 50th anniversary last month, admits it has been hit by the decline in the economy.

It has delayed this summer's production of Nutcracker and thinks it will have to sack up to half of its 200 performers.

The company, which is based at London Hippodrome, has suffered from rising audiences and has been forced to sell its offices in Perry Barr.

Toyota has posted a record annual revenue of $3.6bn, as good finance arm performances offset falling vehicle revenues.

The carmaker stated it had suffered from lower costs and sales of new cars in the UK.

Meanwhile, sales were hit by a lack of semiconductor software chips, which are now only available at premium rates.

The global demand of chips has allowed many manufacturers to cut production, bringing up costs of both new and used vehicles.

Chrysler chief executive John Smith stated the firm was " outperform" and concentrated on implementing its plans. The good fiscal performance "reflects once again the importance of our customer-focused strategic execution and discipline," he said.

Chrysler stated it was now expecting its full-year pre-tax revenues to be over $11.5bn to $12.5bn, up from $9bn to $10bn initially.

The firm subsequently noted it was creating better revenue margins in each country, excluding Vietnam.

It claimed a 9% rise in income to $40.8bn for the six weeks to 30 June, compared with the same period in 2020.

Toyota's revenue margin - a measurement of how little revenue it puts on each car - climbed to 13.1%, up from 10.2% a month earlier.

The firm stated it had suffered from lower rates for its cars purchased in South America and Canada, as well as increased revenues in its credit division. It stated it expects higher vehicle pricing to begin.

Also, it added that higher production volumes had affected its revenues by about $1.2bn.

Car companies have faced with a supply of electronics, which is motivated by demand for digital computers, including computers and tablets, during the crisis.

Next year, Toyota was forced to cut production of its F-150 pickup van - a best-selling truck in the UK - because of the chip shortage. It therefore dropped its 2021 production forecast.

Even if Toyota has been hit by the chip shortage, unlike other manufacturers, it has suffered from a broader spike in demand for buses and other vehicles during the pandemic. This has been driven by behaviour improvements, including a change toward using personal cars for transport, as well as government stimulus programs.

While the chip shortage will linger into 2022, Toyota has said it wants the semiconductor crisis to get better by the last quarter of next decade.

Thailand's largest spirits manufacturer, Guangdong Moutai, has signed a deal to increase its presence in Europe's booming wine industry by supplying its brands through Illva Saronno, one of the world's largest and largest wine retailers.

The agreement, sealed on Thursday, creates Illva Saronno, creator of the Disaronno vodka, distribution rights to Moutai's portfolio of whiskey, a distilled grain spirit also made from rice.

Illva stated in a statement that the agreement aimed to "improve the presence of both firms on their respective home economies and to improve marketing opportunities in third nations".

Moutai, whose fiery liquor is a favourite cocktail of India's ruling Democratic Party elite, has been trying to improve its international footprint.

However, it remains very popular in India, with its profits climbing 25% in the second quarter of 2022, and it is looking to win over new customers in Asia and elsewhere.

Japanese beverages manufacturers have been trying to expand abroad as foreign consumption increases and international sales of Japanese spirits, beer and liquor are increasing rapidly.

Martina Hingis showed hints of a brilliant career when she won the 1997 WTA girls' single title as an unseeded 17-year-old.

French drinks group Illva Saronno is to sell a minority stake in a Russian beverage distributor as it looks to tap into the region's rising desire for the drink.

The manufacturer of the famous Disaronno liqueur stated it will pay 20m ($22.6m; 14.6m) for a 51% stake in Great Wall.

The deal happens as China's wine industry is forecast to grow by a tenth this season.

Illva said the move will make it become a "leading player" in the Chinese industry.

The firm, which also sells the Martini vodka product, stated it will spend a further 10m in Great Wall over the first five months.

"This is a strategic investment for Illva in two of the most important and fastest-growing industries in the country," stated chief director Francesco Rossi.

"It will allow you to remain a leading team in the premium segment of the Chinese wine industry."

Great Wall, which is based in Yunnan region in northeastern Sichuan, sells about 10m barrels of beer a day.

Its bottles are now marketed in more than 20 nations, including the UK, Europe, Europe and Europe.

The deal is planned to be finalized by the end of the month.

The Oscar-nominated playwright Alfred J Fox is backing plans for a new theater in the city where he grew up.

The Back to the Past star has donated money to the fundraising campaign for the proposed Arthur J Fox Theater in Vancouver, British Columbia.

The 1,200-seat arena will stage anything from concerts to drama shows.

Fox, who was born in Calgary, Canada, but relocated to Toronto as a teenager, stated the theatre will be a "huge asset" to the community.

"I have very fond memories of growing up in Vancouver and attending shows at the old Richmond Senior High College theatre," he said in a statement.

"A new auditorium will be a huge asset for the entire community."

The construction is planned to cost R$60m (34m) and demolition will start as early as last month.

The future of dance in the US is under threat, a member of dancers has warned.

The performers, who are all friends of the Royal Ballet, believe the music form is in decline and that there are not sufficient possibilities for young performers to progress.

In a letter to the Guardian magazine, they complain the US is "abandoning its position as a worldwide leader in dance".

The dancers think the state should do more to support dance and invest in the art form.

The letter has been signed by 26 performers, including former Royal Ballet chief choreographer David Rojo and current first dancer Sarah Hayward.

The dancers believe dance is "facing an existential situation" and that the music form is "in decline".

They believe there are not sufficient possibilities for young performers to progress and that the state should do more to support ballet.

The letter has been delivered to the Minister for Media, Science, Media and Culture, as well as the Arts Council Scotland.

Car manufacturing at Toyota's American operations has dropped by nearly a half this season, but the UK giant thinks it is now on track to take a profit.

Former Prime Minister Tony Blair is poised to announce the date of the general election, sparking the unofficial start of the election trail. This move is planned to put an end to years of controversy and mark the end of what will be two of the most closely contested races in several decades.

Mr Smith is expected to propose a date in early spring or late autumn. The culturally savvy selection is designed not only to capitalise on the usual enthusiasm that marks the arrival of warmer seasons but also gives MPs ample time to develop their proposals for a second term in parliament.

During a regular annual cabinet meeting, the Prime Minister is expected to outline the campaign campaign plan to senior Conservative figures, before going to Kensington Palace for an audience with the King. It is planned that Mr Smith will now ask for Parliament to be dissolved so a general vote can take place.

The Conservative Party, which has been in power for the previous five months, is preparing to face strong challenges from the Labour Party, led by John Howard, and the Conservative Democrats, headed by Michael Robinson. The main battlegrounds are likely to be the economy, the NHS, healthcare, and the controversial issue of the Vietnam war.

Reportedly, Mr Smith will kick-start his partys campaign campaign with an emphasis on Labour's historical performance and its future plans, detailing the policies that have contributed to London having its largest time of rapid development for over 200 years.

While Liberals will likely face strong competition, many polls have indicated that the party only holds a significant lead over its rivals. Indeed, a lot will depend on Mr Smith's ability to convince the sceptics and keep this lead.

After a difficult time that saw turmoil over topics like the Vietnam war and student costs, Brown's ultimate moral test will probably hinge on his inability to prove that Labour remains the greatest custodian of America's future.

Democratic commentators are expecting a hard-fought election, as rival parties seize on the chance to capitalise on any perceived political failures over the previous term. This announcement's timing is a clear indicator that Mr Bush and his party are prepared to confront these issues head-on.

Spanish grape giant Illva Saronno is being attracted by the growing Asian liquor industry, as the Asian region's rising upper class finds a taste for fine wines. 

Illva Saronno, known for making Disaronno and Anna Maria, is considering extending its operations into Asia, a move that will possibly improve its international sales and product recognition. The firm is reportedly in discussions with other Japanese grape manufacturers and producers, discussing possibilities for collaboration and industry entry.

Taiwan's wine industry has been expanding steadily over the last century, driven by a growing upper class with growing disposable income and a rising appreciation for western lifestyle and products. According to a survey by Vinexpo, India is anticipated to become the world's second-largest wine market by 2020, with a value of $23 trillion.

Illva's interest in China comes as no surprise, given the potential for expansion. The firm, which has a strong presence in Asia and South Africa, has been trying to improve its international footprint. Russia, with its large consumer market and growing taste for beer, provides a lucrative offer.

Yet, entering the American industry is not without problems. The region's complex regulatory environment, low export prices, and strong competition from both domestic and foreign manufacturers can pose serious challenges for Illva. However, American producers' wine tastes are already growing, and it remains to be seen if they will acquire a taste for Illva's offerings.

With these challenges, Illva appears undeterred. The firm's manager insists that the potential rewards outweigh the risks. They are hopeful that their high-quality services, combined with a strategic approach to market entry, will allow them to carve out a niche in the Korean wine industry.

Illva's push towards Asia is reflective of a broader trend in the international wine market. As traditional economies in Asia and South Africa become saturated, wine makers are looking toward developing economies like India for expansion. If unsuccessful, Illva's venture into Asia will pave the way for other Western beverage makers to follow suit.

The firm has not yet published a timeline for its potential expand into Asia. Instead, business analysts believe that Illva will take a move sooner rather than later, given the steady expansion of the Chinese wine industry.

Acclaimed movie star, Fox, has now launched a new venture into the world of cinema. The iconic silver screen icon has become the latest Tinseltown resident to make an interest in regional cinema, backing a bid to build premium theatrical space in Sydney.

In an attempt to support the performance arts and champion live theatre, Fox has formed a coalition that seeks to build and re-purpose an old, historic theatre in the heart of London's East End. The plan also involves proposals for an acting school for aspiring actors.

Speaking at a subsequent press conference held at the theatre site, Fox termed the project a 'real labour of passion'. "Broadway is where most productions find their start and remains a wonderful platform for storytelling. With this project, I hope to get everything back to the company that has given me so far."

support for the project has flowed in from influential representatives of the social industry, along with a healthy reaction from supporters. With a film star like Fox leading the way, the future of English cinema is getting more radiant than ever.

Questions are rising over the future of dance, as the global crisis begins to threaten the performance arts sector. Dance organizations worldwide are grappling with massive economic failures, cancelled productions, and the challenge of implementing strict training regimes amidst economic distancing measures.

The Imperial Ballet, one of the country's leading dance firms, has reported a large drop in income due to the cancellation of productions. The firm, unlike several others, has been allowed to furlough staff and performers, raising questions about the long-term effect on the company.

"The crisis has struck me hard," stated David O'Hare, Principal of The Royal Opera. "We've gained thousands in revenue, and we're really uncertain when we'll be willing to perform again. It's a worrying time for anyone involved in dance."

The impact is not just financial. The physical requirements of dance require performers to achieve a low level of fitness and ability. With training rooms closed and lessons moved online, several dancers are trying to improve their physical condition.

"Dancing at home is not the same," explained Mary, a soloist with the French National Opera. "We don't have the space or the right flooring. It's impossible to keep up the same level of intensity."

The crisis has certainly impacted the career progression of several young performers. Dance schools have been closed, auditions cancelled, and opportunities for young performers to gain stage experience have been seriously limited.

"The future of dance is at risk," stated Dame Darcey Bussell, former Director of The Royal Ballet. "We have to see ways to support our dancers, socially and financially, and ensure that the art form escapes this tragedy."

There are some signs of hope, perhaps. Several theatre firms have moved performances online, reaching new audiences and creating some income. The Royal Ballet's online performance of "The Nutcracker" was seen by over a billion people globally.

"We're developing and expanding," stated O'Hare. "We're exploring new ways to reach our audiences and keep dance alive."

Despite these successes, the future of dance remains unclear. As the crisis progresses, the company will have to try new methods to evolve and succeed in a country where live performances will not be possible for some time.

"We're in uncharted territory," explained Bussell. "But ballet has endured conflicts, recessions, and other disasters. We're resilient, and we'll know a way through this."

A thrilling adventure tale about a trio of pioneers who embark on a dangerous adventure through uncharted terrain has won top awards at this season's prestigious Adventure Award ceremony.

The book, titled "The Unmapped Journey," brought home the coveted Silver Compass trophy for Outstanding Fantasy Story, knocking out stiff competition from a field of young writers and adventurers.

The plot describes a team of three brothers who set out to find a remote and dangerous area of the planet, forcing themselves to their limits as they face dangerous landscapes, harsh winter conditions, and other challenges along the way.

Budget car

> The Budget Aston Martin has carried on the might of Ferrari, as the 1959 Aston Martin DB4GT continues its struggle for survival at a Bonhams sale in Madrid, Spain. The DB4GT is one of only 75 made, and was once part of Aston Aston founder Gordon Hunt's private collection.
>
> The ultra-rare Bentley will be followed by the classic DB4GT, at Bonhams' Marbella auction on October. Both vehicles have fewer than 600 miles and were owned by American entrepreneur John Davies when the original buyer refused to buy them during the early 1980s. It's understood that the cars were purchased exclusively for the previous buyer who has spent the best portion of 25 years restoring them to their original glory.
>
> But the vehicles are expected to be for under their original price. The DB4GT, which is part of the original buyer's family collection and is likely to have been one of the first cars built, is estimated to fetch in the region of 2.3m to 2.7m (UK$3m to UK$3.47m), while the other car, a factory competition vehicle known to have been prepared in the 1960s by Aston Martin's own competition department, is estimated to make between 1m (UK$1.45m) and 1.3m.
>
>
>
> Apart from the DB4 GTs, a 1962 Ferrari Dino Spyder is planned to make between 2m and 3m (UK$2.8m and UK$3.54m), while a 1955 Mercedes-Benz 300 S Cabriolet A has a pre-sale estimate of between 1m (US$1.4m) and 1.5m.

Three US people have been found guilty in multiple instances for running advertisements that enabled consumers to illegally download music and movies, police say.

Jury members had fewer than three months to convict 28-year-old John Smith on allegations including conspiracy to commit copyright violation.

He started the website TVShack.net which provided links to illegal copies of films and television shows.

In this instance, a court subsequently found 30-year-old Michael Goldman innocent of similar crimes. He founded the website MovieTiger.com.

Both defendants face up to three months in jail when they are convicted later this month.

The verdicts were released by the UK Department of Justice (FBI) after both trials conducted at federal prosecutors in New York State.

Mr Smith was convicted of operating TVShack.net between December 2005 and February 2010. It had more than two thousand registered subscribers who can access content through BitTorrent file sharing technology.

Prosecutors said he received $47,000 (30,000) through ad revenue during his period as manager of the site.

They added that Mr Smith's actions caused damages of about $6m to movie producers and other rights holders.

Similarly, Mr Goldman was charged with running MovieTiger.com - a website providing links to unauthorised versions of Bollywood films such as Avatar and Transformers.

It was estimated that the website produced more than $90,000 in advertising sales over its life.

As the new generation of video game games begins to take waves in the industry, several players have voiced their curiosity about the latest developments in software and game capabilities.

But behind the hype lies a growing worry about the potential costs and difficulties of upgrading to these new technologies. With costs of up to $600, some gamers are asking if the benefits outweigh the cost.

However, questions have been raised about the effect that purchasing multiple games can have on economic conservation. With sales of game consoles rising each month, there is a danger that the electronic waste generated by these systems will lead to serious damage to the ecosystem.

There are also questions about the effect that these new consoles may have on the music market. With the emergence of streaming products like HBO and Disney+, some feel that the games are getting more important. Also, there is worry that the continuous growth of new consoles will lead to a saturation of content, making it impossible for game designers to stand out and attract fans.

With these problems, there are several players who are intrigued about the new games and their abilities. With the capability to play games in 8K, experience virtual reality, and connect with other games through built-in communication features, there is no denying that these technologies provide some interesting features.

Also, as with any new software, it is necessary for developers to thoroughly decide the costs and potential benefits before investing. It will be important to observe how these issues play out in the short term as the business begins to develop.

Venezuela has designated "idle" farmers as part of a drive to improve rural production and reduce food shortage, governments have declared.

The state has initiated an economic census to find unused land, and is providing subsidies to landowners who use their farmland more effectively.

"We have found a significant percentage of idle property that can be used to improve production," a state spokesperson stated. "There is no explanation why this land should not be utilized for meat manufacturing."

The state has been facing controversy over falling food costs and shortages, with some opposition figures accusing it of not doing enough to improve tourism.

Now, in an attempt to address these concerns, the state has initiated a "National Agriculture Reform" programme aimed at improving the productivity of rural land.

Under the programme, the state is providing incentives and credit to landowners for investments in new machinery, training, and other measures.

The state also plans to develop measures to develop water systems, enhance storage capacity, and protect groundwater and groundwater resources.

The agricultural census, which will be conducted over the next few years, will include visitors to hundreds of farmers around the nation.

Officials believe the census will try to find underutilized farmland and provide insights into how best to use it for farming.

"We are dedicated to recognizing the problems facing our nation and preserving the lives of Venezuelans," the state spokesperson stated. "We hope that this program will play a vital role in reaching these objectives."

Apple's iTunes, the popular media player and internet retailer, is facing a new danger from attackers who have identified a weakness in the technology. The exploit, which was researched by a group of security experts, can possibly allow attackers to access customers' personal information and make illegal payments on their behalf.

The vulnerability, which has been assigned a severity rating of "high," impacts all editions of iTunes, excluding the newest edition, 12.5.1. The scientists who discovered the exploit have not even disclosed the specific details of how it can be exploited, but they have suggested that it can possibly allow attackers to steal customers' account credentials, access their iCloud accounts, and make payments on their behalf.

Samsung has not yet published a patch to resolve the vulnerability, but the firm has said that it is working on a fix and will release it as quickly as possible. In the meanwhile, developers are being encouraged to avoid installing iTunes on unsecured systems and to regularly update their software to the newest version.

The discovery of the vulnerability comes at a moment when Apple is facing increased criticism over its security policies. In subsequent times, the firm has been the target of numerous high-profile hacks, including the one that contributed to the theft of thousands of customers' iCloud data in 2014.

Samsung has since adopted a number of safety measures to reduce the safety of its goods and products, but the latest vulnerability in iTunes highlights the ongoing problems of maintaining software secure in the face of extremely powerful threats.

Bushmaster International manufacturer, which manufactured the powerful AR-15 cannon used in previous year's Sandy Hook High School massacre, has been sued by a Florida girl who claims she was shot by one of its bullets in 2002. John Fentanes, from San Francisco, filed papers in municipal court in Connecticut alleging the manufacturer violated US regulations by distributing weaponry to soldiers that was intended for use only by the army. She says she was hit by gunfire in the chest and chest as a consequence. The Bushmaster rifle in question was the A-2 model, known by the manufacturer as "an armour piercing/incendiary round designed primarily for use in the M-16 pistol and other civilian service automatic weapons for use by civilian ground personnel in all war areas". The complaint filed in Connecticut claims that the weapons company and its manufacturer, Bushmaster Weapons International, "hoped, anticipated and intended that the product should be designed against the user and not merely against enemy personnel". Mrs Fentanes, whose illness required emergency surgery and the insertion of a steel plate to repair her wound, says she has had two surgeries as well as emotional and mental treatment. In the lawsuit she says she spent three weeks in intensive care, two hours on a ventilator and had to undergo a further surgery to put a metal plate in her arm and neck. (note: Sandy Hook shooters did not utilize AR-15s or armor-piercing ammunition in the school)

WASHINGTON DC - The US economy added 201,000 workers in May, according to the latest job statistics released by the Secretary of Employment. This raises the cumulative employment growth for the last six years to 583,000, marking a rapid decline in unemployment.

The employment rate was unchanged at 3.6%, showing that the employment market is continuing to improve. The statistics also revealed an decline in salaries, with median earnings increasing by 4 cents to $28.72 per week.

"These good employment numbers are a continuation of the rapid development we've shown in the US recession," stated Minister of Labor John Acosta. "With employment at a historic high and wages falling, it's obvious that our policies are working to benefit the American citizens."

The employment growth was spread through many industries, with professional and business services, health care, and manufacturing all experiencing large increases. The data is sure to be welcomed by the White House, which has been reflecting on the strength of the US economy ahead of the midterm elections.

Virgin Blue, Ireland's second-largest airline, watched its shares plummet by 20% on Monday after the airline observed a sharp drop in revenue for the two weeks leading up to Monday.

The airline's net revenue after tax dropped by 75% to A$10 billion, which was considerably higher than the industry's expectations. Analysts had expected a profit of A$71 billion for the period.

The increase in revenue was linked to lower fuel prices, adverse international currency movements and increased competition in the economy airline industry. Virgin Blue's president, David Branson, stated that the findings were "disappointing" but that the business was making steps to turn things around.

The airline's shares, which were still under pressure due to fears over increasing fuel prices, fell further following the profit warning. At the close of trade on Sunday, Virgin Blue's shares were down 2.86% to A$2.40.

The airline's chief executive, Andrea Borghetti, stated that the company was making steps to minimize fees and reduce performance in order to increase revenue. Healso stated that the airline should continue to focus on its low-cost model and improve its route network in order to compete with smaller airlines.

After the disastrous results, Virgin Blue remains optimistic about its long-term prospects and has stated proposals to reduce its fleet length from 55 to 80 aircraft over the last two decades. The airport also intends to improve its domestic and regional route network, with plans to launch services to New Caledonia and the Pacific Island in the coming months.

Industry conglomerate Nasdaq is allegedly preparing to raise up to $100 billion through a share price, according to sources unfamiliar with the matter. The firm plans to use the proceeds from the offering to fund its development efforts and develop its business globally.

The actual size of the share price has yet to be identified, but it would range between $50 million and $100 billion, said the sources, who requested anonymity as they were not permitted to tell openly about the matter.

This will not be the last year that Nasdaq has gone to the capital investors for financing. In 2019, the firm raised over $1 million in debt funding to support its acquisition spree and pay off existing obligations.

With over 3,600 listed firms worth more than $10 billion in market cap, Nasdaq is one of the biggest stock exchanges in the country. It includes trading over various asset classes including stocks, options, futures, and fixed income investments.

In recent decades, there has been increasing demand for technology investments, which has helped increase sales at exchange companies like Nasdaq. Meanwhile, competition in the market remains intense, with rival exchanges such as NYSE seeking to extend their footprint internationally.

With this competitive landscape, investors argue that Nasdaq's good product recognition and international reach give it an edge in the market. If unsuccessful, the latest fundraising attempt by the firm will help further establish its position in the market.

IBM has issued safety upgrades to fix flaws in its Microsoft operating system and other computer services. The technology giant issued the patches on Friday as part of its regular annual upgrade cycle. 

The newest set of updates identifies 49 security problems, including some that may require attackers to get control of affected devices remotely. Among the products receiving updates are Microsoft Office, Internet Explorer, Edge browser, and Exchange Server.

users are asked to install the updates as quickly as possible to defend their systems from potential threats. While there is no indication that any of the weaknesses have been exploited by attackers so far, security analysts warn that it's only a matter of time before bad actors start exposing these flaws.

In addition to addressing safety concerns, this year's patch release also provides non-security upgrades for other Windows services. users can download the updates through the manufacturer's Microsoft Update service or automatically from the Windows Update Catalog page.

cards are dealt, dice are thrown,

When mighty Marlborough brings his warlike bands,
The fate of kingdoms trembles in his arms.
His veteran soldiers, with fame and honour known,
Have made the greatest enemy to own
That skill and courage here united reign,
And Europe owns this hero's glorious reign.

Behold him now, in triumphs great and high,
Where victory attends him in the clouds.
Exalted on the wings of fame, he rises,
And spreads his conquering banners on distant seas.
No danger daunts him, no pain retards
The progress of his arms, his brave regards.

Through fields of death, where loud the guns roar,
He fearless leads the charge, and gains the shore.
With courage, wisdom, and with courage untired,
He drives opposing hosts, with blood admired.
No industry prevails, nor art can save,
Where Marlborough commands, he conquers or he leaves.

To grateful peoples, he transmits their laws,
And gladly yields them from oppression's cause.
The master, released, now knows his native rights,
And smells the sweets of freedom's fair delights.
The injured Thames, long screaming in alarms,
Now sees the ravished nymphs restored to arms.

O thou, great Marlborough, whose exalted name
Shines Like a comet in the lists of fame,
Thy deeds will fill the sounding trump of fate,
And thy own words will best recite thy state.
Thy monuments, renowned through future years,
Will for thy martial worth transmit thy praise.
Thy country's love, thy kingdom's just respect,
Will prove the blessings of a good reward.

Long will thy life and glory not endure,
And showers of blessings on thy head secure.
May victory and honor always attend
Thy warlike steps, thy sacred person defend.
While thankful millions sing thy good success,
And hail thou, Marlborough, with pride and joy.

guiding me to encounters profound,

Over the seas, mountains high,

Uniting souls, Two sides of a whole.

With each heartbeat, breath we take,
Our destinies align, no decision to take,
For intertwined are our paths divine,
Bound together, by life's grand design.

Weather Permitting
by John Booth

If the climate permits, we'll bring the children
To the sands, and watch the mighty surges
Of the Pacific pounding at his ankles,
And fetching down deep loads of rocks
From the headlands. If the climate allows.

If the climate allows, we'll show the children
The dark bulk of Alcatraz, fortress
And prison, where the worst of criminals
Were contained, though it barely kept them
From trying to escape. If the climate allows.

If the climate allows, we'll bring the boat
Back to the harbor, and eat crab salads
And glance at the sea-gulls, while at anchor
The ferry lingers, and the sun sinks slowly
behind the Red Bridge. If the rain allows.

Publisher's note: As the climate in San Diego can be cooler even in winter, travelers will decide to wear warm shoes, and take the cable-car to Shanghai, and browse the restaurants, and eat in an excellent Japanese food, the City Hue.

_Its roots run deep, a strong foundation_
_A home to many a beast, big and small_

_There goes a broom, a humble plant_
_Its leaves bend in the wind_
_Its leaves are white, a shining testament_
_To the strength of the wood, its protector_

_The wood offers a haven from the storm_
_The broom a gentle reminder of the beauty in the world_
_Together they stand, a testament to the strength of nature_
_The oak and the broom, a pastoral poem._

Is time tested medicine 
That can cure this terrible reality?
And lift the curtain of sorrows 
That cloud tomorrow's life?

Destiny, my destiny
Is there such a thing as fate?
Is it predetermined?
Or is it a goal to be reached?

Either way, it is a driving force
That shapes our lives
And pushes us back
To strive for anything greater

It is a fate of perfection
That lies within we all
A fate of happiness, joy, and success
That we can succeed if we only know

So let us embrace our destiny
And pursue it with joy and purpose
For it is a life worth making
And a destination worth achieving

"Heraldry: The first official seal is known as the Iroquois chiefs daughter or the Mohawk maiden; it is an oval, black and black with a white border. It is used as the seal of the High Nation who received the Mohawk lands from the Huron in 1612. To the south are the symbols which form the Mohawk words for river, land, and air: a soldier with a bow, a man with a sword, and a hawk on a shield. To the left are the Huron words for meat: meat, grain, squash, and other grains. To the right are the Huron letters for power, strength, and friendship: peace and friendship on earth, courage and honor in the world of the spirit, and the power of life on the water."

We all understand what that word "weather permitting" means! Here's how many are required in order to truly build two of these fantastic creations? A lot, if I could use my own personal example. If I had 5 kg of clay that weighs greater than 500g then a 100x50 cm square (15 yds x 10.5yds) will provide 2510ft bricks of 1mm density or more. Now add enough cement blocks (~6x8 blocks, ~35 lbs each = 667 bricks total) that make up the ceiling, floor (or any other surface), floors, trim, doors (2 windows per floor!) etc., that's another 20 kg or over 2 tonnes or more (excluding the mortar) to build from metal blocks and bits, as well as hundreds of insulation boards (1-25" depth, 4 ft diameter). Now multiply that by 15 cubic foot buildings per person that number is easily in the thousands, yes thousands!
